'''2,4-Dinitrophenol''' ('''2,4-DNP''' or simply '''DNP''') is an organic compound with the formula HOC<sub>6</sub>H<sub>3</sub>(NO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. It is a yellow, crystalline solid that has a sweet, musty odor. It sublimes, is volatile with steam, and is soluble in most organic solvents as well as aqueous alkaline solutions.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/21297020|title=The Merck index : an encyclopedia of chemicals, drugs, and biologicals|last=|first=|date=1989|publisher=Merck|others=Budavari, Susan.|year=|isbn=091191028X|edition=11th ed., centennial|location=Rahway, N.J., U.S.A.|pages=1900|oclc=21297020}}</ref> It is a precursor to other chemicals and is biochemically active, inhibiting energy ([[adenosine triphosphate]], ATP) production in cells with mitochondria. Its use in high doses as a dieting aid has been identified with severe side-effects, including a number of deaths.<ref name=PMC3550200Tab1>{{cite journal | url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3550200/table/Tab1/ | title = Summary of previously published fatalities relating to exposure to DNP including basic demographics, amount of exposure and maximal temperature recorded pre-death | pmc=3550200 | pmid=21739343 | doi=10.1007/s13181-011-0162-6 | volume=7 | journal=J Med Toxicol | pages=205–12 | vauthors=Grundlingh J, Dargan PI, El-Zanfaly M, Wood DM | year=2011}}</ref>
==Synthesis== DNP is produced by hydrolysis of [[2,4-Dinitrochlorobenzene|1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene]].<ref name=Booth>Gerald Booth "Nitro Compounds, Aromatic" in "Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry" 2007; Wiley-VCH, Weinheim. {{DOI|10.1002/14356007.a17_411}} {{Dead link|date=October 2017}}</ref>
==Uses== Commercial DNP is used as an antiseptic and as a non-selective [[bioaccumulation|bioaccumulating]] pesticide.<ref name="EPA">{{cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2016-09/documents/2-4-dinitrophenol.pdf|title=2,4-Dinitrophenol|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Environmental Protection Agency]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref> It is a chemical intermediate in the production of [[sulfur dye]]s,<ref name=Booth/> wood preservatives<ref name=EPA/> and [[picric acid]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=2B4VqK18VOUC&lpg=PA132&dq=picric%20acid%20synthesis%20further%20nitration%20dinitrophenol&pg=PA132#v=onepage&q=picric%20acid%20synthesis%20further%20nitration%20dinitrophenol&f=false|title=Organic Chemistry of Explosives|last=Agrawal|first=Jai Prakash|last2=Hodgson|first2=Robert|date=2007-01-11|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9780470059357|language=en}}</ref> DNP has also been used to make photographic developers and explosives (see [[Shellite (explosive)|shellite]]).<ref name="pmid21739343">{{Cite journal|last=Grundlingh|first=Johann|last2=Dargan|first2=Paul I.|last3=El-Zanfaly|first3=Marwa|last4=Wood|first4=David M.|date=September 2011|title=2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP): a weight loss agent with significant acute toxicity and risk of death|journal=Journal of Medical Toxicology: Official Journal of the American College of Medical Toxicology|volume=7|issue=3|pages=205–212|doi=10.1007/s13181-011-0162-6|issn=1937-6995|pmc=3550200|pmid=21739343}}</ref> DNP is classified as an explosive in UK<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rnXUDAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA452&ots=eT4b7avODJ&dq=dinitrophenol%20is%20classified%20as%20explosive%20in%20United%20Kingdom&pg=PA452#v=onepage&q=dinitrophenol%20is%20classified%20as%20explosive%20in%20United%20Kingdom&f=false|title=Bretherick's Handbook of Reactive Chemical Hazards|last=Urben|first=Peter|date=2017-03-18|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=9780081010594|language=en}}</ref> and USA.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2017/12/28/2017-28010/commerce-in-explosives-2017-annual-list-of-explosive-materials|title=Commerce in Explosives; 2017 Annual List of Explosive Materials|date=2017-12-28|work=Federal Register|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref>
DNP is particularly used as a herbicide alongside with other closely related dinitrophenol herbicides like [[Dinitro-ortho-cresol|2,4-dinitro-''o''-cresol]] (DNOC), [[dinoseb]] and [[dinoterb]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/717387050|title=Reproductive and developmental toxicology|last=|first=|date=2011|publisher=Academic Press|others=Gupta, Ramesh C.|year=|isbn=9780123820327|location=London|pages=509|oclc=717387050}}</ref>
== Chemical hazards == Dust explosion possible if in powder or granular form, mixed with air. May explosively decompose on shock, friction or concussion. May explode on heating.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=e4_S46UcI2AC&lpg=PT399&ots=oxE0nLE33O&dq=%22dinitrophenol%22%20dust%20or%20powder%20forms%20explosive%20mixture%20with%20air&pg=PT399#v=onepage&q=%22dinitrophenol%22%20dust%20or%20powder%20forms%20explosive%20mixture%20with%20air&f=false|title=Encyclopaedia of Occupational Health and Safety: Guides, indexes, directory|last=Stellman|first=Jeanne Mager|date=1998|publisher=International Labour Organization|isbn=9789221098171|language=en}}</ref> DNP forms explosive salts with [[base (chemistry)|strong bases]] and [[ammonia]], and emits toxic fumes of [[nitrogen dioxide]] when heated to decomposition.<ref>{{cite book|title=Dangerous properties of industrial materials|last=Sax|first=N.Irving|author2=Bruce, Robert D|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=1989|isbn=0-442-27368-1|edition=7th|volume=3}}</ref> DNP [[Strength (explosive)|explosive strength]] is 81% of [[TNT]] according to [[Trauzl lead block test]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=4TIkDAAAQBAJ&lpg=PT340&dq=Lead%20block%20excavation%20values%20dinitrophenol&pg=PT340#v=onepage&q=Lead%20block%20excavation%20values%20dinitrophenol&f=false|title=Explosives|last=Meyer|first=Rudolf|last2=Köhler|first2=Josef|last3=Homburg|first3=Axel|date=2016-05-09|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9783527689613|language=en}}</ref>
==Biochemical aspects== In living cells, DNP acts as a proton [[ionophore]], an agent that can shuttle [[protons]] (hydrogen cations) across biological membranes. It dissipates the proton gradient across [[mitochondria]] and [[chloroplast]] membranes, collapsing the [[proton motive force]] that the cell uses to produce most of its [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] chemical energy. Instead of producing ATP, the energy of the proton gradient is lost as heat.<ref name="PMC3550200Tab1" />
DNP is often used in [[biochemistry]] research to help explore the [[bioenergetics]] of [[Chemiosmosis|chemiosmotic]] and other [[membrane transport]] processes.
===Health effects=== DNP is considered to have high [[acute toxicity]].<ref name=EPA/> Acute oral exposure to DNP has resulted in increased basal metabolic rate, nausea, vomiting, sweating, dizziness, headache, and loss of weight.<ref name=EPA/> Chronic oral exposure to DNP can lead to the formation of cataracts and [[skin lesion]]s and has caused effects on the [[bone marrow]], [[central nervous system]], and [[cardiovascular system]].<ref name=EPA/><ref>{{cite journal | publisher = Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry | title = Toxicological Profile for Dinitrophenols | author = Public Health Service, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services | date = 1995}}</ref>
===Dieting aid=== DNP was used extensively in [[Anti-obesity medication|diet pills]] from 1933 to 1938 after Cutting and Tainter at Stanford University made their first report on the drug's ability to greatly increase metabolic rate.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cutting WC, Mehrtens HG, Tainter ML | title = Actions and uses of dinitrophenol: Promising metabolic applications | journal = [[J Am Med Assoc]] | year = 1933 | volume = 101 | issue = 3 | pages = 193–195 | doi = 10.1001/jama.1933.02740280013006 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Tainter ML, Stockton AB, Cutting WC | title = Use of dinitrophenol in obesity and related conditions: a progress report | journal = [[J Am Med Assoc]] | year = 1933 | volume = 101 | issue = 19 | pages = 1472–1475 | doi = 10.1001/jama.1933.02740440032009 }}</ref> After only its first year on the market Tainter estimated that at least 100,000 people had been treated with DNP in the United States, in addition to many others abroad.<ref>{{ cite journal |vauthors=Tainter ML, Cutting WC, Stockton AB | title = Use of Dinitrophenol in Nutritional Disorders : A Critical Survey of Clinical Results | journal = [[Am J Public Health]] | year = 1934 | volume = 24 | issue = 10 | pages = 1045–1053 | doi = 10.2105/AJPH.24.10.1045 | pmc = 1558869 | pmid = 18014064 | url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1558869/pdf/amjphnation00921-0049.pdf | format = pdf }}</ref> DNP acts as a [[protonophore]], allowing protons to leak across the inner [[mitochondrial membrane]] and thus bypass [[ATP synthase]]. This makes ATP energy production less efficient. In effect, part of the energy that is normally produced from cellular respiration is wasted as heat. The inefficiency is proportional to the dose of DNP that is taken. As the dose increases and energy production is made more inefficient, metabolic rate increases (and more fat is burned) in order to compensate for the inefficiency and to meet energy demands. DNP is probably the best known agent for uncoupling [[oxidative phosphorylation]]. The "[[phosphorylation]]" of [[adenosine diphosphate]] (ADP) by ATP synthase gets disconnected or "uncoupled" from oxidation.
The factor that limits ever-increasing doses of DNP is not a lack of ATP energy production, but rather an excessive rise in body temperature due to the heat produced during uncoupling. Accordingly, DNP overdose will cause fatal [[hyperthermia]], with body temperature rising to as high as {{convert|44|C|F}} shortly before death. In light of this, when it was used clinically, the dose was slowly [[Dosing|titrated]] according to personal tolerance, which varies greatly.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Simkins S. | title = Dinitrophenol and desiccated thyroid in the treatment of obesity: a comprehensive clinical and laboratory study | journal = [[J Am Med Assoc]] | year = 1937 | volume = 108 | pages = 2110–2117 | doi=10.1001/jama.1937.02780250024006}}</ref>
Case reports have shown that an acute administration of 20–50 mg per kilogram of body weight in humans can be lethal.<ref name="pmid16035205">{{cite journal |vauthors=Hsiao AL, Santucci KA, Seo-Mayer P |title=Pediatric fatality following ingestion of dinitrophenol: postmortem identification of a "dietary supplement" |journal=Clin Toxicol |volume=43 |issue=4 |pages=281–285 |year=2005 |pmid=16035205 |url= |doi=10.1081/clt-200058946|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The lowest published fatal ingested dose is 4.3 mg/kg.<ref name="pmid21739343" /> Concerns about dangerous side-effects and rapidly developing [[cataracts]]<ref>{{Cite journal|title = A Study of Dinitrophenol and Its Relation to Cataract Formation | pmc=1315023 | pmid=16693262 | volume=39 | year=1941 | journal=Trans Am Ophthalmol Soc | pages=405–37 | vauthors=Horner WD}}</ref> resulted in DNP being discontinued in the United States by the end of 1938.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Colman|first=Eric|date=July 2007|title=Dinitrophenol and obesity: an early twentieth-century regulatory dilemma|journal=[[Regulatory toxicology and pharmacology]]|volume=48|issue=2|pages=115–117|doi=10.1016/j.yrtph.2007.03.006|issn=0273-2300|pmid=17475379}}</ref> DNP, however, continues to be used by some [[bodybuilding|bodybuilders]] and athletes to rapidly lose body fat. Fatal overdoses include cases of accidental exposure,<ref name="pmid7058360">{{cite journal |vauthors=Leftwich RB, Floro JF, Neal RA, Wood AJ |title=Dinitrophenol poisoning: a diagnosis to consider in undiagnosed fever |journal=South. Med. J. |volume=75 |issue=2 |pages=182–184 |date=February 1982 |pmid=7058360 |doi= 10.1097/00007611-198202000-00016|url=http://meta.wkhealth.com/pt/pt-core/template-journal/lwwgateway/media/landingpage.htm?issn=0038-4348&volume=75&issue=2&spage=182| accessdate= 18 November 2008 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> suicide,<ref name="pmid16035205" /><ref name="GermanDeath">A. Hahn, K. Begemann, R. Burger, J. Hillebrand, H. Meyer, K. Preußner: "Cases of Poisoning Reported by Physicians in 2006", page 40. BfR Press and Public Relations Office, 2006.</ref><ref name="pmid20156878">{{cite journal |vauthors=Bartlett J, Brunner M, Gough K |title=Deliberate poisoning with dinitrophenol (DNP): an unlicensed weight loss pill |journal=Emerg Med J |volume=27 |issue=2 |pages=159–160 |date=February 2010 |pmid=20156878 |doi=10.1136/emj.2008.069401 |url=}}</ref> and excessive intentional exposure (overdose).<ref name="GermanDeath" /><ref name="pmid15487646">{{cite journal |vauthors=McFee RB, Caraccio TR, McGuigan MA, Reynolds SA, Bellanger P |title=Dying to be thin: a dinitrophenol related fatality |journal=Veterinary and human toxicology |volume=46 |issue=5 |pages=251–254 |year=2004 |pmid=15487646 }}</ref><ref name="pmid16803658">{{cite journal |vauthors=Miranda EJ, McIntyre IM, Parker DR, Gary RD, Logan BK |title=Two deaths attributed to the use of 2,4-dinitrophenol |journal=Journal of Analytical Toxicology |volume=30 |issue=3 |pages=219–222 |year=2006 |pmid=16803658 |doi=10.1093/jat/30.3.219}}</ref> The substance's use as a dieting aid has also led to a number of accidental fatalities.<ref>{{cite journal| pmid=15487646 | volume=46 | title=Dying to be thin: a dinitrophenol related fatality | date=October 2004 | journal=Vet Hum Toxicol | pages=251–4 | vauthors=McFee RB, Caraccio TR, McGuigan MA, Reynolds SA, Bellanger P}}</ref><ref>http://wiadomosci.onet.pl/regionalne/warszawa/dwudziestolatka-zmarla-po-kuracji-odchudzajacej-za,1,5535542,region-wiadomosc.html</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wiadomosci.onet.pl/regionalne/warszawa/dwudziestolatka-zmarla-po-kuracji-odchudzajacej-za,1,5535542,region-wiadomosc.html|title=Dwudziestolatka zmarła po kuracji odchudzającej. Zażywała DNP|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/04/20/mothers-heart-wrenching-warning-after-daughters-insides-explode-like-tnt-from-taking-internet-diet-pills-5159053/|title=21-year-old's insides 'explode like TNT' after taking deadly diet pills|date=2015-04-20|work=Metro|access-date=2017-10-14|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-24123194|title=Chris Mapletoft parents 'shocked' over diet pills death|publisher=BBC News|date=17 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Hyderabad millionaire's son dies after taking bodybuilding pills | url = http://ibnlive.in.com/news/uk-hyderabad-millionaires-son-dies-after-taking-bodybuilding-pills/374363-62-127.html}}</ref> In [[England and Wales]] alone, between 2007 and 2016 dinitrophenol was mentioned on the death certificate as being involved in 15 deaths.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/birthsdeathsandmarriages/deaths/adhocs/007648numberofdeathswheredinitrophenoldnpwasmentionedonthedeathcertificateenglandandwales2007to2016|title=Number of deaths where dinitrophenol (DNP) was mentioned on the death certificate, England and Wales, 2007 to 2016|last=|first=|date=2017-10-24|website=www.ons.gov.uk|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref> The [[Food Standards Agency]] are aware about 8 deaths involving DNP between 1 January 2017 and 30 June 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://s3.eu-west-2.amazonaws.com/fsa-catalogue2/fsaresponsedinitrophenolrelateddeathsintheuk.pdf|title=FSA Freedom of Information request|last=|first=|date=2018-07-23|website=www.food.gov.uk|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-06}}</ref>
Although DNP is widely considered too dangerous for clinical use, its [[mechanism of action]] remains under investigation as a potential approach for treating obesity.<ref name="pmid12119996">{{cite journal |vauthors=Harper JA, Dickinson K, Brand MD |title=Mitochondrial uncoupling as a target for drug development for the treatment of obesity |journal=Obesity Reviews |volume=2 |issue=4 |pages=255–265 |year=2001 |pmid=12119996 |doi =10.1046/j.1467-789X.2001.00043.x }}</ref> Currently, research is being conducted on [[uncoupling protein]]s naturally found in humans.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Busiello|first=Rosa A.|last2=Savarese|first2=Sabrina|last3=Lombardi|first3=Assunta|date=2015-02-10|title=Mitochondrial uncoupling proteins and energy metabolism|journal=Frontiers in Physiology|volume=6|doi=10.3389/fphys.2015.00036|issn=1664-042X|pmc=4322621|pmid=25713540}}</ref>
The United Kingdom's [[Food Standards Agency]] identifies DNP as "an industrial chemical known to have serious short-term and long-term effects, which can be extremely dangerous to human health." and advises "consumers not to take any product containing DNP at any level. This chemical is not suitable for human consumption."<ref>{{cite web|title=Warning about 'fat-burner' substances containing DNP|url=http://www.food.gov.uk/news-updates/news/2012/nov/dnp-warning#.UXZBuJWTAYM|publisher=Food Standards Agency|accessdate=23 April 2013}}</ref>
===Pharmacokinetics=== Information about [[pharmacokinetics]] of DNP in humans is limited and conflicting. The EPA states that "Data on the elimination kinetics of the dinitrophenols or their metabolic products in humans were not found."<ref>{{cite web | publisher = [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] | title = Ambient water quality criteria for nitrophenols, 440/5-80-063 | url = http://www.epa.gov/ost/pc/ambientwqc/nitrophenols80.pdf |format=PDF| year = 1980| accessdate= 9 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> The [[ATSDR]]'s Toxicological Profile for Dinitrophenols also states that "No studies were located regarding distribution in humans after oral exposure to 2,4-DNP. Limited information is available regarding distribution in animals after oral exposure to 2,4-DNP." However, they do state that "Elimination from the body appears to be rapid, except possibly in cases of compromised liver function."<ref>{{cite web |author1=Harris, M. O. |author2=Cocoran, J. J. | year = 1995 | title = Toxicological Profile for Dinitrophenols | publisher = [[Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry]] | url = http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/tp.asp?id=729&tid=132 | accessdate=23 April 2013}}</ref> This coincides with a review in the NEJM on the biological actions of dinitrophenol, which stated that "Judging from the metabolic response, DNP appears to be eliminated entirely in three or four days; in the presence of liver or kidney damage it is possible that the drug will be retained over a longer period."<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1056/NEJM193408302110901 | author = Edsall, G. | year = 1934 | title = Biological actions of dinitrophenol and related compounds: a review | journal = [[The New England Journal of Medicine]] | volume = 211 | pages = 385–390 | issue = 9}}</ref> Oddly, more recent papers give an array of possible half-lives, ranging from 3 hours,<ref name="pmid16045446">{{cite journal |vauthors=Korde AS, Pettigrew LC, Craddock SD, Maragos WF |title=The mitochondrial uncoupler 2,4-dinitrophenol attenuates tissue damage and improves mitochondrial homeostasis following transient focal cerebral ischemia |journal=J. Neurochem. |volume=94 |issue=6 |pages=1676–1684 |date=September 2005 |pmid=16045446 |doi=10.1111/j.1471-4159.2005.03328.x }}</ref> to 5–14 days.<ref name="pmid16035205" /> Other recent papers maintain that the half-life in humans is unknown.<ref name="GermanDeath" />
Although further investigation is needed, one case report notes that dinitrophenol-induced hyperthermia has been successfully resolved with [[dantrolene]] administration.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kumar S, Barker K, Seger D | year = 2002 | title = Dinitrophenol-Induced Hyperthermia Resolving With Dantrolene Administration. Abstracts of the North American Congress of Clinical Toxicology | url = | journal = Clin Toxicol | volume = 40 | issue = | pages = 599–673 | doi=10.1081/clt-120016859}}</ref> "Dinitrophenol uncouples oxidative phosphorylation, causes release of calcium from mitochondrial stores and prevents calcium re-uptake. This leads to free intracellular calcium and causes muscle contraction and hyperthermia. Dantrolene inhibits calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum which reduces intracellular calcium. The resulting muscle relaxation allows heat dissipation. There is little risk to dantrolene administration. Since dantrolene may be effective in reducing hyperthermia caused by agents that inhibit oxidative phosphorylation, early administration may improve outcome."<ref name="pmid16749560">{{cite journal |vauthors=Barker K, Seger D, Kumar S |title=Comment on "Pediatric fatality following ingestion of Dinitrophenol: postmortem identification of a 'dietary supplement'" |journal=Clin Toxicol |volume=44 |issue=3 |pages=351 |year=2006 |pmid=16749560 |doi= 10.1080/15563650600584709|url=}}</ref>
==Commerce== In 2003, a vendor of DNP was sentenced to prison for [[mail and wire fraud|mail fraud]], with the FDA's [[Office of Criminal Investigations|OCI]] investigators having gathered evidence that the vendor's [[capsule (pharmacy)|encapsulation]] of DNP was neither accurate nor sanitary.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.fda.gov/ICECI/EnforcementActions/EnforcementStory/EnforcementStoryArchive/ucm096380.htm|title = Office of Criminal Investigation 2003|date = 8 Jun 2015|accessdate = 10 Sep 2015|website = U.S. Food and Drug Administration|publisher = U.S. Food and Drug Administration}}</ref> In 2018, a seller in [[United Kingdom]] was convicted of [[Manslaughter in English law|manslaughter]] for selling DNP as "fatburner" for human consumption.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.harrow.gov.uk/news/article/673/harrow_council_wins_landmark_dnp_manslaughter_case|title=Harrow Council wins landmark DNP manslaughter case|last=|first=|date=2018-06-27|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref>
==Environmental effects== DNP is considered an important environmental contaminant by the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]]. It has been found in 61 of 1400 priority sites that need clean-up of industrial waste. It can enter the air from automobile exhaust, burning of certain industrial substances, and from reaction of nitrogen in air with other atmospheric chemicals. The major site of degradation is the soil, where microorganisms metabolize it.
However, the effects of DNP on [[Anaerobic organism|anaerobic]] micro-organisms are still largely undetermined. Some studies suggest that there is anaerobic toxicity due to a reduced methane production.

The constitution passed by 98.5%.<ref name=kingtriumphs/> *Parliamentary elections were held on 25 November.<ref name=electionboycott/> | injuries = 128<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/59AF3EEC-1269-4F56-9806-23E586288D59.htm?GoogleStatID=9|title=قتلى بشغب أعقب مظاهرات المغرب|publisher=AlJazeera.net|date=21 February 2011|accessdate=24 February 2011}}</ref> | fatalities = 6<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=224033|work=The Jerusalem Post|date=7 June 2011|accessdate=11 June 2011|title=Demonstrator's death energizes Moroccan protesters|first=David|last=Miller}}</ref> | map_type = | map_caption = | time = | timezone = }} {{History of Morocco}} The '''Moroccan protests''' are a series of demonstrations across [[Morocco]] which occurred from 20 February 2011 to the spring of 2012. They were inspired by [[Arab Spring|other protests in the region]].<ref name="businessweek Unrest Spreads">{{cite news|last=Hatem|first=Mohammed|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-02-16/bahrain-yemen-libya-face-protests-as-region-s-unrest-spreads.html|title=Bahrain, Yemen, Libya Face Protests as Region’s Unrest Spreads|work= Business Week|date=16 February 2011}}</ref> The protests were organized by the '''20 February Movement'''.
==Origin== The protests in Morocco were inspired by the [[Arab Spring]] protests and revolutions in other North African countries.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YxAzDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA97|title=Morocco: Challenges to Tradition and Modernity|last=Sater|first=James N.|date=2016-05-20|publisher=Routledge|year=|isbn=9781317573982|location=|pages=97|language=en}}</ref> They were centred around demands for political reform, which included reform against police brutality, electoral fraud, political censorship and high unemployment.
==Timeline==
===2011=== On 20 February, thousands of Moroccans rallied in the capital, [[Rabat]], to demand that King Mohammed give up some of his powers, chanting slogans such as "Down with autocracy" and "The people want to change the constitution."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703498804576156180408970252?mod=googlenews_wsj | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Marc | last=Champion | title=Morocco Joins in, Defying Predictions | date=21 February 2011}}</ref> They were heading towards the parliament building, and police did not halt them, although Moroccan Finance Minister Salaheddine Mezouar said that people should not join the march. A separate protest was underway in [[Casablanca]] and one was planned for [[Marrakesh]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12518116 |title=Morocco protesters demand political change |work=BBC |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110221024225/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12518116| archivedate= 21 February 2011 |accessdate=21 February 2011}}</ref>
Thousands took to the streets of Rabat, Casablanca, Tangier and Marrakech in peaceful protests demanding a new constitution, a change in government and an end to corruption. During a march on Hassan II Avenue in the capital, Rabat, demonstrators demanded a new constitution to bring more democracy to the country. They shouted slogans calling for economic opportunity, education reform, better health services, and help in coping with the rising cost of living.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/856068-protests-spread-to-streets-of-morocco |title=Protests spread to streets of Morocco |work=Metro NEws |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=21 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/02/20/moroccans-want-to-reign-in-royal-powers/ |title=Moroccans want to reign in royal powers |work=Euronews |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=21 February 2011}}</ref>
The Associated Press estimated the turnout in Rabat at 4,000, while organisers put the crowd outside Parliament at 20,000.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/africa/articles/2011/02/21/moroccans_join_in_spreading_unrest |title=Moroccans join in spreading unrest |work=Boston Globe |first=Hassan|last=Alaoui |agency=Associated Press |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=21 February 2011|location=Rabat}}</ref> The Interior Ministry estimated that the total number of protesters was about 37,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/ARTJAWEB20110221162602/maroc-violences-mohammed-vi-reformele-bilan-des-manifestations-au-maroc-s-eleve-a-cinq-morts-et-128-blesses.html |title=Le bilan des manifestations au Maroc s’élève à cinq morts et 128 blessés |publisher=Jeune Afrique |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=21 February 2011}}</ref>
On 26 February, about 1,000 people demonstrated in [[Casablanca]] demanding political reforms, according to [[Agence France-Presse|AFP]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/ipad/at-reform-rally-in-morocco/story-fn6s850w-1226012647707|title=Casablanca catches protest fever |date=27 February 2011|accessdate=1 March 2011|work=Herald Sun|agency=Agence France-Presse}}</ref>
On 13 March, several hundred demonstrators gathered in Casablanca demanding reforms. Riot police broke up the rally with batons, injuring dozens in what was described as the most violent intervention since the start of the protests.<ref>{{cite news |title=Moroccan police break up rally, hurt dozens-witness |url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE72D00X20110314?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews&sp=true |agency=Reuters Africa |date=14 March 2011|accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref>
On 20 March, an estimated 35,000 citizens of diverse backgrounds and interests<ref>[http://www.map.ma/eng/sections/social/around_35000_protes/view "Around 35,000 protested on Sunday in different Moroccan cities - authorities"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110324185500/http://www.map.ma/eng/sections/social/around_35000_protes/view |date=24 March 2011 }}, Agence Maghreb Arabe Presse. 21 March 2011. Retrieved 23 March 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.moroccoboard.com/news/34/5153 "Photos of 20 March Protests in Morocco"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110323113415/http://www.moroccoboard.com/news/34/5153 |date=23 March 2011 }}, Morocco Board News Service. 20 March 2011. Retrieved 23 March 2011</ref> participated in peaceful protests in more than 60 cities across the country, some demanding more political changes than those announced by King Mohammed in his 9 March address, with others wanting to keep up the pressure so that the reforms come about.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iu2GgwAB5vFQmq-iZrp2ZsSD4W3Q?docId=CNG.30929bbed886ca3041584a88b0537905.d81|title=Thousands rally in call for Morocco reforms|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=20 March 2011|accessdate=14 January 2012|publisher=Google News|location=Rabat}}</ref> The police did not intervene and no violent acts were reported.
On 24 April, thousands of people protested across Morocco, demanding an end to corruption, an independent judiciary, constitutional reforms, legislative elections as well as more jobs for university graduates.<ref>{{cite news |title=Protesters demand reform in Morocco|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/04/201142512013759717.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=25 April 2011 |accessdate=25 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110429090358/http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/04/201142512013759717.html| archivedate= 29 April 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="24AprAFP">{{cite news |title=Moroccans stage peaceful pro-democracy protests |agency=Agence France-Presse|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jLVsfu60TI8Ev8KlOaNQdZgp5uNw?docId=CNG.f9dc8540002b694b3f07a574f74a6ed3.ce1 |publisher=Google News |date=24 April 2011 |accessdate=25 April 2011|location=Rabat}}</ref>
On 8 May, thousands of Moroccans marched in Marrakesh to demand reforms and express their opposition towards terrorist attacks, like the one on 28 April.<ref>{{cite news |title=Thousands demand reform in Morocco rally |first=Souhail|last=Karam |url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE74716020110508?sp=true |agency=Reuters Canada |date=8 May 2011 |accessdate=11 May 2011|location=Marrakesh}}</ref>
On 22 May, Moroccan police spent hours chasing hundreds of pro-democracy activists through the streets of the capital in an effort to prevent any pro-reform demonstrations. The government appeared to be implementing a new zero-tolerance policy for protesters.<ref>[http://hosted2.ap.org/APDEFAULT/Article_2011-05-22-ML-Morocco-Demonstrations/id-paaa0869d0d074b9388450639c6688ea5 Associated Press 22 May 2011]</ref>
On 5 June, nearly 60,000 protesters convened in Rabat and Casablanca to demonstrate, many carrying a picture of Kamal Amari,<ref>[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/06/06/Up-to-60000-protesters-march-in-Morocco/UPI-24741307361952/?spt=hs&or=tn "Up to 60,000 protesters march in Morocco"], UPI. 6 June 2011. accseesd 6 June 2011</ref> who died from police brutality. The death highlighted escalating police brutality directed at demonstrators.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/05/30/morocco.protests.violence/ "Police violence reaching new levels in Morocco with Sunday beatings"], CNN. 30 May 2011. Retrieved 6 June 2011</ref>
On 28 July, a few dozen 20 February Movement protesters gathered in front of a courthouse in Safi to demand authorities to free two unfairly arrested Sebt Gzoula demonstrators. Those two{{who|date=November 2012}} were arrested under false claims of attacking government forces.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}}
Protests have continued nearly every Sunday, with thousands marching in cities around Morocco calling for governmental reform.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}}
On 18 September, 3,000 protesters marched through the streets of Casablanca in the largest such demonstration in months.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/09/18/ap/middleeast/main20107964.shtml |title=Morocco's democracy protests restart after hiatus |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110919155145/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/09/18/ap/middleeast/main20107964.shtml |archivedate=2011-09-19}}</ref>
===2012=== {{Off-topic|date=March 2013}} On 27 May, tens of thousands of Moroccans took to the streets of [[Casablanca]] protesting against the government’s alleged failure to tackle unemployment and other social woes, accusing Prime Minister [[Abdelilah Benkirane]] of failing to deliver promised reforms.<ref>{{cite news | title = Morocco protests fill Casablanca streets| date=27 May 2012 | publisher=BBC News| url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18231125| accessdate=10 September 2012}}</ref>
On 22 July, hundreds of protesters led by 20 February Youth Movement marched in the working class area of [[Sidi Bernoussi]] in Casablanca and chanted against government policies, social marginalisation, and corruption. They also took aim at the wealthy clique of Moroccans known as the [[Makhzen]], the governing elite centred around monarch King [[Mohammed VI]]. They were later met with violence by police; suddenly at the very end, police started beating street vendors and passers-by and later started chasing and apprehending protesters.<ref>{{cite news|last=Molloy|first=Connor| title = Morocco protests turn violent| date=25 July 2012 | work=Daily News Egypt| url = http://thedailynewsegypt.com/2012/07/25/morocco-protests-turn-violent/| accessdate=10 September 2012}}</ref>
On 11 August, nearly 1,000 people gathered in Casablanca chanting anti-corruption slogans, denouncing the sharp rise in prices, and calling for the release of jailed activists, with another 300 people gathered near the main boulevard in [[Rabat]] chanting slogans criticising Prime Minister Abdelilah Benkirane and King Mohammed VI, while waving anti-government banners. Activists blame the ruling [[Justice and Development Party (Morocco)|Justice and Development Party (PJD)]] for a surge in fuel prices — petrol jumped by 20% in June 2012 when the government moved to cut its unaffordable subsidies bill — that has driven up the cost of food and other basic goods. They also accuse the moderate [[Islamist]] party of not fulfilling its campaign pledges to address social grievances and fight corruption.<ref>{{cite news| title = Anti-government demos in Morocco's main cities| date=11 August 2012 | publisher=Agence France-Presse (via Google)| url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hMyJ5rFtqF4ToxuixWwMXTsJ806g?docId=CNG.0ecd32f22630d8846ffcba9428901618.91| accessdate=10 September 2012}}</ref>
Dozens of activists gathered on 23 August outside Parliament to call for the abolition of the ceremony of the [[Bay'ah]], in which government officials bow down before King Mohammed VI in an elaborate ritual at the palace in Rabat, an annual event normally held on 30 July to commemorate the king's coronation 13 years ago. Opposition activists say the event perpetuates a "backwardness" and "servitude" in Morocco that is inappropriate for the 21st century, touching on a highly sensitive issue in the [[North African]] country. Most of those attending demonstration were members of the 20 February Youth Movement.<ref>{{cite news|last=Martelli|first=Simon|title=Protest over Morocco king loyalty ritual highlights tensions| date=23 August 2012 | publisher=Agence France-Presse (via Google)|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iL-sPVYaDTFBuxsIX0ydVsUYG3gw?docId=CNG.70a031fd8f1cbe07c563f19c1c6f856f.1a1| accessdate=10 September 2012}}</ref>
About 500 demonstrators marched in Rabat on 23 September to protest against corruption and political detentions. The marchers, mostly youths, chanted slogans urging the authorities to release from prison members of the 20 February Youth Movement. There were no reports of unrest and the march ended peacefully.<ref>{{cite news|title=Protests in Rabat against political detentions |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jA6jKrty4836LFDx7I3yYb_UAT-A?docId=CNG.ecf981e7cccc633c7b442e7e2570178e.831|accessdate=24 September 2012|publisher=Agence France-Presse (via Google) |date=23 September 2012}}</ref>
==Domestic response== On 9 March, in a live televised address, King Mohammed VI announced his decision to undertake a comprehensive constitutional reform aimed at improving democracy and the rule of law, and underlined his "firm commitment to giving a strong impetus to the dynamic and deep reforms... taking place". The monarch announced the formation of a commission to work on the constitutional revisions, with proposals to be made to him by June after which a [[Moroccan constitutional referendum, 2011|referendum]] would be held on the draft constitution.<ref>{{cite news |title= Moroccan monarch pledges reform |publisher=Al Jazeera |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/03/201139204839521962.html |date=9 March 2011 |accessdate=9 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110310063322/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/03/201139204839521962.html| archivedate= 10 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The commission was widely criticised by the protest movement leaders, which refused to participate in the commission's work, despite being invited to do so by the government.
On 14 April, King Mohammed VI pardoned or reduced the sentences of 190 prisoners, including Islamists and [[Sahrawi independence]] activists.<ref name="24AprAFP"/>
==Constitutional reform proposals== In a televised speech on 17 June, [[Mohammed VI of Morocco|King Mohammed VI]] announced a series of constitutional reforms, passed through [[Moroccan constitutional referendum, 2011|a national referendum]] on 1 July.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/18/world/africa/18morocco.html?_r=1&src=me&ref=world Morocco King Proposes Limited Steps to Democracy], ''[[The New York Times]]'', 17 June 2011. Retrieved 19 June 2011</ref> The newly proposed reforms were largely supported by Moroccans, and popular celebrations were observed throughout the country, although the leaders of the 20 February Movement rejected the proposals as insufficient and called for continuing protests on 19 June 2011 demanding "truly democratic constitution and a parliamentary monarchy", while calling for a mass boycott of the poll.<ref name="aj">[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/06/201161810543184895.html Protests called against Morocco reform plan,] [[Al Jazeera]], 18 June 2011. Retrieved 19 June 2011</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13827502 | publisher=BBC News | title=Moroccans demonstrate over king's proposed reforms | date=20 June 2011}}</ref> On 29 June 2011, the protesters called for a boycott of the referendum.<ref>http://derstandard.at/1308680006152/Demokratiebewegung-ruft-zum-Boykott-auf</ref>
The proposed reforms passed and gave the prime minister and parliament more executive authority, and made [[Berber languages|Berber]] an official language in Morocco, together with [[Arabic language|Arabic]], as well as the [[Hassānīya language|Arab-Hassani Language]] spoken among the [[Saharawi]] tribes of Morocco. The proposal empowered the prime minister with the authority to appoint government officials and to dissolve the parliament - the powers previously held by the king.<ref name="aj"/> However, the king remains the military commander-in-chief and retains his position as the chair of the Council of Ministers and the Supreme Security Council, the primary bodies responsible for the security policy.<ref name="aj"/> A new constitutional provision also confirms the king's role as the highest religious authority in the country.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13816974 Morocco's King Mohammed unveils constitutional reforms], [[BBC News]], 18 June 2011. Retrieved 19 June 2011</ref>
In a televised speech on 30 July the king said the constitutional changes should be implemented swiftly, starting with [[Moroccan parliamentary election, 2011|parliamentary elections]], adding that "any delay may jeopardise this dynamic of trust and squander opportunities offered by the new reform". After negotiations between the interior ministry, which oversees elections, and some 20 political parties, the government proposed that parliamentary elections should take place on 11 November instead of the scheduled date of September next year.<ref>{{cite news |title=Morocco to host early parliamentary election|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/08/201181541738753674.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=15 August 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011}}</ref>
A large number of protesters went onto the streets again on 11 September 2011<ref>http://derstandard.at/1315006080977/Tausende-demonstrieren-erneut-fuer-demokratische-Reformen</ref> and on 18 September 2011.<ref>{{cite news |title=Morocco’s pro-democracy movements start demonstrations again after hiatus |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/moroccos-pro-democracy-movements-start-demonstrations-again-after-hiatus/2011/09/18/gIQArwB2cK_story.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110923023420/http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/moroccos-pro-democracy-movements-start-demonstrations-again-after-hiatus/2011/09/18/gIQArwB2cK_story.html |archive-date=2011-09-23 |deadurl=yes}} </ref>
==Media platforms== One of the media platforms that advertised the movement was [[Mamfakinch]], a collaborative website that published content mainly in French and Arabic, but also English. "Mamfakinch" means "no concession."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://moroccansforchange.com/2011/04/03/mamfakinch/ |work=Moroccans For Change |title=Mamfakinch |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150415045504/http://moroccansforchange.com/2011/04/03/mamfakinch/ |archivedate=15 April 2015 |df= }}</ref> The website was started by young Moroccans who were excited by the 20 February demonstrations, which sought sweeping social, economic, and political reform in Morocco. The designers claim diverse political persuasions but share a common belief in the democratic values of freedom and humans rights. The site is not afraid to be critical of the Moroccan government and promotes the rights to free speech and access to information. Mamfakinch is a citizen media source endeavoring to provide accurate information that other, mainstream media sources misrepresent, intentionally distort, or completely ignore.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://summit2012.globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/announcing-the-winners-of-the-breaking-borders-awards/ | work= Global Voices | title= Announcing the Winners of the Breaking Borders Awards }}</ref>
In 2012, Mamfakinch received the [http://summit2012.globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/announcing-the-winners-of-the-breaking-borders-awards/ Google/Global Voices Breaking Borders Award] for "defending and promoting freedom of speech rights on the internet."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mamfakinch.com/a-propos/ | work=Mamfakinch | title= About Us }}</ref>
==Casualties== On 20 February 2011, five bodies had been found in [[Al Hoceima]], within a bank that had been destroyed by protesters who set it on fire during the 20 February protests.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12524647 |title=Morocco protests: Five burned bodies found - minister |accessdate=21 February 2011 |date=21 February 2011 |publisher=BBC News |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wfm0MiTu?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12524647 |archivedate=21 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> According to eyewitnesses, the bodies belonged to rioters that were trying to loot the bank.<ref name="hespress3">{{cite web|url=http://www.hespress.com/?browser=view&EgyxpID=28416 |title=ارتفاع حصيلة أحداث 20 فبراير إلى 6 قتلى |publisher=Hespress |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=25 February 2011}}</ref>
On 2 June 2011, a man died of injuries he had allegedly received during the riots the city of Safi witnessed three days before. Official reports state that the man's participation to the protest in precarious health conditions led to the complications which caused his death.<ref>{{cite news|first=David E. |last=Miller|title=Demonstrator's death energizes Moroccan protesters|url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=224033|accessdate=24 September 2012|newspaper=The Media Line|date=7 June 2011}}</ref>

{{merge to|ASEAN–India Commemorative Summit|discuss=Talk:ASEAN–India Commemorative Summit#Proposed merge with ASEAN-India Car Rally 2012|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox motorsport championship | name = ASEAN-India Car Rally 2012 | logo = ASEAN-INDIA Car Rally 2012 Logo.jpg | image-size = | caption = ASEAN-INDIA Car Rally 2012 Official Logo | country/region = [[Indonesia]], [[Singapore]], [[Malaysia]], [[Thailand]], [[Cambodia]], [[Vietnam]], [[Laos]], [[Myanmar]], [[India]] | Flag-Off = [[Yogyakarta]], Indonesia & Ceremonial Flag-off in Singapore | Participants = 120 | teams = 11 | engines = [[Mahindra XUV500]] and [[Mahindra Scorpio]] | website = }} [[File:Asean India Car Rally While Reached Numaligarh.jpg|thumb|left|Asean India Car Rally 2012 at [[Numaligarh]], [[Assam]], [[India]]]] '''ASEAN-India Car Rally''' is a [[rally car]] that took place in 2012. To mark the occasion of the 20th commemorative year of India-ASEAN relations, the 2nd edition of the ASEAN-India Car Rally took place from 26 November - 21 December 2012. The rally began in [[Yogyakarta]] [[Indonesia]], with a ceremonial flag-off in [[Singapore]] and wind its way through 8 of the 10 ASEAN countries before finally ending in New Delhi, India. 31 Mahindra XUV 500 took part in this rally covering about 8000 km through 8 Asian countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aseanindia.com/car-rally |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130215132522/http://www.aseanindia.com/car-rally |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 15, 2013 |title=ASEAN India |accessdate=February 1, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asean.org/news/asean-secretariat-news/item/asean-india-car-rally-officially-concluded-in-new-delhi |title=ASEAN-India Car Rally Officially Concluded in New Delhi |date=21 December 2012 |accessdate=3 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121230102428/http://www.asean.org/news/asean-secretariat-news/item/asean-india-car-rally-officially-concluded-in-new-delhi |archivedate=30 December 2012 }}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Abderraouf Jdey | image = Jdey Composite 1.jpg | image_size = | caption = A still photo from Jdey's video message. His and bin al-Shibh's videos were never released. | birth_name = Abderraouf bin Habib bin Yousef Jdey | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|05|30|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Grombalia]], Tunisia | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Terrorist | spouse = | parents = }} '''Abderraouf bin Habib bin Yousef Jdey''' ({{lang-ar|عبد الرؤوف جدي}}, '''Abd ar-Rawūf Jday''') (also known as '''Farouk al-Tunisi''' and '''Al-Rauf Al-Jiddi''') (born May 30, 1965) is a [[Canadian citizen]],<ref name="csisAlmrei">[[Canadian Security Intelligence Service]], Summary of the Security Intelligence Report concerning Hassan Almrei, February 22, 2008.</ref> who was found swearing to die as a [[shahid|shaheed]] (martyr) on a series of videotapes found in the rubble of [[Mohammed Atef]]'s house in Afghanistan in 2002.<ref>[https://www.fbi.gov/mpg/persons.mpg FBI Seeking Information - War on Terrorism, Martyrdom Messages/video Seeking Information Alert] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805160829/https://www.fbi.gov/mpg/persons.mpg |date=August 5, 2009 }}, VIDEO 2 minutes 11 seconds, mpg (29.1 mb)</ref><ref>[http://mfile.akamai.com/6066/rm/www.fbi.gov/mpg/persons.rm FBI Seeking Information - War on Terrorism, Martyrdom Messages/video Seeking Information Alert], VIDEO 2 minutes 11 seconds, rm (229 kb - stream)</ref><ref>[https://www.fbi.gov/mpg/persons_asf.asf FBI Seeking Information - War on Terrorism, Martyrdom Messages/video Seeking Information Alert] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805160917/https://www.fbi.gov/mpg/persons_asf.asf |date=August 5, 2009 }}, VIDEO 2 minutes 11 seconds, asf (371 kb - stream)</ref><ref name="roguesgallery">[https://www.fbi.gov/terrorinfo/terrorismsi.htm FBI webpage] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030202083247/https://www.fbi.gov/terrorinfo/terrorismsi.htm |date=February 2, 2003 }} on several people wanted for questioning</ref>
The United States has issued three separate alerts that Jdey was about to attack inside the country, in January 2002, September 2003 and May 2004.<ref name="again" /> Three years later, the United States announced that he was one of a handful of terrorists actively plotting to attack the country, although none of their predictions ever panned out.
==Life== {{wikisource|Abderraouf Jdey letter about life in Canada}}{{wikisource|Abderraouf Jdey letter about Jihad}}{{commons category|Abderraouf Jdey}} Jdey moved to [[Canada]], using a false passport and seeking [[Right of asylum|asylum]],<ref name="bosglob">Hickerson, Colin. [[Boston Globe]], "US wary of 'time bombs' waiting to strike from north", February 4, 2003</ref><ref>Leiken, Robert S. and Steven Brooke, [http://www.nixoncenter.org/reports/BrookeLeikenMatrix.xls Matrix of terror suspects] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513194255/http://www.nixoncenter.org/reports/BrookeLeikenMatrix.xls |date=2008-05-13 }}</ref> from [[Tunisia]] in 1991 and became a [[Canadian nationality law|Canadian citizen]] in 1995.
He rented a [[C$]]217 monthly apartment in [[Rosemont–La Petite-Patrie]] (a borough of Montreal),<ref name="bosglob"/> and studied [[biology]] at the [[Université de Montréal]].<ref name="rfjhotsheet"/> In 1999, he wrote a pair of letters to unknown [[Muslims]] overseas, explaining how he found religion and speaking with contempt of the United States and [[United Nations]].<ref name="letters">Ha, Tu Thanh. ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/ArticleNews/printarticle/LAC/20081013/TERRORSUSPECT13/national/National Letters show anger of Canadian terrorism suspect]{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, October 13, 2008</ref>
American authorities allege that he "may" have trained at [[Mes Aynak]] alongside hijackers [[Khalid al-Mihdhar]] and [[Nawaf al-Hazmi]] in Afghanistan, before being assigned to a second wave of attacks. A letter written by [[Saif al-Adl]], and later found by American forces, suggested that Jdey may have originally been slated to have participated in the original [[9/11|September 11 attacks]]<ref name="rfjhotsheet"/><ref name="nine">[[9/11 Commission]], [http://govinfo.library.unt.edu/911/report/911Report.pdf 9/11 Report: Notes to Chapter 7.], August 2004</ref>
Jdey returned to [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada in early 2001. [[Khalid Sheikh Mohamed]], while being [[enhanced interrogation|harshly interrogated]], said that Jdey then backed out of the plan.<ref>Intelligence report, interrogation of KSM, July 1, 2003</ref> According to a 2010 Harvard report on al Qaeda by a former CIA officer, Jdey was detained in summer 2001 together with [[Zacarias Moussaoui]]. Moussaoui was carrying textbooks on cropdusting; Jdey was carrying textbooks on biology. Jdey was evidently subsequently released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/files/al-qaeda-wmd-threat.pdf |title=Al Qaeda Weapons of Mass Destruction Threat: Hype or Reality? p. 16 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-06-10}}</ref> In November 2001, he left Canada, several months after obtaining a replacement passport for one he'd received two years earlier which he claimed to have lost.<ref name="again">[[CBC.ca|CBC]], [http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/ussecurity/fbi_wanted.html Wanted - again], May 27, 2004</ref> He was believed to be bound for Europe.<ref name="bosglob"/><ref name="rfjhotsheet">{{cite web|url=http://www.rewardsforjustice.net/english/index.cfm?page=abderraouf |title=Rewards For Justice wanted poster on Jdey |publisher=Rewardsforjustice.net |date=1965-05-30 |accessdate=2013-06-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205062604/http://www.rewardsforjustice.net/english/index.cfm?page=abderraouf |archivedate=2012-02-05 |df= }}</ref>
==November airline crash== Less than three months after the crash of [[American Airlines Flight 587]] in [[Queens, New York]], rumors were already suggesting that it had been destroyed by an unknown terrorist with a [[shoe bomb]] similar to the one found on [[Richard Reid]].<ref>Irvine, Reed. Accuracy in Media, [http://www.aim.org/media-monitor/rumors-about-flight-587/ Rumors about Flight 587], February 6, 2002</ref>
Four months later, [[Mohammed Mansour Jabarah]] agreed to cooperate with American authorities in exchange for a reduced sentence. A known colleague of [[Khalid Sheikh Mohamed]], he stated that Mohamed's lieutenant had told him that Reid and Jdey had both been enlisted by the al-Qaeda chief to carry out identical plots as part of a "second wave" of attacks against the [[United States]].<ref>Mili, Hayder. [http://www.jamestown.org/terrorism/news/uploads/ter_003_015.pdf Securing the Northern Front: Canada and the War on Terror] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081116015239/http://www.jamestown.org/terrorism/news/uploads/ter_003_015.pdf |date=November 16, 2008 }}, July 28, 2005</ref><ref>Ressa, Maria. {{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/WORLD/asiapcf/southeast/01/30/reid.alqaeda/|title=Sources:Reid is al Qaeda operative.|accessdate=2006-09-15 | work=CNN | date=January 29, 2003}} CNN.com, December 6, 2003.</ref><ref>[[Daniel Pipes|Pipes, Daniel]], [http://www.danielpipes.org/article/2053 Why did American Airlines 587 crash?], August 30, 2004</ref><ref>Bell, Stewart. [[National Post]], [http://www.canada.com/national/nationalpost/news/story.html?id=a4f777f9-958a-4538-9c71-7f6d797676e Montreal man downed US plane, CSIS told] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160107181129/http://www.canada.com/national/nationalpost/news/story.html?id=a4f777f9-958a-4538-9c71-7f6d797676e |date=2016-01-07 }}, August 27, 2004</ref>
==United States 2002 claims== [[File:Jdey Composite 2.jpg|thumb|A [[composite image]] created by the FBI to show how Jdey may try to disguise himself.]] On January 14, 2002, a series of five videocassettes were recovered from the rubble of the destroyed home of [[Mohammad Atef]] outside of [[Kabul, Afghanistan]]. The tapes showed Jdey, [[Ramzi bin al-Shibh]], [[Muhammad Sa'id Ali Hasan]], [[Abdul Rahim Jenko|Abd Al-Rahim]], and [[Khalid Ibn Muhammad Al-Juhani]] vowing to die as martyrs. It was the first time authorities had reason to suspect him of any wrongdoing.<ref>[[CBC.ca|CBC]], [http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2002/01/25/terror_cda020125.html Two Canadians among fugitive al-Qaeda members], January 26, 2002</ref> [[NBC News]] said the videos had been recorded after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
Three days later, the FBI released to the public the first [[FBI Seeking Information – Terrorism list]] in order to profile the five wanted terrorists about whom very little was known, but who were suspected of plotting additional terrorist attacks in martyrdom operations.<ref>[https://www.fbi.gov/mostwant/seekinfo/seek.htm Most Wanted Terrorists Seeking Information] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060314213748/https://www.fbi.gov/mostwant/seekinfo/seek.htm |date=March 14, 2006 }}, January 17, 2002, (dead link)</ref><ref>[https://www.fbi.gov/terrorinfo/terseekinfomartyr.htm Martyrdom Messages/video, Seeking Information Alert] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805042335/https://www.fbi.gov/terrorinfo/terseekinfomartyr.htm |date=August 5, 2009 }} video clips published by the FBI January 17, 2002, and photos of the remaining 4 terrorists, FBI archival after September 2002</ref> Already under fire for issuing "excessive and somewhat alarmist" warnings about terrorists plotting against the United States, [[Attorney General]] [[John Ashcroft]] stated that Jdey and [[Faker Boussora]] were likely traveling together and should be considered "extremely dangerous".<ref>Lichtblau, Eric. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', [http://articles.latimes.com/2002/jan/26/news/mn-24928 2 Canadians tied to terrorist plots], January 26, 2002</ref>
A month after Jdey and Boussora were declared fugitives, the [[Republic of Turkey]] announced that the pair may be within their borders.<ref>[[Fox News]], [http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,45989,00.html Turks: Al Qaeda Men Planning Israel Attack], February 20, 2002</ref>
[[Ramzi bin al-Shibh]] was interrogated at an American [[black site]] in 2003 about his knowledge of Jdey, and confessed that Jdey had recruited by [[al-Qaeda]].<ref>Intelligence report, interrogation of bin al-Shibh, Sept. 11 2003</ref> The following year [[Walid bin 'Attash]], similarly interrogated under harsh circumstances at [[The Dark Prison]], confirmed that Jdey had been known to him.<ref>Intelligence report, interrogation of Khallad (Walid bin 'Attash), May 21, 2004</ref>
==United States 2003 claims== In September 2003, the FBI issued an alert for four people they alleged "pose a threat to U.S. citizens", including Jdey, [[Adnan G. El Shukrijumah]] and the previously unknown [[Zubayr al-Rimi]] and [[Karim el-Mejjati]].<ref name="three">[[CNN]], [http://www.cnn.com/2003/US/09/05/fbi.bolo/ FBI seeks 4 suspected of terrorist activities], September 2003</ref>
==United States 2004 claims== On May 26, 2004, [[Attorney General of the United States|Attorney General]] [[John Ashcroft]] and [[FBI Director]] [[Robert Mueller]] announced that reports indicated that Jdey was one of seven al-Qaeda members who were planning terrorist actions for the summer or fall of 2004. The other six named were Shukrijumah, [[Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani]], [[Fazul Abdullah Mohammed]], [[Amer El-Maati]], [[Aafia Siddiqui]] and [[Adam Yahiye Gadahn]].<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2004/US/05/26/terror.threat.transcript/ Transcript: Ashcroft, Mueller news conference], CNN.com, Wednesday, May 26, 2004 Posted: 8:19 PM EDT (0019 GMT)</ref> American [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]]s labeled the warning "suspicious" and said it was held solely to divert attention from President Bush's plummeting poll numbers and to push the failings of the [[Invasion of Iraq]] off the front page.<ref name="kerry">Pither, Kerry. "Dark Days: The Story of Four Canadians Tortured in the Name of Fighting Terror", 2008.</ref> CSIS director [[Reid Morden]] voiced similar concerns, saying it seemed more like "election year" politics, than an actual threat, and ''[[The New York Times]]'' pointed out that one day before the announcement, they had been told by the [[Department of Homeland Security]] that there were no current risks.<ref name="kerry"/>
The day after the announcement, there was a reported sighting of Jdey and Shukrijumah at a [[Denny's|Denny's restaurant]] in [[Colorado]].{{Dead link|date=August 2011}}<ref name="online">Kupferberg, Chaim. Onlinejournal.com, [http://onlinejournal.org/Special_Reports/081104Kupferberg/08-11-04_Kupferberg.pdf The 'official' operative clique for the next 9/11?], August 11, 2004</ref> The following year, another tip suggested that the pair had been seen driving a car with a [[Massachusetts]] license plate in [[Maine]].{{Dead link|date=August 2011}}<ref name="online"/>
In April 2005, the [[U.S. State Department]] [[Bureau of Diplomatic Security|Rewards for Justice Program]] offered a reward of up to US$5 million for information leading to the capture of Jdey, even though he has not been indicted.<ref name="fbihotsheet">[[FBI]], [https://www.fbi.gov/terrorinfo/jdey.htm Rewards for Justice: Jdey] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161222183944/https://www2.fbi.gov/terrorinfo/jdey.htm |date=2016-12-22 }}</ref>

{{Infobox person |name = Anatole Jenkins |image = Anatole Jenkins 02.jpg |caption = Jenkins at campaign rally for [[Hillary Clinton]] |birth_name = Anatole Jenkins |birth_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |occupation = Political Strategist }}
'''Anatole Jenkins''' is an American [[political strategist]] and political staffer. He served on [[Hillary Clinton]]'s [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|2016 presidential campaign]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Template:Presidential_staff_Minnesota|title=Presidential Staff Minnesota|last=|first=|date=|website=Ballotpedia|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> He currently serves as the Deputy National Field Director for the [[Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=Anna Palmer|author2=Jake Sherman|author3=Daniel Lippman|url=http://www.politico.com/tipsheets/playbook/2017/09/26/puerto-rico-desperate-for-help-moore-v-strange-tonight-bannon-unleashed-in-alabama-philippe-reines-to-protest-trump-full-time-bday-weigel-222471|publisher=Politico}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://t.e2ma.net/webview/fbhzw/7289be381de9b5d6eab5233efb3565aa|title=DCCC builds up its field team -- meet their latest hire.|last=|first=|date=|website=The Beat DC|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
Jenkins spent much of his career working with groups related to President Barack Obama, including his political organization Organizing for America, [[Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2012|Barack Obama's 2012 presidential campaign]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/mhastings/obama-skips-the-strip-on-vegas-swing|title=Obama Skips The Strip On Vegas Swing|newspaper=BuzzFeed|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref> and [[Organizing for Action]], Obama's nonprofit built from his campaign infrastructure. He served as Coordinated Campaign Field Director for the [[Nevada Democratic Party]] in 2014.
In October 2013, Barack Obama's [[Twitter]] and [[Facebook]] accounts were hacked. In the same hacking, Jenkins' email was [[Cybercrime|hacked]] revealing details of Barack Obama's political organization. At the time, he was the Fundraising Manager for Obama. Official representatives of the [[Syrian Electronic Army]], a loose group of hackers who support Syrian President [[Bashar Al Assad]], claimed responsibility.<ref name="syrian">{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/obama-twitter-hacked-syrian-electronic-army-2013-10|title=The Syrian Electronic Army Hacked Obama's URL Shortener|newspaper=Business Insider|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref>

{{Infobox wrestling event |name = Atlantis 35th Anniversary Show |image =Atlantis 35th Anniversary Show.png |caption =Official poster of the event |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date = July 13, 2018 |date_aired = |venue = [[Arena México]] |city = [[Mexico City|Mexico City, Mexico]] |attendance =15,500<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wrestlingdata.com/index.php?befehl=shows&show=415591 | title=CMLL Viernes Espectacular - 35 Años de Atlantis| date=July 13, 2018| accessdate=September 21, 2018 | work=Wrestling Data}}</ref> |lastevent = [[Torneo Gran Alternativa (2018)]] |nextevent = [[Negro Casas 40th Anniversary Show]] }} The '''Atlantis 35th Anniversary Show''', or more properly '''Funcion Homenaje a Atlantis por 35 Años de carrera luchistica''' (Spanish for "Tribute to Atlantis for his 35 year career in wrestling") was a [[professional wrestling]] [[Card (sports)#Supercard|super card]] held on July 13, 2018. The show was produced and scripted by the Mexican [[professional wrestling promotion]] [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL: Spanish for "World Wrestling Council") and took place at [[Arena México]] in Mexico City, Mexico. The special edition of CMLL's [[CMLL Super Viernes|Super Viernes]] show honored CMLL wrestler [[Atlantis (wrestler)|Atlantis]] for reaching his 35th anniversary as a professional wrestler.
While the event honored Atlantis he did not work the main event match, instead he teamed up with old partners [[Octagón]] and [[Rayo de Jalisco Jr.]] to defeat the team of [[Fuerza Guerrera]], [[Máscara Año 2000]] and [[Último Guerrero]]. The main event saw [[Los Ingobernables]] ([[Rush (wrestler)|Rush]] and [[El Terrible]]) defeat the Sky Team ([[Valiente (wrestler)|Valiente]] and [[Volador Jr.]]) to with the [[CMLL World Tag Team Championship]]. The show featured four additional matches.
==Production== ===Background=== Professional wrestler [[Atlantis (wrestler)|Atlantis]] made his in ring debut in the summer of 1983.<ref name=FigurasAtlantis>{{cite news|title=Lucha Libre: Conoce la historia de las leyendas de cuadrilátero|work=Atlantis (1962)|location=[[Mexico]]|id=Grandes Figuras de la Lucha Libre|page=8|year=2008|language=Spanish}}</ref> Over the years the young, highly skilled wrestler rose through the ranks of CMLL, winning his first major ''[[Lucha de Apuestas]]'', or "bet match", just over a year after his debut as he defeated [[Arturo Beristain|Talismán]] in the ===Storylines=== The event featured six [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] with different wrestlers involved in pre-existing [[Screenplay|scripted]] feuds, [[plot (narrative)|plots]] and [[narrative thread|storylines]]. Wrestlers were portrayed as either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that portray the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they followed a series of tension-building events, which culminated in a wrestling match or series of matches.
==Event== The fifth match of the night honored Atlantis as he teamed up with his old partners [[Octagón]] and [[Rayo de Jalisco Jr.]], neither of whom worked for CMLL on a regular basis at that point in time. To honor his partner Octagón wore an outfit where his traditional red color was replaced with the blue color associated with Atlantis. The trio faced off against [[Fuerza Guerrera]], [[Máscara Año 2000]] and [[Último Guerrero]]. For the night both Máscara Año 2000 and Último Guerrero wore their old wrestling masks that they had both lost years ago. After his team won Atlantis introduced his sons, Atlantis Jr. and El Hijo de Atlantis, to the CMLL crowd.<ref name=CMLLTag39/><ref name=EstoAtlantis/><ref name=Atlantis35/>
==Aftermath== The ongoing rivalry between [[Los Ingobernables]] and the Ibarra family ([[Volador Jr.]], [[L.A. Park]], [[El Hijo de L.A. Park]] and [[Flyer (wrestler)|Flyer]]) continued past the championship change, focusing more on Rush and Volador Jr. than previously. After the [[Negro Casas 40th Anniversary Show]], [[Matt Taven]] and [[Bárbaro Cavernario]] were added to the mix,<ref name=Casas40Ovaciones>{{cite web | url=https://ovaciones.com/aceptan-el-reto/ | title=¡Aceptan el reto! | first=Arturo | last=Rosas Plata | language=Spanish | date=August 4, 2018 | accessdate=September 21, 2018 | work=Ovaciones}}</ref> the latter stepping in to take [[El Terrible]]'s place when he was injured. That feud that became the main event of CMLL's biggest show of 2018, the [[CMLL 85th Anniversary Show]]. Rush and Bárbaro Cavernario won the tag team ''[[Lucha de Apuestas]]'', or bet match, when Taven attacked Volador Jr., forcing both Volador Jr. and Taven to be shaved bald as a result.<ref name=WON>{{cite web | url=https://www.f4wonline.com/mexico/cmll-85th-aniversario-live-results-hair-vs-hair-tag-team-main-event-265781 | title=CMLL 85. Aniversario live results: hair vs. hair tag team main event | work=[[Wrestling Observer|Wrestling Observer Figure Four Online]] | date=September 14, 2018 | accessdate=September 15, 2018 | first=Chris | last=Aiken}}</ref>
