{{Use New Zealand English|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] | name = Lianne Dalziel | honorific-suffix = | image = Lianne Dalziel September 2017.jpg | caption = Dalziel in September 2017 |order = 46th |office = Mayor of Christchurch |term_start = 24 October 2013 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Bob Parker (mayor)|Bob Parker]] |successor = | order3 = Minister of Commerce | primeminister3 = [[Helen Clark]] | term_start3 = 15 August 2002 | term_end3 = 21 February 2004 | predecessor3 = [[Paul Swain]] | successor3 = [[Margaret Wilson]] | term_start4 = 19 October 2005 | term_end4 = 19 November 2008 | predecessor4 = [[Pete Hodgson]] | successor4 = [[Simon Power]] | order5 = [[Minister for ACC]] | primeminister5 = [[Helen Clark]] | term_start5 = 28 March 2001 | term_end5 = 15 August 2002 | predecessor5 = | successor5 = [[Ruth Dyson]] | constituency_MP6 = [[Christchurch Central]] | parliament6 = New Zealand | majority6 = | predecessor6 = [[Geoffrey Palmer (politician)|Geoffrey Palmer]] | successor6 = [[Tim Barnett (politician)|Tim Barnett]] | term_start6 = 27 October 1990 | term_end6 = 12 October 1996 | constituency_MP7 = [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour Party]] [[List MP|List]] | parliament7 = New Zealand | term_start7 = 12 October 1996 | term_end7 = 27 November 1999 | constituency_MP8 = [[Christchurch East]] | parliament8 = New Zealand | majority8 = | predecessor8 = [[Larry Sutherland]] | successor8 = [[Poto Williams]] | term_start8 = 27 November 1999 | term_end8 = 11 October 2013 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1960|6|7}} | birth_place = [[Christchurch]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = New Zealand | spouse = | party = [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour Party]] | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = Union Worker | profession = | cabinet = | committees = Commerce Committee (chairperson)
Privileges Committee | portfolio = | religion = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Lianne Audrey Dalziel''' ({{IPAc-en|d|æ|l|ˈ|z|ɛ|l}}; born 7 June 1960) is the [[Mayor of Christchurch]]. Prior to this position, she was a member of the [[New Zealand Parliament]] for 23 years, serving as Minister of Immigration, Commerce, Minister of Food Safety and Associate Minister of Justice in the [[Fifth Labour Government of New Zealand|Fifth Labour Government]].{{cite press release |publisher=New Zealand Government |date=31 October 2007 |title=Ministerial List for Announcement on 31 October 2007 |url=http://www.beehive.govt.nz/Documents/Files/Ministerial%20List.DOC |format=DOC |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081001195125/http://www.beehive.govt.nz/Documents/Files/Ministerial%20List.DOC |archivedate=1 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }} She resigned from [[Cabinet of New Zealand|Cabinet]] on 20 February 2004 after apparently lying about a [[leak]] of documents to the media, but was reinstated as a Minister following [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour]]'s return to office after the [[New Zealand general election, 2005|2005 election]]. She resigned from Parliament effective 11 October 2013 to contest the [[Christchurch mayoral election, 2013|Christchurch mayoral election]]. The incumbent, [[Bob Parker (mayor)|Bob Parker]], decided not to stand again, and she was widely regarded as the top favourite and won with a wide margin to become the 46th Mayor of Christchurch. == Early life == Dalziel was born in 1960{{cite web | publisher=[[New Zealand Parliament]] | url= http://www.parliament.nz/en-NZ/MPP/MPs/MPs/f/5/1/50MP621-Dalziel-Lianne.htm | title= Hon Lianne Dalziel | accessdate =25 May 2009}} raised in [[Christchurch]], and attended [[University of Canterbury|Canterbury University]]. She graduated with a law degree and was admitted to the Bar. She served as the legal officer for the Canterbury Hotel and Hospital Workers' Union, and later became the union's Secretary. She also participated in national groups such as the Federation of Labour and the [[New Zealand Council of Trade Unions]]. == Member of Parliament == {{NZ parlbox header|align=left}} {{NZ parlbox|term=43rd |start={{NZ election link year|1990}} |end=1993 |electorate=[[Christchurch Central]] |party=New Zealand Labour Party}} {{NZ parlbox |start={{NZ election link year|1993}} |term=44th |end=1996 |electorate=Christchurch Central |party=New Zealand Labour Party}} {{NZ parlbox|term=45th |start={{NZ election link year|1996}} |end=1999|electorate=List|party=New Zealand Labour Party|list=4}} {{NZ parlbox|term=46th |start={{NZ election link year|1999}} |end=2002 |electorate=[[Christchurch East]] |party=New Zealand Labour Party|list=8}} {{NZ parlbox|term=47th |start={{NZ election link year|2002}} |end=2005 |electorate=Christchurch East |party=New Zealand Labour Party|list=14}} {{NZ parlbox|term=48th |start={{NZ election link year|2005}} |end=2008 |electorate=Christchurch East |party=New Zealand Labour Party|list=26}} {{NZ parlbox|term=49th |start={{NZ election link year|2008}} |end=2011 |electorate=Christchurch East |party=New Zealand Labour Party|list=15}} {{NZ parlbox|term=50th |start={{NZ election link year|2011}} |end=2013 |electorate=Christchurch East |list=none |party=New Zealand Labour Party}} {{NZ parlbox footer}} Dalziel entered Parliament as a [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour Party]] MP for [[Christchurch Central]] in [[New Zealand general election, 1990|1990]], replacing outgoing former Prime Minister [[Geoffrey Palmer (politician)|Geoffrey Palmer]]. She held this seat until the [[New Zealand general election, 1996|1996 election]] (being replaced by [[Tim Barnett (politician)|Tim Barnett]]), when she became a list MP under the new [[Mixed-member proportional representation|MMP]] electoral system. In the [[New Zealand general election, 1999|1999 election]], she chose to contest an electorate again, and won the [[Christchurch East]] seat. She held the seat in the 2002, 2005, 2008 and 2011 elections. In 2011 she opted not to go on the Labour list. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine picked her as a future leader in its December 1994 edition. === Cabinet minister === In the new government formed by [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour]], Dalziel became Minister of Immigration, Minister for Senior Citizens, and Minister for Disability Issues. When Labour won re-election in the [[New Zealand general election, 2002|2002 election]], Dalziel also became Minister of Commerce (while ceasing to be Minister for Disability Issues). In 2003, she ceased to be Minister for Senior Citizens. As Minister of Immigration, Dalziel was often in the spotlight. In particular, she often clashed with [[Winston Peters]], leader of the anti-immigration [[New Zealand First]] party. After the [[New Zealand general election, 2005|2005 election]], Dalziel was re-elected by her caucus colleagues to [[Cabinet of New Zealand|Cabinet]] and was given the portfolios of Commerce, Small Business, and Women's Affairs. [[Mike Williams (New Zealand politician)|Mike Williams]], President of the Labour Party from 2000 to 2009, states that he was surprised by Clark appointing Dalziel Minister of Commerce and thought of it as an "odd choice". But she worked herself into the portfolio, paid attention to detail, and within a year had "proved herself". Williams believes this is due to her high intelligence and her ability to listen. [[Tim Barnett (politician)|Tim Barnett]], MP for [[Christchurch Central]] from 1996 to 2008, and today General Secretary of the Labour Party (equivalent to [[Chief executive officer|CEO]]), credits her training as a lawyer and "having a bigger brain than most of us" for her success. Williams states that as Minister of Commerce, Dalziel worked closely with National's [[Simon Power]] and built "cross-party unity on various issues". === Controversies === Dalziel's position became difficult after she was accused of giving certain documents to the press to bolster the case for a decision her Associate Minister had made. The decision, concerning the deportation of a [[Sri Lanka]]n teenager who was seeking asylum but who had originally lied about the reasons, was controversial, and Dalziel leaked the notes of the teenager's lawyer to [[TV3 (New Zealand)|TV3]], attempting to discredit the teenager's case for asylum.{{cite news |title=Dalziel loses job over leak |url= http://tvnz.co.nz/content/256921/2591754/article.html |accessdate=20 April 2013 |newspaper=TVNZ |date=20 February 2004}} Dalziel tried to avoid admitting to being the source of the documents, but was forced to admit that the leak had been at her direction. There was also significant controversy about how Dalziel had obtained the documents in the first place. Dalziel offered her resignation which Prime Minister [[Helen Clark]] accepted. === Opposition and mayoral ambitions=== After Labour was defeated in the [[New Zealand general election, 2008|2008 general election]], Dalziel became the Opposition spokesperson on Justice and Commerce and, from [[New Zealand general election, 2011|2011]], the spokesperson for the [[2011 Christchurch earthquake|Christchurch Earthquake Recovery]], Civil Defence & Emergence Management, Consumer Rights & Standards, and associate spokesperson for Justice.{{cite web |title=Lianne Dalziel |url= http://www.labour.org.nz/liannedalziel |accessdate=30 September 2013 |publisher=[[New Zealand Labour Party]]}} Rumours of Dalziel standing as [[Mayor of Christchurch]] go back to at least 2009.{{cite news |last=Matthews |first=Philip |title=A Point of Principle |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=21 September 2013 |pages=C1–C3}} Since the February 2011 earthquake, the rumours that Dalziel would contest the [[Christchurch mayoral election, 2013|2013 Christchurch mayoralty]] became more consistent. In May 2012, Dalziel tried to put an end to these rumours by announcing: "The job I really want is [[Gerry Brownlee]]'s, rather than [[Bob Parker (mayor)|Bob Parker]]'s."{{cite news |last=Gorman |first=Paul |title=Dalziel won't run for mayor |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/6908427/Dalziel-won-t-run-for-mayor |accessdate=26 August 2012 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=12 May 2012}} Brownlee is Earthquake Recovery Minister, and Parker was the [[Mayor of Christchurch]] at the time. In the February 2013 reshuffle of opposition portfolios, Dalziel dropped out of the top 20 (only the first 20 positions are ranked by the Labour Party).{{cite news |last=Vance |first=Andrea |title=Dalziel dropped from Labour's top 20 |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/8348590/Dalziel-dropped-from-Labours-top-20 |accessdate=3 March 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=25 February 2013}} An editorial in ''[[The Press]]'' presumed that her strong support for [[David Cunliffe]] was part of the reason for her demotion. The editorial also speculated that she might reconsider her political future:{{cite news |title=Labour's new faces |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/opinion/editorials/8350124/Editorial-Labours-new-faces |accessdate=3 March 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=26 February 2013 |page=A12}}
The demotion is bound to concentrate Dalziel's mind on whether she should run for the [[Mayor of Christchurch|Christchurch mayoralty]]. As things stand, a place for her in a Labour cabinet as minister for the earthquake recovery looks unlikely, but she would be a strong candidate for mayor.
Following months of speculation, ''The Press'' reported on 20 April 2013 that Lianne Dalziel would challenge Parker for the mayoralty, and that she had asked 24-year-old Student Volunteer Army organiser [[Sam Johnson (activist)|Sam Johnson]] to be her running mate, with a view of Johnson becoming deputy mayor. The newspaper expressed surprise by this pairing, given that Dalziel was a Labour Party member, and Johnson a member of the [[New Zealand Young Nationals|Young Nats]], the youth arm of the [[New Zealand National Party|National Party]].{{cite news |title=Dalziel invites Johnson to join mayoral race |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/8574677/Dalziel-seeks-running-mate-in-mayoral-race |accessdate=20 April 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=20 April 2013 |location=[[Christchurch]] |page=A1}} Saying that: "It was a really difficult decision to make, but I don't think it is the right thing for me right now", Johnson eventually decided against running.{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Student-Army-head-wont-run-for-mayor/tabid/423/articleID/295115/Default.aspx |work=3 News NZ |title= Student Army head won't run for mayor| date=22 April 2013}} On 19 June, Dalziel formally confirmed that she would contest the mayoralty, also announcing that she would resign from Parliament, which would trigger a [[Christchurch East by-election, 2013|by-election in the Christchurch East electorate]].{{cite news |last=Cairns |first=Lois |title=Heavyweights fight for city |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/8811913/Heavyweights-fight-for-City |accessdate=19 June 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=19 June 2013 |page=A1}}{{cite news |last=Cairns |first=Lois |title=Dalziel formally enters mayoralty race |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/local-elections-2013/8940226/Dalziel-formally-enters-mayoralty-race |accessdate=26 August 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=19 July 2013}} Dalziel delivered her resignation letter on 17 September and delivered her valedictory speech the following day with her resignation taking effect on Friday, 11 October; the day before the [[New Zealand local elections, 2013|local body election]]{{cite news |last=Conway |first=Glenn |title=Dalziel officially resigns from Parliament |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/local-elections-2013/9175441/Dalziel-officially-resigns-from-Parliament |accessdate=17 September 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=17 September 2013 |page=}} so that the by-election campaign did not interfere with the local body election. In a later interview, Dalziel confirmed that she would have left Parliament even if Shearer had put her onto the [[Frontbench team of David Shearer|front bench]]. Although some expressed concerns about Dalziel's Labour Party background, including [[Christchurch Central City|central city]] property developer [[Antony Gough]], who talked of her "red apron strings" getting in the way of working with local business owners, she also nevertheless open support from the political right for her mayoral ambitions: [[Christchurch City Council]]lor Tim Carter, son of Christchurch property developer Philip Carter and nephew of [[Speaker of the New Zealand House of Representatives|Speaker]] [[David Carter (politician)|David Carter]], encouraged her to stand for the mayoralty;{{cite news |last=Cairns |first=Lois |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/8593994/Tim-Carter-out-backs-Lianne-Dalziel |title=Carter out, backs Dalziel |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=25 April 2013 |location=[[Christchurch]] |page=A1}} former [[New Zealand National Party|National Party]] cabinet minister [[Philip Burdon]] was one of her nominees when she lodged her nomination for the mayoralty with the returning officer;{{cite news |last=Cairns |first=Lois |title=Dalziel formally enters mayoralty race |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/local-elections-2013/8940226/Dalziel-formally-enters-mayoralty-race |accessdate=30 September 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=19 July 2013}} and blogger [[Cameron Slater]], by many considered a "conduit for factions of the National Party" wrote:{{cite web |authorlink=Cameron Slater |last=Slater |first=Cameron |title=Onya Lianne |url= http://www.whaleoil.co.nz/2013/06/onya-lianne/#axzz2gOzc0pIC |publisher=Whale Oil Beef Hooked |accessdate=30 September 2013 |date=18 June 2013}}
Christchurch needs a uniter, not a divider, and the word is that National would far rather deal with Lianne and the competent councillors she is bringing with her than Bob Parker.
Dalziel's Earthquake Recovery portfolio in Labour's shadow cabinet was split and given to [[Ruth Dyson]] and [[Clayton Cosgrove]].{{cite news |last=Cairns |first=Lois |title=Two MPs to take over Dalziel's portfolio |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/8907042/Two-MPs-to-take-over-Dalziels-portfolio |accessdate=23 August 2013 |newspaper=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |date=11 July 2013}} ==Mayor of Christchurch== [[File:Christchurch Tram Launch 412.jpg|thumb|Launch of a tramway extension on 12 February 2015 by Prime Minister [[John Key]] and Dalziel]] Dalziel was elected [[Mayor of Christchurch]] in the [[Christchurch mayoral election, 2013|October 2013 mayoral election]], with a margin of almost 50,000 votes over the next candidate, businessman Paul Lonsdale.{{cite press release |title=Elections 2013: Final declaration of results |url=http://ccc.govt.nz/thecouncil/newsmedia/mediareleases/2013/201310181.aspx |publisher=[[Christchurch City Council]] |accessdate=20 October 2013 |date=18 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022215008/http://ccc.govt.nz/thecouncil/newsmedia/mediareleases/2013/201310181.aspx |archivedate=22 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }} She was sworn in on 24 October,{{cite news |last=Cairns |first=Lois |title=Dalziel chained into office |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/local-elections-2013/9325054/Dalziel-chained-into-office |accessdate=26 October 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=25 October 2013 |page=A2}} with a past mayor, [[Vicki Buck]] as her deputy.[http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/local-body-elections/9312098/Vicki-Buck-named-deputy-mayor Vicki Buck named deputy mayor]. ''Fairfax NZ News''. 22 October 2013. ==See also== *[[Politics of New Zealand]] *[[Government of New Zealand]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Lianne Dalziel}} * [http://www.labour.org.nz/liannedalziel New Zealand Labour Party bio] * Video of valedictory speech :* [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HQlg4-OFzwk part 1] :* [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8TN6jenQieo part 1] {{s-start}} {{s-par | nz}} {{s-bef | before=[[Geoffrey Palmer (politician)|Geoffrey Palmer]]}} {{s-ttl | title=[[Christchurch Central|Member of Parliament for Christchurch Central]]|years=1990–1996}} {{s-aft | after=[[Tim Barnett (politician)|Tim Barnett]]}} |- {{s-bef | before=[[Larry Sutherland]]}} {{s-ttl | title=[[Christchurch East|Member of Parliament for Christchurch East]]|years=1999–2013}} {{s-aft | after= [[Poto Williams]]}} |- {{s-off}} {{s-bef | before = [[David Carter (politician)|David Carter]]}} {{s-ttl | title = [[Minister for Senior Citizens]] |years=1999–2003}} {{s-aft | after = [[Ruth Dyson]]}} |- {{S-bef | before = ?}} {{S-ttl | title = [[Minister for ACC]]|years=2001–2002}} {{S-aft | after = [[Ruth Dyson]]}} |- {{S-bef | before = [[Paul Swain]]}} {{S-ttl | rows=2 | title = Minister of Commerce|years=2002–2004
2005–2008}} {{S-aft | after = [[Margaret Wilson]]}} {{S-bef | before = [[Pete Hodgson]]}} {{S-aft | after = [[Simon Power]]}} |- {{s-bef | before = [[Bob Parker (mayor)|Bob Parker]]}} {{s-ttl | title = [[Mayor of Christchurch]]|years= 2013–present}} {{s-inc}} {{end}} {{Mayors of Christchurch}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dalziel, Lianne}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:New Zealand Labour Party MPs]] [[Category:Members of the Cabinet of New Zealand]] [[Category:University of Canterbury alumni]] [[Category:New Zealand lawyers]] [[Category:Women government ministers of New Zealand]] [[Category:New Zealand list MPs]] [[Category:New Zealand MPs for Christchurch electorates]] [[Category:Members of the New Zealand House of Representatives]] [[Category:People associated with the 2011 Christchurch earthquake]] [[Category:Mayors of Christchurch]] [[Category:21st-century New Zealand politicians]] [[Category:21st-century women politicians]] [[Category:Women members of the New Zealand House of Representatives]]

{{Redirect|Death in space|death in specifically outer space conditions|Space exposure}} [[Image:Challenger explosion.jpg|thumb|right|[[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|Space Shuttle ''Challenger'']] disintegrates 73 seconds after its 1986 launch resulting in the death of all seven crew members.]] This article lists verifiable '''spaceflight-related accidents and incidents''' resulting in fatality or near-fatality during flight or training for manned space missions, and testing, assembly, preparation or flight of manned and unmanned spacecraft. Not included are accidents or incidents associated with [[intercontinental ballistic missile]] (ICBM) tests, unmanned space flights not resulting in fatality or serious injury, or [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] or [[Germany|German]] [[rocket-powered aircraft]] projects of [[World War II]]. Also not included are [[Lost cosmonauts|alleged unreported Soviet space accidents]], which are considered [[fringe theory|fringe theories]] by a majority of historians. {{As of|2018}}, there have been 18 astronaut and cosmonaut fatalities during spaceflight.{{sfnp|Harwood|2005}}{{Sfnp|Musgrave, Larsen, Tommaso|2009|p=143}} Astronauts have also died while training for space missions, such as the [[Apollo 1]] launch pad fire which killed an entire crew of three. There have also been some non-astronaut fatalities during spaceflight-related activities. [[File:Astronauts Memorial Plaque.jpg|thumb|Astronauts Memorial Plaque at Cape Canaveral (2015)]] [[File:Fallen Astronaut.jpg|thumb|''[[Fallen Astronaut]]'' memorial on the Moon, includes most spaceflight-related fatalities up to 1971]] ==Astronaut fatalities== :''(In the statistics below, "astronaut" is applied to all space travellers to avoid the use of "astronaut/cosmonaut".)'' ===During spaceflight=== {{As of|2018|03}}, in-flight accidents have killed 18 astronauts, in four separate incidents.{{Sfnp|Musgrave, Larsen, Tommaso|2009|p=143}} NASA astronauts who died on duty are memorialized at the [[Space Mirror Memorial]] at the [[John F. Kennedy Space Center#Visitor Complex|Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex]] in [[Merritt Island, Florida]]. Cosmonauts who died on duty under the [[Soviet Union]] were generally honored by burial at the [[Kremlin Wall Necropolis]] in [[Moscow]]. No Soviet or Russian cosmonauts have died during spaceflight since 1971. There have been a total of five fatal in-flight accidents, three of them flew above the [[Kármán line]], and one was intended to do so. In each case, the entire crew was killed. {{-}} {| class="wikitable" border="1" cellpadding=3 cellspacing=3 |+ Orbital spaceflight fatalities |- bgcolor=#cccccc ! Date !! Incident !! Mission !! Fatalities !! Description |- || {{nowrap|1967-04-24}} || Parachute failure || {{nowrap|[[Soyuz 1]]}} || {{nowrap|{{flagicon|Soviet Union}} [[Vladimir Komarov]]}} || The one-day mission was plagued by a series of mishaps with the new spacecraft type, culminating with its [[parachute]] not opening properly after [[atmospheric reentry]]. Komarov was killed when the capsule hit the ground at high speed.https://rarehistoricalphotos.com/astronaut-vladimir-komarov-man-fell-space-1967/ {{cite news | last = Coleman | first = Fred | title = Soviet Cosmonaut Dies in Spacecraft | location = Owosso, Michigan | newspaper = The Owosso Argus-Press | date = 1967-04-24 | page = 1 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jzoiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CKsFAAAAIBAJ&dq=soyuz&pg=1794,5629826 | agency = American Press }} The Soyuz 1 crash site coordinates are {{Coord|51.3615|N|59.5622|E}}, {{convert|3|km|mi|sp=us}} west of Karabutak, Province of Orenburg in the Russian Federation, about {{convert|275|km|mi|sp=us}} east-southeast of Orenburg. In a small park on the side of the road is a memorial monument: a black column with a bust of Komarov at the top.{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?t=h&lci=org.wikipedia.en&q=51.3615,59.5622(Soyuz+1)&ll=51.361599,59.563065&spn=0.051342,0.138359&z=13 |title = Google Maps - Soyuz 1 Crash Site - Memorial Monument Location|accessdate = 2010-12-25}}{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?ll=51.374567,59.572163&spn=0.052613,0.165997&t=h&z=13&iwloc=lyrftr:com.panoramio.all,6302492947772100897,51.360849,59.562378&lci=com.panoramio.all |title = Google Maps - Soyuz 1 Crash Site - Memorial Monument Photo|accessdate = 2010-12-25}}{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?ll=51.360902,59.562378&spn=0,0.138359&t=h&z=13&lci=com.panoramio.all&layer=c&cbll=51.360902,59.562378&cbp=12,0,,0,5&photoid=po-10147834 |title = Google Maps - Soyuz 1 Crash Site - Memorial Monument Photo closeup|accessdate = 2010-12-25}} |- || {{nowrap|1971-06-30}} || Decompression in space || {{nowrap|[[Soyuz 11]]}} || {{nowrap|{{flagicon|Soviet Union}} [[Georgy Dobrovolsky]]}}
{{nowrap|{{flagicon|Soviet Union}} [[Viktor Patsayev]]}}
{{nowrap|{{flagicon|Soviet Union}} [[Vladislav Volkov]]}} || The crew of [[Soyuz 11]] were killed after undocking from [[space station]] [[Salyut 1]] after a three-week stay. A cabin vent valve accidentally opened at service module separation. The recovery team found the crew dead. These three are the only human fatalities ''in space'' (above {{convert|100|km|ft|sp=us}}) thus far. {{cite news | last = Butler | first = Sue | title = What Happened Aboard Soyuz 11? Reentry Strain Too Much? | location = Daytona Beach, Florida | newspaper = Daytona Beach Morning Journal | date = 1971-07-01 | page = 43 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-E4fAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ptEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1152,257121 }} {{cite news | author = Reuters | title = Space deaths detailed | newspaper = The Leader-Post | location = Regina, Saskatchewan | date = 1973-11-03 | page = 9 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AfhUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yDwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4921,564442 | ref = harv }} The Soyuz 11 landing coordinates are {{Coord|47.35663|N|70.12142|E}}, {{convert|90|km|mi|sp=us}} southwest of [[Karazhal]], [[Karagandy]], [[Kazakhstan]], and about {{convert|550|km|mi|sp=us}} northeast of [[Baikonur]], in open flat country far from any populated area. In a small circular fenced area at the site is a memorial monument in the form of a three-sided metallic column. Near the top of the column on each side is the engraved image of the face of a crew member set into a stylized triangle.{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?t=h&lci=org.wikipedia.en&q=47.35663,70.12142(Soyuz+11)&ll=47.356749,70.121613&spn=0.007137,0.02075&z=16 |title = Google Maps - Soyuz 11 Landing Site - Monument Location|accessdate = 2010-12-25}}{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?ll=47.359133,70.123994&spn=0.006672,0.02075&t=k&z=16&iwloc=lyrftr:com.panoramio.all,12164185215360008001,47.357432,70.122986&lci=com.panoramio.all |title = Google Maps - Soyuz 11 Landing Site - Monument Photo|accessdate = 2010-12-25}}{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?ll=47.356821,70.121719&spn=0,0.02075&t=h&z=16&lci=com.panoramio.all&layer=c&cbll=47.356821,70.121719&cbp=12,0,,0,5&photoid=po-35267103 |title = Google Maps - Soyuz 11 Landing Site - Monument Photo closeup|accessdate = 2010-12-25}} |- || {{nowrap|1986-01-28}} || Vehicle disintegration during launch – [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|Space Shuttle ''Challenger'' disaster]] || {{nowrap|[[STS-51-L]]}} || {{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Gregory Jarvis]]}}

{{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Dick Scobee]]}} ||The Space Shuttle [[Space Shuttle Challenger|''Challenger'']] was destroyed 73 seconds after lift-off on [[STS-51-L]] at an altitude of {{convert|15|km|ft|sp=us}}. The investigation found that cold weather conditions caused an [[O-ring]] seal to fail, allowing hot gases from the shuttle [[Space Shuttle Solid Rocket Booster|solid rocket booster (SRB)]] to impinge on the [[Space Shuttle external tank|external propellant tank]] and booster strut. The strut and aft end of the tank failed, allowing the top of the SRB to rotate into the top of the tank. ''Challenger'' was thrown sideways into the [[Mach number|Mach]] 1.8 windstream and broke up with the loss of all seven crew members. NASA investigators determined they may have survived the spacecraft disintegration, possibly unconscious from [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]]; some tried to activate their emergency oxygen. Any survivors of the breakup were killed, however, when the largely intact [[cockpit]] hit the water at 320 km/h (200 mph), about 32 km (20 miles) east of [[Cape Canaveral]] at 28.64 degrees north, 80.28 degrees west.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UE9DAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gq0MAAAAIBAJ&pg=2046,632352 "Shuttle explodes; crew lost"], ''Frederick, OK - Daily Leader newspaper'', January 28, 1986.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SQAuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=eNsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1908,6830991 "Flight From Triumph to Tragedy Kills Challenger's 'Seven Heroes'"], ''The Palm Beach Post'', January 29, 1986. About half of the vehicle's remains were never recovered, and fragments still wash ashore occasionally on the coast of [[Brevard County, Florida]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2015}} |- ||{{nowrap|2003-02-01}} || Vehicle disintegration on re-entry – [[Space Shuttle Columbia disaster|Space Shuttle ''Columbia'' disaster]] ||{{nowrap|[[STS-107]]}} ||{{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Rick Husband|Rick D. {{nowrap|{{flagicon|Israel}} [[Ilan Ramon]]}} ||The Space Shuttle [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] was lost as it returned from a two-week mission, [[STS-107]]. Damage to the shuttle's [[Space shuttle thermal protection system|thermal protection system (TPS)]] led to structural failure of the shuttle's left wing and the spacecraft ultimately broke apart during reentry at an altitude of under 65 km. Investigation revealed damage to the reinforced carbon-carbon leading edge wing panel resulted from the impact of a piece of foam insulation that broke away from the external tank during the launch.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VPtPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2QgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4185,576971 "Space Shuttle debris rains across Texas"], ''Ocala, FL Star Banner newspaper'', February 2, 2003. The vehicle broke up over the [[southwestern United States]] and fell in fragments over eastern [[Texas]] and central [[Louisiana]]. |} {| class="wikitable" |+Spaceflight fatalities below the [[Karman line]] |- ! Date !! Incident !! Mission !! Fatalities !! Description |- | {{nowrap|1967-11-15}} || Control failure || {{nowrap|[[X-15 Flight 3-65-97]]}} || {{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Michael J. Adams]]}} || During X-15 Flight 191, Adams' seventh flight, the plane had an electrical problem followed by control problems at the [[apogee]] of its flight. The pilot may also have become disoriented. During reentry from a 266,000 ft (50.4 mile, 81.1 km) apogee, the X-15 yawed and went into a spin at Mach 5. The pilot recovered, but went into a Mach 4.7 inverted dive. Excessive loading led to structural breakup at about 65,000 feet (19.8 km).{{cite web|url=http://www.check-six.com/Crash_Sites/X-15A_crash_site.htm|title=X-15A Crash|publisher=}} Adams was posthumously awarded [[Astronaut Badge|astronaut wings]], as his flight had passed an altitude of 50 miles (80.5 km),[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=g8wpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fAEEAAAAIBAJ&dq=nasa&pg=5777%2C6076777 "Pilot Killed As X-15 Falls From Altitude Of 50 Miles"], ''Toledo Blade newspaper'', November 16, 1967. {{cite news | author = Associated Press | title = Mystery death plunge of X-15 rocket plane | newspaper = The Windsor Star | page = 72 | location = Windsor, Ontario | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CTU_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=gFEMAAAAIBAJ&dq=x-15&pg=3974,5212179 | date = 1967-11-16 }} |} ===During training or testing=== In addition to accidents during spaceflights, 13 astronauts, test pilots, and other personnel have been killed during training and test flights. {| class="wikitable" border="1" cellpadding=3 cellspacing=3 |+Fatalities during training or testing for spaceflight |- bgcolor=#cccccc ! Description |- ||Fire in altitude chamber ||{{nowrap|23 March 1961}} || (Soviet Air Force Group 1) ||{{nowrap|{{flagicon|Soviet Union}} [[Valentin Bondarenko]]}} ||First space-related fatality. During a 15-day endurance experiment in a low-pressure altitude chamber with at least 50% [[oxygen]] atmosphere, [[Vostok programme|Vostok]] cosmonaut trainee Bondarenko dropped an alcohol-soaked cloth onto an electric hotplate. He suffered [[third-degree burns]] over most of his body and face, and died in a hospital 16 hours later. {{cite news | author = Associated Press | title = Soviets admit cosmonaut's death | newspaper = Wilmington Morning Star | page = 6 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LsEsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IRQEAAAAIBAJ&dq=space%20training%20accident&pg=7046,1879647 | date = 1986-04-06 | location = Wilmington, North Carolina | ref = harv }} |- ||Training jet crash ||{{nowrap|31 October 1964}} || ([[NASA Astronaut Group 3]]) ||{{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Theodore Freeman]]}} ||Before being selected for a Gemini crew, Freeman was flying a [[Northrop T-38|T-38]] jet trainer on landing approach to Ellington AFB near Houston, TX, when a [[goose]] smashed into the left side of the cockpit [[canopy (aircraft)|canopy]]. Shards of [[Plexiglas]] entered the engine intake and caused both engines to [[flame out]]. Freeman [[ejection seat|ejected]] too close to the ground for his parachute to open properly.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_mMhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=54YFAAAAIBAJ&dq=theodore%20freeman&pg=2525%2C4569 "Crash Kills Astronaut"], ''Richland, WA - Tri City Herald'', Nov. 1, 1964[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YqYyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NOkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1474,394194 "Goose Hit Jet, Killing Astronaut"], ''The Miami News'', Nov. 17, 1964 |- ||[[1966 NASA T-38 crash|Training jet crash]] ||{{nowrap|28 February 1966}} || [[Gemini 9A|Gemini 9]] ||{{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Elliot See]]}}
{{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Charles Bassett]]}} ||See and Bassett attempted to land their T-38 at [[Lambert Field]] in [[St. Louis, Missouri]] in bad weather, and crashed into the adjacent [[McDonnell Aircraft]] factory, where they were going for simulator training for their Gemini 9 flight.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Zf4cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EpsEAAAAIBAJ&dq=see%20bassett%20crash&pg=6560%2C4113604 "2 Astronauts Die In Plane Crash"], ''The Tuscaloosa News'', Feb. 28, 1966[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=E20eAAAAIBAJ&sjid=S8kEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2560,5750 "See - Bassett Backup Crew Gets Gemini"], ''Daytona Beach, FL - Morning Journal newspaper'', Mar 1, 1966 |- ||Fire during spacecraft test ||{{nowrap|27 January 1967}} ||[[Apollo 1]] ||{{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Gus Grissom|Virgil "Gus" Grissom]]}}
{{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Ed White (astronaut)|Ed White]]}}

Chaffee]]}} ||An electrical fire in the cabin spread quickly in the pure oxygen atmosphere and claimed the lives of all three Apollo 1 crew members during a "plugs-out" test in preparation for their planned February 21 launch.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JtApAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ockEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1478,5366370 "One Astronaut Cried 'Fire' Before All Died"], ''Daytona Beach, FL News-Journal Newspaper'', Jan 29, 1967 |- ||Training jet crash ||{{nowrap|5 October 1967}} || ([[Apollo program|Apollo]]) ||{{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Clifton Williams|Clifton C. Williams]]}} ||Williams, flying alone in a T-38 jet from [[Cape Kennedy]], Florida to [[Houston]], Texas, crashed due to an aileron control mechanical failure, about {{convert|15|mi}} north of [[Tallahassee]], Florida.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BcIwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MFcDAAAAIBAJ&dq=williams%20crash&pg=7184%2C1086744 "Williams Wanted To Be First On The Moon"], ''St. Petersburg, FL - Evening Independent newspaper'', Oct. 6, 1967 Williams ejected too low for the parachute to open properly.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4OYhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5GUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5402,1608439 "Board Pinpoints Astronaut's Death"], ''Sarasota, FL - Herald-Tribune newspaper'', Jun. 7, 1968 Williams had been selected as lunar module pilot on an Apollo crew with commander [[Pete Conrad]] and command module pilot [[Richard F. Gordon Jr.|Richard Gordon]]. |- ||Training jet crash ||{{nowrap|8 December 1967}} || ([[Manned Orbiting Laboratory]]) ||{{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Robert Henry Lawrence Jr.]]}} ||The first African-American astronaut, selected for the Air Force [[Manned Orbiting Laboratory]] program, was killed when his [[F-104 Starfighter]] jet crashed at [[Edwards Air Force Base]], California, while practicing a series of high speed, quick descent landings with Major Harvey Royer as pilot in command. Both crewmen ejected; Royer survived with injuries, but Lawrence, the instructor pilot, was found in his ejection seat, parachute not fully deployed.{{cite book|author=Shayler David|title=Disasters and Accidents in Manned Spaceflight|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ng9i5IMtlpsC&pg=PA84|year=2000|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1-85233-225-9|page=84}}[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3a4rAAAAIBAJ&sjid=m_0FAAAAIBAJ&dq=lawrence%20astronaut&pg=3090%2C4769907 "Air Crash Kills Astro"], ''Nashua, NH - Telegraph newspaper'', Dec. 9, 1967 |- ||Drowned during water recovery training ||{{nowrap|11 July 1993}} ||(Soviet Air Force Cosmonaut Training Group 11) ||{{nowrap|{{flagicon|Russia}} [[Sergei Vozovikov]]}} ||Sergei Yuriyevich Vozovikov was a member of the Soviet Air Force Cosmonaut Training Group 11. His Cosmonaut training was from 1 October 1991 to 6 March 1992. He drowned 11 July 1993 during water recovery training in the Black Sea, near [[Anapa]], Russia.[http://www.astronautix.com/astros/vozvikov.htm "Vozovikov"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019174215/http://astronautix.com/astros/vozvikov.htm |date=2010-10-19 }}, ''Encyclopedia Astronautica''{{cite book|title=Disasters and accidents in manned spaceflight|author=David Shayler|publisher=Springer|date=June 2000|pages=470|isbn=1-85233-225-5}} |- ||[[VSS Enterprise crash|Spaceplane crash during test flight]] ||{{nowrap|31 October 2014}} ||[[VSS Enterprise]] PF04 ||{{nowrap|{{flagicon|US}} [[Michael Alsbury]]}} || [[Michael Alsbury]] was killed and [[Peter Siebold]] was seriously injured when [[SpaceShipTwo]] [[VSS Enterprise|VSS ''Enterprise'']] disintegrated during a powered atmospheric test flight over California due to premature deployment of the [[Atmospheric entry#Feathered reentry|feathering system]].{{cite web|url=http://spaceflightnow.com/2014-10-31/virgin-galactics-spaceshiptwo-suffers-anomaly-during-test-flight/|title=Virgin Galactic's SpaceShipTwo rocket plane crashes on test flight|first=Stephen|last=Clark|publisher=SpaceflightNow|date=31 October 2014|accessdate=31 October 2014}} |} ==Non-fatal incidents during spaceflight== Apart from actual disasters, a number of missions resulted in some very near misses and also some training accidents that nearly resulted in deaths. {| class="wikitable" border="1" cellpadding=3 cellspacing=3 |- bgcolor=#cccccc ! Incident !! Date !! Mission !! Description |- ||Separation failure ||{{nowrap|12 April 1961}} ||{{nowrap|[[Vostok 1]]}} ||After retrofire, the Vostok service module unexpectedly remained attached to the reentry module by a bundle of wires. The two halves of the craft were supposed to separate ten seconds after retrofire. But they did not separate until 10 minutes after retrofire, when the wire bundle finally burned through. The spacecraft went into wild gyrations at the beginning of reentry, before the wires burned through and the reentry module settled into the proper reentry attitude. {{cite news | author = American Press | title = Report: First Man In Space Nearly Died In The Attempt | location = Durant, Oklahoma | newspaper = The Durant Daily Democrat | date = 1996-03-06 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapersid=tJZDAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pa4MAAAAIBAJ&dq=rocket%20explodes%20%7C%20explosion%20%7C%20accident%20%7C%20fatal%20%7C%20died&pg=4822%2C598696 }} |- ||Landing capsule sank in water ||{{nowrap|21 July 1961}} ||[[Mercury-Redstone 4]] ||After splashdown in the Atlantic, the hatch malfunctioned and blew, filling the capsule with water and almost drowning [[Gus Grissom]], who managed to escape before it sank. Grissom then had to deal with a spacesuit that was rapidly filling with water, but managed to get into the helicopter's retrieval collar and was lifted to safety. {{cite news | last = Webb Jr. | first = Alvin B. | title = Space Cabin Sinks After Hatch 'Blows' | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8MEzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OkgDAAAAIBAJ&dq=grissom&pg=5918%2C3851655 | location = Salt Lake City, Utah | newspaper = The Deseret News | date = 1961-07-21 }} The spacecraft was recovered in 1999, having settled {{convert|300|nmi|abbr=on}} southeast of Cape Canaveral in {{convert|15000|ft|abbr=on}} of seawater. An unexploded [[SOFAR bomb]], designed for sound fixing and ranging in case the craft sank, had failed and had to be dealt with when it was recovered from the ocean floor in 1999.{{cite web |title = The Liberty Bell 7 Recovery |url = http://www.uxb.com/pages/marine-services.html |publisher = UXB |location = Blacksburg, Virginia |year = 2011 |accessdate = 2013-03-18 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6FDpAqAU4?url=http://www.uxb.com/pages/marine-services.html |archivedate = 2013-03-18 |deadurl = yes |df = }} |- ||Spacesuit or airlock design fault ||{{nowrap|18 March 1965}} ||{{nowrap|[[Voskhod 2]]}} ||The mission featured the world's first [[spacewalk]], by [[Alexei Leonov]]. After his twelve minutes outside, Leonov's spacesuit inflated in the vacuum to the point where he could not reenter the airlock. He opened a valve to allow some of the suit's pressure to bleed off, and was barely able to get back inside the capsule after suffering side effects of [[Decompression sickness|the bends]]. Because the spacecraft was so cramped, the crew could not keep to their reentry schedule and landed 386 km off course in deep forest. They spent a night sheltering in the capsule from the cold, and a second night in a temporary hut built by rescuers before skiing with them to a clearing where a helicopter flew them to [[Perm]].{{cite news|last1=Rincon|first1=Paul|title=The First Spacewalk How the first human to take steps in outer space nearly didn't return to Earth|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/special/2014/newsspec_9035/index.html|accessdate=2 February 2016|publisher=BBC|date=2014}}{{cite news|last1=McKie|first1=Robin|title=Alexei Leonov, the first man to walk in space|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/may/09/alexei-leonov-first-man-to-walk-in-space-soviet-cosmonaut|accessdate=2 February 2016|work=The Observer|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|date=9 May 2015}} |- ||Engine shutdown at launch ||{{nowrap|12 December 1965}} ||{{nowrap|[[Gemini 6A]]}} ||The first on-pad shutdown in the US Manned Program. [[Gemini 7]] orbiting {{convert|185|mi}} directly over Missile Row witnessed the event and reported they could clearly see the momentary exhaust plume before shutdown.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=htmd4BrNJ5k|title=Aborted Launch - Gemini 6 (CBS)|first=|last=lunarmodule5|date=28 May 2010|publisher=|via=YouTube}} |- ||Equipment failure ||{{nowrap|17 March 1966}} ||{{nowrap|[[Gemini 8]]}} ||A maneuvering thruster refused to shut down and put their capsule into an uncontrolled spin. {{cite news | last = Volker | first = Al | title = Astronaut Feared 'Break-Up' | newspaper = The Miami News | date = 1966-03-27 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GG5VAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_D4NAAAAIBAJ&dq=gemini%208&pg=1379%2C3483507 }} After the Gemini spun up to one revolution per second, [[Neil Armstrong]] regained control by switching from the main attitude control system to the reentry system. Mission rules required a landing as soon as possible once the reentry thrusters were used, causing an early end to the flight.{{cite web|title=Gemini 8|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1966-020A|website=National Space Science Data Center|publisher=NASA|accessdate=June 11, 2015}} |- ||Separation failure ||{{nowrap|18 January 1969}} ||{{nowrap|[[Soyuz 5]]}} ||Harrowing reentry and landing when the capsule's service module initially refused to separate, causing the spacecraft to begin reentry faced the wrong way. The service module broke away before the capsule would have been destroyed, and so it made a rough but survivable landing far off course in the [[Ural mountains]]. |- ||Struck twice by lightning during launch ||{{nowrap|14 November 1969}} ||{{nowrap|[[Apollo 12]]}} ||Two lightning strikes during launch. The first strike, at 36 seconds after liftoff, knocked the three fuel cells offline and the craft switched to battery power automatically. The second strike, at 52 seconds after liftoff, knocked the onboard guidance platform offline. Four temperature sensors on the outside of the Lunar Module were burnt out and four measuring devices in the reaction control system failed temporarily. Fuel cell power was restored about four minutes later. The astronauts spent additional time in Earth orbit to make sure the spacecraft was functional before firing their S-IVB third stage engine and departing for the Moon.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xUo1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=0XoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1814,4497663 "Apollo Hit Twice By Lightning"], ''Salt Lake City, Utah - Deseret newspaper'', Dec 17, 1969[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ru8rAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EAYGAAAAIBAJ&dq=apollo%20lightning&pg=5072,4709789 "Apollo Struck Twice By Lightning"], ''Hopkinsville, Kentucky - New Era newspaper'', Nov 22, 1969 |- ||Struck by camera during splashdown ||{{nowrap|24 November 1969}} ||{{nowrap|[[Apollo 12]]}} ||Astronaut Alan Bean was struck above the right eyebrow by a 16mm movie camera when the spacecraft [[Splashdown (spacecraft landing)|splashed down]] in the ocean. The camera broke free from its storage place. Bean suffered a [[concussion]],{{cite book |last1=Crotts |first1=Arlin |title=The New Moon: Water, Exploration, and Future Habitation |date=2014 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=9781139915557 |page=356 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y8mKBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA356}} and a 1.25 cm cut above the eyebrow that required stitches.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NdMfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EtkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2593,4742445 "Moon Men Healthy, Resting"], ''The Fort Scott, KS - Tribune newspaper'', Nov 25, 1969 |- ||Premature engine shutdown ||{{nowrap|11 April 1970}} ||{{nowrap|[[Apollo 13]]}} ||During launch, the Saturn V second stage experienced a premature shutdown on one of its five engines. The center engine shut down two minutes early. The remaining engines on the second and third stages were burned a total of 34 seconds longer to compensate. It was later determined that the shutdown was caused by [[pogo oscillation]] of the engine. [[Parking orbit]] and [[translunar injection]] were successfully achieved.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dKxVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=POEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5882,2397166 "Third U.S. lunar mission leaves pad without hitch"], ''Eugene, OR - Register-Guard newspaper'', Apr 11, 1970[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8NQnAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vJADAAAAIBAJ&pg=5952,2859197 "Apollo 13 on way after engine fails"], ''The Age newspaper'', Apr 13, 1970[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rRZJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=doMMAAAAIBAJ&pg=695,4976223 "Apollo 14 Tests Wait For Month"], ''Youngstown Vindicator newspaper'', Apr 29, 1970 |- ||Equipment failure ||{{nowrap|13 April 1970}} ||{{nowrap|[[Apollo 13]]}} ||The crew came home safely after a violent rupture of a liquid oxygen tankNASA's official report ([https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19700076776_1970076776.pdf REPORT OF APOLLO 13 REVIEW BOARD]) does not use the word "explosion" in describing the tank failure. Rupture disks and other safety measures were present to prevent a catastrophic explosion, and analysis of pressure readings and subsequent ground-testing determined that these safety measures worked as designed. [https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19700076776_1970076776.pdf See findings 26 and 27 on page 195 (5-22) of the NASA report]. deprived the Service Module of its ability to produce electrical power, crippling their spacecraft en route to the moon. They survived the loss of use of their command ship by relying on the Lunar Module as a "life boat" to provide life support and power for the trip home.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8eczAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1jIHAAAAIBAJ&dq=apollo%2013&pg=5469%2C1688843 "Magnitude Of Apollo 13 Damage Astounded Crew"], ''Lodi, CA News-Sentinel'', Apr. 18, 1970 |- ||One of three main parachutes failed ||{{nowrap|7 August 1971}} ||{{nowrap|[[Apollo 15]]}} ||During descent, the three main parachutes opened successfully. However, when the remaining reaction control system fuel was jettisoned, one parachute was damaged by the discarded fuel causing it to collapse. Spacecraft and crew still [[Splashdown (spacecraft landing)|splashed down]] safely, at a slightly higher than normal velocity, on the two remaining main parachutes. If a second parachute had failed, the spacecraft would probably have been crushed on impact with the ocean, according to a NASA official.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6PdfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=k1YMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5562,3504799 "Rocket Fuel Gets Blame In Apollo Parachute Fluke"], ''Lumberton, NC - The Robesonian newspaper'', Aug 13, 1971 |- ||Separation failure ||{{nowrap|5 April 1975}} ||{{nowrap|[[Soyuz 7K-T No.39|Soyuz 18a]]}} ||The mission nearly ended in disaster when the rocket suffered a second-stage separation failure during launch. This also interrupted the craft's attitude, causing the vehicle to accelerate towards the Earth and triggering an emergency reentry sequence. Due to the downward acceleration, the crew experienced an acceleration of 21.3 ''g'' rather than the nominal 15 ''g'' for an abort. Upon landing, the vehicle rolled down a hill and stopped just short of a high cliff. The crew survived, but Lazarev, the mission commander, suffered internal injuries due to the severe G-forces and was never able to fly again. |- ||Chemical poisoning ||{{nowrap|24 July 1975}} ||[[Apollo-Soyuz Test Project]] ||During final descent and parachute deployment, the U.S. crew were exposed to 300 µL/L of toxic [[nitrogen tetroxide]] (Reaction Control System [[oxidizer]]) fumes venting from the spacecraft and reentering a cabin air intake, because a switch was left in the wrong position. 400µL/L is fatal. [[Vance Brand]] lost consciousness for a short time. The crew members suffered from burning sensations of their eyes, faces, noses, throats and lungs. [[Thomas Patten Stafford|Thomas Stafford]] quickly broke out emergency oxygen masks and put one on Brand and gave one to [[Deke Slayton]]. The crew were exposed to the toxic fumes from 24,000 ft (7.3 km) down to landing. About an hour after landing the crew developed chemical-induced pneumonia and their lungs had [[edema]]. They experienced shortness of breath and were hospitalized in Hawaii. The crew spent five days in the hospital, followed by a week of observation in semi-isolation. By July 30, their chest X-rays appeared to return to normal except for Slayton; he was diagnosed with a benign lesion, unrelated to the gas exposure, which was later removed.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RBgsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kMgEAAAAIBAJ&dq=apollo%20gas&pg=993%2C1384026 "Brand Takes Blame For Apollo Gas Leak"], ''Florence, AL - Times Daily newspaper'', Aug. 10, 1975 |- ||Landing capsule sank in water ||{{nowrap|16 October 1976}} ||{{nowrap|[[Soyuz 23]]}} ||The capsule broke through the surface of a frozen lake and was dragged underwater by its parachute. The crew was saved after a very difficult rescue operation.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uR8qAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OCkEAAAAIBAJ&dq=soyuz%2023&pg=7061%2C5025050 "Cosmonauts Land in Lake, Blizzard"], ''Milwaukee Journal newspaper'', Oct 18, 1976 |- ||Engine malfunction ||{{nowrap|12 April 1979}} ||{{nowrap|[[Soyuz 33]]}} ||Engine failure forced the mission to be aborted. It was the first-ever failure of a ''Soyuz'' engine during orbital operations. The crew, commander [[Nikolai Rukavishnikov]] and [[Bulgarians|Bulgarian]] cosmonaut [[Georgi Ivanov (cosmonaut)|Georgi Ivanov]], suffered a steep ballistic re-entry, but were safely recovered. |- || SRB ignition shock wave overpressure reached design limits of orbiter structure ||{{nowrap|12 April 1981}} ||{{nowrap| [[STS-1]]}} ||During launch, the Solid Rocket Booster ignition shock wave overpressure was four times greater than expected (2.0 psi measured vs 0.5 psi predicted). Some of the aft structures on {{OV|102}} reached their design limits (2.0 psi) from the overpressure. The overpressure bent four struts that supported two RCS fuel tanks in the nose of ''Columbia'' and the orbiter's locked body flap was pushed up and down {{convert|6|in|cm|abbr=on}} by the shock wave. [[John Young (astronaut)|John Young]] and [[Robert Crippen]] in the crew cabin received a 3 ''g'' jolt from the shock wave. An improved water spray shock wave damping system had to be installed on the launch pad prior to launch.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5owxAAAAIBAJ&pg=6809%2C2982705 "Shock Wave Doesn't Worry Shuttle Crew"], ''Toledo Blade newspaper'', Sep 16, 1981[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8m4hAAAAIBAJ&pg=6280%2C3165186 "Shuttle shock wave problem still puzzles NASA"], ''Richland, WA - Tri-City Herald newspaper'', Sep 11, 1981[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TFpPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NwMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6671%2C1003970 "Shuttle's Pressure Problem Studied"], ''Toledo Blade newspaper'', Jun 27, 1981[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Up0cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GGgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6386,4682253 "Space Shuttle Columbia Nears Second Flight"], ''Sarasota Herald Tribune newspaper'', Oct 25, 1981 |- ||Fire in launch vehicle ||{{nowrap|26 September 1983}} ||[[Soyuz 7K-ST No.16L|Soyuz T-10-1]] ||A fuel spillage before the planned liftoff caused the vehicle to be engulfed in flames. The crew was narrowly saved by the activation of their launch escape system, with the rocket exploding two seconds later. |- ||Leaked hydrazine fuel fire and explosion ||{{nowrap|8 December 1983}} ||{{nowrap|[[STS-9]]}} ||In the last two minutes of the mission, during {{OV|102}}'s final approach to the Edwards AFB runway, hydrazine fuel leaked onto hot surfaces of two of the three onboard [[auxiliary power unit]]s (APU) in the aft compartment of the shuttle and caught fire. About 15 minutes after landing, hydrazine fuel trapped in the APU control valves exploded, destroying the valves in both APUs. The fire also damaged nearby wiring. The fire stopped when the supply of leaked fuel was exhausted. All of this was discovered the next day when technicians removed an access panel and discovered the area blackened and scorched. It is believed that hydrazine leaked in orbit and froze, stopping the leak. After returning, the leak restarted and ignited when combined with oxygen from the atmosphere. There were no injuries during the incident.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bn1hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iXIFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4279,3692142 "Fuel Devices on Space Shuttle Were on Fire During Landing"], ''Schenectady Gazette newspaper'', Dec 12, 1983[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QbVPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YQYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4756,8269042 "Engineers Study Blaze Aboard Columbia"], ''Ocala Star-Banner newspaper'', Dec 14, 1983 |- ||Space Shuttle in-flight engine failure ||{{nowrap|29 July 1985}} ||{{nowrap| [[STS-51-F]]}} ||Five minutes, 45 seconds into ascent, one of three [[Space Shuttle Main Engine|main engines]] aboard ''Challenger'' shut down prematurely due to a spurious high temperature reading. At about the same time, a second main engine almost shut down from a similar problem, but this was observed and inhibited by a fast acting [[flight controller]]. The failed SSME resulted in an [[Space Shuttle abort modes#Abort to Orbit (ATO)|Abort To Orbit (ATO)]] trajectory, whereby the shuttle achieves a lower than planned orbital altitude. Had the second engine failed within about 20 seconds of the first, a [[Space Shuttle abort modes#Transoceanic abort landing|Transoceanic Abort Landing (TAL)]] abort might have been necessary. No bailout option existed until after mission STS-51-L, the ''Challenger'' disaster. But even with that option, a bailout (a "contingency abort") would never be considered when an "intact abort" option exists, and after five minutes of normal flight it would always exist unless a serious flight control failure or some other major problem beyond engine shutdown occurred.{{sfnp|Dumoulin|2000}} {{cite news | author = United Press International | title = Shuttle OK after close call | location = Meriden, Connecticut | newspaper = Record-Journal | date = 1985-07-30 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bgRdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DloNAAAAIBAJ&dq=shuttle%20close%20call%20nasa&pg=5306,5832772 | page = 1 | ref = harv }} |- ||Sensor failure ||{{nowrap|6 September 1988}} ||{{nowrap|[[Mir EP-3]]}} ||At the end of the mission, Soviet cosmonaut [[Vladimir Lyakhov]] and [[Afghanistan|Afghan]] cosmonaut [[Abdul Ahad Mohmand]] undocked from [[Mir]] in the spacecraft [[Soyuz TM-5]]. During descent they suffered a computer software problem combined with a sensor problem. The deorbit engine on the TM-5 spacecraft which was to propel them into [[atmospheric reentry]], did not behave as expected. During an attempted burn, the computer shut off the engines prematurely, believing the spacecraft was out of alignment.{{sfnp|Harland|2005|pages=173–174}} Lyakhov determined that they were not, in fact, out of alignment, and asserted that the problem was caused by conflicting signals picked up by the alignment sensors caused by solar glare.{{sfnp|Harland|2005|pages=173–174}} With the problem apparently solved, two orbits later he restarted to deorbit engines. But the engines shut off again. The flight director decided that they would have to remain in orbit an extra day (a full revolution of the Earth), so they could determine what the problem was. During this time it was realised that during the second attempted engine burn, the computer had tried to execute the program which was used to dock with Mir several months earlier during [[Mir EP-2|EP-2]].{{sfnp|Harland|2005|pages=173–174}} After reprogramming the computer, the next attempt was successful, and the crew safely landed on 7 September.{{Sfnp|Furniss, Shayler, Shayler|2007|p=355}} |- ||Thermal tile damage ||{{nowrap|6 December 1988}} ||{{nowrap|[[STS-27]]}} ||{{OV|104}}' Thermal Protection System tiles sustained unusually severe damage during this flight. Ablative insulating material from the right-hand solid rocket booster nose cap had hit the orbiter about 85 seconds into the flight, as seen in footage of the ascent. The crew made an inspection of the shuttle's impacted starboard side using the shuttle's [[Canadarm]] robot arm, but the limited resolution and range of the cameras made it impossible to determine the full extent of the tile damage. Following reentry, more than 700 tiles were found to be damaged including one that was missing entirely. STS-27 was the most heavily damaged shuttle to return to earth safely. |- ||Spacesuit puncture ||{{nowrap|8 April 1991}} ||{{nowrap|[[STS-37]]}} ||During an [[extravehicular activity]], a small rod (palm bar) in a glove of EV2 astronaut [[Jay Apt]]'s [[extravehicular mobility unit]] punctured the suit. Somehow, the astronaut's hand conformed to the puncture and sealed it, preventing any detectable depressurization. During post-flight debriefings, Apt said after the second EVA, when he removed the gloves, his right hand index finger had an abrasion behind the knuckle. A postflight inspection of the right hand glove found the palm bar of the glove penetrating a restraint and glove bladder into the index finger side of the glove. NASA found air leakage with the bar in place was 3.8 [[SCCM (flow unit)|SCCM]], well within the specification of 8.0 SCCM. They said if the bar had come out of the hole, the leak still would not have been great enough to activate the secondary oxygen pack. The suit would, however, have shown a high oxygen rate indication.[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19930016767_1993016767.pdf "STS-37 Space Shuttle Mission Report May 1991 - NASA-CR-193062"], ''Extravehicular Activity Evaluation, Page 16'', accessed online 4 Jan, 2011 |- ||Explosive release device punctured cargo bay bulkhead ||{{nowrap|12 September 1993}} ||{{nowrap| [[STS-51]]}} ||While releasing the Advanced Communications Technology Satellite from the payload bay, both the primary and backup explosive release devices detonated. Only the primary device was supposed to have detonated. Large metal bands holding the satellite in place were ripped away, causing flying debris. The debris punctured the orbiter's payload bay bulkhead leading to the main engine compartment, damaging wiring trays and payload bay thermal insulation blankets. The puncture in the bulkhead was 3 mm by 13 mm in size. The crew was uninjured and the damage was not great enough to endanger the shuttle. The satellite was undamaged.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3fFlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-9AMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6694,4840969 "Damage suffered by space shuttle"], ''Portsmouth, OH - Daily Times newspaper'', Oct 8, 1993 |- ||Eye injury from Mir exercise equipment ||{{nowrap|18 May 1995}} ||{{nowrap|[[Mir]]}} ||While exercising on the EO-18/NASA 1/[[Soyuz TM-21]] mission, astronaut [[Norman E. Thagard]] suffered an eye injury. He was using an exercise device, doing deep knee bends, with elastic straps. One of the straps slipped off of his foot, flew up, and hit him in the eye. Later, even a small amount of light caused pain in his eye. He said using the eye was, "like looking at the world through gauze." An ophthalmologist at Mission Control-Moscow prescribed steroid drops and the eye healed.[https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4225/nasa1/nasa1.htm "NASA-1 Norm Thagard: An Ending and a Beginning"], ''NASA History.Gov website'', accessed online Jan 27, 2011 |- ||Fire on board ||{{nowrap|23 February 1997}} ||{{nowrap|[[Mir]]}} ||There was a fire on board the ''Mir'' space station when a [[lithium perchlorate]] canister used to generate oxygen leaked. The fire was extinguished after about 90 seconds, but smoke did not clear for several minutes. |- ||Fuel cell failure ||{{nowrap|8 April 1997}} ||{{nowrap|[[STS-83]]}} ||Fuel cell #2 aboard [[Space Shuttle Columbia|Space Shuttle ''Columbia'']] unexpectedly failed on Day 4 in orbit, forcing an early end to the flight. The mission touched down safely, and the crew was reflown with the same mission plan on [[STS-94]]. |- ||Collision in space ||{{nowrap|25 June 1997}} ||{{nowrap|[[Mir]]}} ||At ''Mir'', during a re-docking test with the [[Progress M-34]] cargo freighter, the [[Progress spacecraft|Progress]] freighter collided with the [[Spektr]] module and solar arrays of the Mir space station. This damaged the solar arrays and the collision punctured a hole in the Spektr module and the space station began depressurizing. The onboard crew of two Russians and one visiting NASA astronaut were able to close off the Spektr module from the rest of Mir after quickly cutting cables and hoses blocking the hatch closure. |- ||Main engine electrical short and hydrogen leak ||{{nowrap|23 July 1999}} ||{{nowrap| [[STS-93]]}} ||Five seconds after liftoff, an electrical short knocked out controllers for two shuttle main engines. The engines automatically switched to their backup controllers. Had a further short shut down two engines, ''Columbia'' would have ditched in the ocean, although the crew could have possibly bailed out. Concurrently a pin came loose inside one engine and ruptured a cooling line, allowing a hydrogen fuel leak. This caused premature fuel exhaustion, but the vehicle safely achieved a slightly lower orbit. Had the failure propagated further, a risky transatlantic or RTLS abort would have been required. |- ||Toxic ammonia leak during EVA ||{{nowrap|10 February 2001}} ||[[International Space Station|ISS]]/[[STS-98]] ||During EVA 1 on the mission, NASA astronauts [[Robert L. Curbeam]] and [[Thomas D. Jones]] were connecting cooling lines on the International Space Station while working to install the [[Destiny Laboratory Module]]. A defective quick-disconnect valve allowed 5% of the ammonia cooling supply to escape into space. The escaping ammonia froze on the spacesuit of astronaut Curbeam as he struggled to close the valve. His helmet and suit were coated in ammonia crystals an inch thick. Mission Control instructed Curbeam to remain outside for an entire orbit to allow the Sun to evaporate the frozen ammonia from his spacesuit. When they returned to the airlock, the astronauts pressurized, vented and then repressurized the air lock to purge any remaining toxic ammonia. After they removed their spacesuits, the crew wore oxygen masks for another 20 minutes to allow life-support systems in the airlock to further filter the air. No injuries resulted from the incident.[https://www.nytimes.com/2006-12-16/science/space/16shuttle.html "A Toxic Leak Haunts the Shuttle Crew"], ''New York Times'', December 16, 2006 |- ||Ballistic reentry, injured shoulder ||{{nowrap|3 May 2003}} ||[[Soyuz TMA-1]] ||The capsule had a malfunction during its return to Earth from the ISS [[Expedition 6]] mission and performed a ballistic reentry. The crew was subjected to about 8 to 9 G's during reentry. The capsule landed 500 km from the intended landing target. In addition, after landing the capsule was dragged about 15 meters by its parachute and ended up on its side in a hard landing. Astronaut [[Don Pettit]] injured his shoulder and was placed on a stretcher in a rescue helicopter and did not take part in post-landing ceremonies.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article878581.ece "Moscow, we have a problem: our spacecraft is lost"], ''The London Sunday Times newspaper'', May 5, 2003[https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2003-05-03-space-shuttle_x.htm "Soyuz misses its mark but still finds Earth safely"], ''USA Today newspaper'', May 4, 2003{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=3452908 |title=Space crew reach Kazakh capital |date=May 6, 2003 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=October 15, 2011}} |- || Unplanned rolls during ascent ||{{nowrap|29 September 2004}} ||[[SpaceShipOne flight 16P|SpaceShipOne-16P]] ||On suborbital flight [[SpaceShipOne flight 16P|16P]], the first of two flights that won the [[X-Prize]] for exceeding 100 km in altitude, astronaut [[Mike Melvill]] experienced 29 unplanned rolls during and after powered ascent. The rolls began at 50 seconds into the engine burn. The burn was stopped 11 seconds early after burning a total of 76 seconds. After engine cutoff, the craft continued rolling while coasting to apogee. The roll was finally brought under control after apogee using the craft's reaction jets. SpaceShipOne landed safely and Mike Melvill was uninjured.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-3gpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QNYEAAAAIBAJ&dq=space&pg=5892,4182698 "Private rocket plane goes rolling into space"], ''The Southeast Missourian newspaper'', September 30, 2004[http://www.space.com/missionlaunches/rutan_roll_041002.html "SpaceShipOne Rolling Rumors: Rutan Sets the Record Straight"], ''Space.com website - posted: 2 October 2004'', accessed online 4 January 2011 |- ||Separation failure ||{{nowrap|19 April 2008}} ||[[Soyuz TMA-11]] ||Reentry mishap similar to that suffered by Soyuz 5 in 1969. The service module failed to completely separate from the reentry vehicle and caused it to face the wrong way during the early portion of aerobraking. As with Soyuz 5, the service module eventually separated and the reentry vehicle completed a rough but survivable landing. Following the Russian news agency [[Interfax]]'s report, this was widely reported as life-threatening[http://edition.cnn.com/2008/TECH/space/04/23/russia.space.ap/ Russia probes Soyuz capsule's perilous re-entry], ''[[CNN]]', April 23, 2008{{cite web | url = http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5jJitDZhZSzTx3L37XQOplAlh8fGQD9072A901 | title = Russian news agency says Soyuz crew was in danger on descent| last1=Eckel|first1=Mike| date=2008-04-24| archive-url = http://www.chinapost.com.tw/life/science-and-technology/2008/04/24/153410/Recent-Soyuz.htm| archive-date =2016-05-05 | dead-url =yes | access-date=2016-05-05}} while [[NASA]] urged caution pending an investigation of the vehicle.Morring, Frank, [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=space&id=news/wait042308.xml&headline=NASA%20Urges%20Caution%20On%20Soyuz%20Reports NASA Urges Caution On Soyuz Reports], [[Aviation Week & Space Technology]], April 23, 2008 South Korean astronaut [[Yi So-Yeon]] was hospitalized after her return to South Korea due to injuries caused by the rough return voyage in the Soyuz TMA-11 spacecraft. The South Korean Science Ministry said that the astronaut had a minor injury to her neck muscles and had bruised her spinal column.[http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=space&id=news/Southkor050208.xml&headline=South%20Korean%20Astronaut%20Hospitalized "South Korean Astronaut Hospitalized"], ''Aviation Week'', May 2, 2008 |- ||Aborted spacewalk after water leak in suit ||{{nowrap|16 July 2013}} ||[[International Space Station|ISS]] [[Expedition 36]] ||During EVA-23, [[European Space Agency]] astronaut [[Luca Parmitano]] reported that water was steadily leaking into his helmet. Flight controllers elected to abort the EVA immediately, and Parmitano made his way back to the [[Quest Joint Airlock|''Quest'' airlock]], followed by fellow astronaut [[Chris Cassidy]]. The airlock began repressurizing after a 1-hour and 32 minute spacewalk, and by this time Parmitano was having difficulty seeing, hearing, and speaking due to the amount of water in his suit. After repressurization, Expedition 36 commander [[Pavel Vinogradov]] and crewmembers [[Fyodor Yurchikhin]] and [[Karen Nyberg]] quickly removed Parmitano's helmet and soaked up the water with towels. Despite the incident, Parmitano was reported to be in good spirits and suffered no injury.[http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/07/astronaut-duo-us-spacewalk-outside-iss/ "EVA-23 terminated due to EVA-23 terminated due to Parmitano EMU issue"], ''NASASpaceFlight'', July 16, 2013[http://www.spaceflightnow.com/station/exp36/16eva/index2.html "Spacewalk aborted by spacesuit water leak"], ''SpaceflightNow'', July 16, 2013[http://www.nasa.gov/content/tuesday-spacewalk-ended-early/ "Tuesday Spacewalk Ended Early"], ''NASA'', July 16, 2013 By December, 2013, NASA had determined the leak to have been caused by a design flaw in the Portable Life Support System liquid coolant. The designers failed to take into account the physics of water in zero-g, which unintentionally allowed coolant water to mix with the air supply.[http://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/files/Suit_Water_Intrusion_Mishap_Investigation_Report.pdf],"International Space Station (ISS) EVA Suit Water Intrusion",''NASA'', December 20, 2013 |- |Hole detected in station |30 August 2018 |[[Soyuz MS-09]] attached to [[International Space Station|ISS]] [[Expedition 55]] |Ground controllers detected a dip in cabin pressure, which astronauts traced to a 2-millimeter hole in [[Soyuz MS-09]], which was quickly patched up by Soyuz commander Sergey Prokopyev with epoxy.{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/41694-space-station-air-leak-fixed.html|title=Space Station Leak All Patched Up Now, NASA Says|work=Space.com|access-date=2018-09-22}} |- |Launch booster failure, ballistic re-entry |11 October 2018 |[[Soyuz MS-10]] |The crew reported feeling weightless; mission control declared a rocket had failed. An emergency was declared and the spacecraft carrying the crew was sepaparated from the rocket. It returned to Earth in a ballistic descent (sharper than normal angle), and the crew experienced 6.7 [[g-force|G]] during the landing.[https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/11/europe/soyuz-rocket-russia-nasa-intl/index.html Astronauts survive Soyuz rocket emergency landing] CNN, 2018-10-11. The crew did not need immediate medical care when recovered. Investigation determined the ball joint supporting one of the side boosters had been deformed during assembly; the damaged joint prevented proper separation despite proper activation of the separation motors; the booster re-contacted the core stage, inflicting further damage.[https://lenta.ru/news/2018/10/31/rocketcos/ «Роскосмос» назвал причину крушения «Союза»] |} ==Non-fatal incidents during training== [[Image:LLTV crash.jpg|thumb|Test pilot Stuart Present ejects safely from the [[LLRV|Lunar Landing Training Vehicle]]. (NASA)]] Spaceflight-related accidents and incidents during assembly, testing, and preparation for flight of manned and unmanned spacecraft have occasionally resulted in injuries or the loss of [[Craft (vehicle)|craft]] since the earliest days of space programs. ==List== ===1960–1969=== * Three of the five [[Lunar Landing Research Vehicle|Lunar Landing Research and Training]] vehicles (LLRV and LLTV) were destroyed in crashes near Houston, Texas: ** 1968 May 6: LLRV No. 1 crashed at [[Ellington AFB]], Texas, caused by loss of helium pressure that controlled the steering jets. Neil Armstrong ejected safely.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0bhaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sFwDAAAAIBAJ&dq=ellington%20air%20force%20base&pg=7378%2C4574343 "Jet Moon Flight Trainer Crashes"], ''St. Petersburg, FL Times newspaper'', May 7, 1968 ** 1968 December 8: LLTV No. 1 crashed at Ellington AFB, Texas, caused by failure of the fly-by-wire control system. MSC test pilot Joseph Algranti ejected safely.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Mg9SAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZDQNAAAAIBAJ&dq=joseph%20algranti&pg=5481%2C2198327 "Moon Lander Crashes In Final Major Test"], ''Oxnard, CA - The Press-Courier'', Dec. 9, 1968 ** 1971 January 29: An LLTV crashed at Ellington AFB, Texas, caused by failure of the fly-by-wire control system. NASA test pilot Stuart Present ejected safely.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vwUVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0wEEAAAAIBAJ&dq=stuart-present&pg=4758%2C2868024 "Test Pilot Ejects Safely As Lunar Lander Crashes"], ''Toledo Blade newspaper'', Jan. 30, 1971 * 1960 July 16: ''Injured during centrifuge training'' : Soviet cosmonaut Anatoly Yakovlevich Kartashov suffered pinpoint hemorrhages of the spine during centrifuge training. Due to the injuries he was grounded by the medical staff and retired from the cosmonaut group on 7 April 1962[http://www.astronautix.com/astros/karashov.htm "Kartashov"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011140528/http://astronautix.com/astros/karashov.htm |date=2011-10-11 }}, ''Encyclopedia Astronautica'', Dec 26, 2010[https://books.google.com/books?id=rrdVPtCNL9AC&pg=PA353&dq=Anatoliy+Kartashov+centrifuge&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage "The first Soviet cosmonaut team: their lives, legacy, and historical impact "], ''by Colin Burgess and Rex Hall, pg 353'', published by Praxis 2010 * 1961 August 19: ''Parachute training accident, broken left foot'' : Cosmonaut [[Pavel Belyayev]] broke his left foot during a parachute jump related to cosmonaut training. As a result, he was out of cosmonaut training until 30 August 1962.[http://babelfish.yahoo.com/translate_url?doit=done&tt=url&intl=1&fr=bf-home&trurl=http://www.federalspace.ru/main.php%3Fid%3D167%26did%3D730&lp=ru_en&btnTrUrl=Translate "Biography of Pavel Belyayev"], ''Russian Federal Space Agency'', Jan 2, 2011 * 1961 Sep 2: ''[[Lockheed T-33|T-33]] jet engine failure, emergency landing'' : Astronauts Gus Grissom and Alan Shepard experienced a broken rotor blade in the jet engine of their T-33 jet while flying a training mission over Lake Erie. The astronauts left in the same jet a day later.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vJgtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kZ0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=5364,547215 "Astronauts In Close Call"], ''Montreal Gazette newspaper'', Sep 5, 1961 * 1962 Oct 22: ''Experimental Paraglider, hard landing'' : Astronaut Gus Grissom was piloting an experimental paraglider at Edwards Air Force Base, CA, that was towed aloft by another aircraft and released. The paraglider made a hard landing that crumpled the nose wheel. The craft remained upright and Grissom walked away unhurt.
