[[File:Brooklyn Museum - Jesus Carried to the Tomb (Jésus porté au tombeau) - James Tissot.jpg|right|thumb|250px|[[James Tissot]]'s ''Jesus Carried to the Tomb'', painted between 1886 and 1894]] '''Matthew 27:60''' is the sixtieth verse of the twenty-seventh chapter of the [[Gospel of Matthew]] in the [[New Testament]]. This verse describes the [[Entombment of Jesus]] by [[Joseph of Arimathea]] after the [[crucifixion of Jesus|crucifixion]]. The original [[Koine Greek]], according to [[The New Testament in the Original Greek|Westcott and Hort]], reads: :και εθηκεν αυτο εν τω καινω αυτου μνημειω ο ελατομησεν εν τη :πετρα και προσκυλισας λιθον μεγαν τη θυρα του μνημειου απηλθεν In the [[King James Version]] of the Bible it is translated as: :And laid it in his own new tomb, which he had hewn out in the rock: and :he rolled a great stone to the door of the sepulchre, and departed. The modern [[World English Bible]] translates the passage as: :and laid it in his own new tomb, which he had cut out in the rock, :and he rolled a great stone to the door of the tomb, and departed. For a collection of other versions see [http://bibref.hebtools.com/?book=%20Matthew&verse=27:60&src=! BibRef Matthew 27:60] Joseph of Arimathea places Jesus in his own new tomb, a sign of great loyalty by Joseph. This verse is based on [[Mark 15:46]], and is paralleled by [[Luke 23:53]] and [[John 19:41]]. Matthew is the only gospel writer to mention that it was Joseph's own tomb that Jesus was placed.[[Robert H. Gundry|Gundry, Robert H.]] ''Matthew a Commentary on his Literary and Theological Art.'' Grand Rapids: William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company, 1982. pg. 581 Typically wealthy residents of Jerusalem would have a large family tomb, with space for many burials. The new tomb implies that no one has yet been entombed there, something made explicit in both Luke and John. Mentioning the newness, and emptiness, of the tomb may also be part of the body of evidence Matthew presents for the truth of the [[resurrection of Jesus|resurrection]]. A new tomb with only one body would prevent any confusion.[[R. T. France|France, R.T.]]. ''The Gospel of Matthew.'' Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing, 2007 pg. 1090 Davies and Allison note that reference to the newness of the tomb might also be an allusion to the newness that emerges from it with the resurrection.Davies, W.D. and Dale C. Allison, Jr. ''A Critical and Exegetical Commentary on the Gospel According to Saint Matthew''. Edinburgh : T. & T. Clark, 1988-1997. The newness of the tomb may also reflect that Joseph's wealth is new found, or that his family is newly arrived in Jerusalem. This could explain why he has a tomb in Jerusalem rather than his native Arimathea.Keener, Craig S. ''The Gospel of Matthew: A Socio-Rhetorical Commentary.'' Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing, 2009. pg. 694 The description of the rock hewn tomb is fully in keeping with archeological evidence from the period. [[Jerusalem]] was surrounded by soft limestone rock that was perforated by natural and artificial caves, creating a giant natural cemetery.Harrington, Daniel J. ''The Gospel of Matthew.'' Liturgical Press, 1991 pg. 405 The door also matches examples from this period. Most tombs would have a smaller stone able to keep out animals. More expensive tombs would have a stone large enough to keep out grave robbers. This and other verses make clear that a larger stone is in place.Davies, W.D. and Dale C. Allison, Jr. ''A Critical and Exegetical Commentary on the Gospel According to Saint Matthew''. Edinburgh : T.& T. Clark, 1988-1997. Joseph departs, not to be seen again in Matthew's narrative. Davies and Allison note that Matthew frequently treats his minor characters in this manner, giving no unnecessary details.Davies, W.D. and Dale C. Allison, Jr. ''A Critical and Exegetical Commentary on the Gospel According to Saint Matthew''. Edinburgh : T. & T. Clark, 1988-1997. Joseph leaving is in the next verses contrasted with the women who remain and the guards who later arrive.[[R. T. France|France, R.T.]]. ''The Gospel of Matthew.'' Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing, 2007 pg. 1090 His departure is not mentioned in any of the other gospels, but Matthew adds the story of the guards arriving, so that could explain adding a mention of Joseph leaving.[[Robert H. Gundry|Gundry, Robert H.]] ''Matthew a Commentary on his Literary and Theological Art.'' Grand Rapids: William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company, 1982. pg. 582 ==References== {{reflist}} {{sequence | prev = [[Matthew 27:59]] | list = [[Gospel of Matthew]]
[[Matthew 27|Chapter 27]] | next = [[Matthew 27:61]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Matthew 27:60}} {{Matthew 27}} [[Category:Matthew 27|27:60]] [[Category:Entombment of Christ|27:60]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Use Indian English|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = National Youth Day |type = national |image = Swami Vivekananda 1896.jpg |imagesize = 200px |caption = |official_name = |observedby = {{IND}} |litcolor = |longtype = |significance = Birthday of [[Swami Vivekananda]] |begins = 1984http://www.odisha.gov.in/portal/LIWPL/event_archive/Events_Archives/32National_Youth_Day.pdf |date = 12 January |duration = 1 day |frequency = Annual |scheduling = Same day each year |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = }} '''National Youth Day''' is celebrated in [[India]] on 12 January on the birthday of [[Swami Vivekananda]]. In 1984 the Government of India declared the day as the National Youth Day and since 1985 the event is celebrated in India every year. == History == It was a great decision of Government of India taken in the year, 1984 to celebrate the birthday of great Swami Vivekananda i.e. 12th January as a National Youth Day every year. As the Government of India had quoted and realized that ' the philosophy of Swamiji and the ideals for which he lived and worked could be a great source of inspiration for the Indian Youth.'{{cite web|title=National Youth Day|url=http://www.belurmath.org/national_youth_day.htm|work=National Youth Day 12th January|accessdate=6 October 2011}} On 12 January 2013, Former Indian Prime Minister [[Manmohan Singh]] told in his address at the inauguration of four-year-long celebrations of Swami Vivekananda's 150th birth anniversary— {{cite web|title=PM's address at the Inauguration of four Year Long Celebrations of Swami Vivekananda's 150th Birth Anniversary |url=http://pmindia.gov.in/speech-details.php?nodeid=972 |publisher=Indian Government |accessdate=1 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120816022843/http://pmindia.gov.in/speech-details.php?nodeid=972 |archivedate=16 August 2012 |df= }}
What Gandhiji said captures the great importance of spreading Swami Vivekananda's ideas and ideals among the youth in our country today. He personified the eternal energy of the youth and their restless quest for truth. It is entirely fitting that the Government of India has declared 12th January, the birthday of Swami Vivekananda, as National Youth Day. We must work to rekindle the eternal message of this great patriot and son of India.
== Celebration and activities == The National Youth Day is observed all over India at schools and colleges, with processions, speeches, recitations, music, youth conventions, seminars, Yogasanas, presentations, competitions in essay-writing, recitations and sports on 12 January every year. Swami Vivekananda's lectures and writings, deriving their inspiration from Indian spiritual tradition and the broad outlook of his Master Sri Ramakrishna Paramahansa, are the source of inspiration and have motivated numerous youth organizations, study circles and service projects involving the youth.{{cite web|title=National Youth Day, India|url=http://india.gov.in/allimpfrms/alldocs/2539.pdf|work=National Youth Day|accessdate=6 October 2011|date=12 January 2009}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.indiacelebrating.com/events/national-youth-day/ National Youth Day] *[http://www.belurmath.org/national_youth_day.htm National Youth Day at Belur Math] {{Swami Vivekananda|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Festivals in India]] [[Category:January observances]] [[Category:Observances in India]] [[Category:Memorials to Swami Vivekananda]] [[Category:Youth in India]] [[Category:Annual events in India]] [[Category:Youth events]] [[Category:1985 establishments in India]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1985]]

'''Newborn care and safety''' are the activities and precautions recommended for new parents or caregivers. It is also an educational goal of many hospital and birthing centers when it's time to bring their [[infant]] home.<ref name = NIH2017>{{cite web|url=https://www.womenshealth.gov/pregnancy/childbirth-and-beyond/newborn-care-and-safety|title=Newborn care and safety - womenshealth.gov|website=womenshealth.gov}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
==Newborn care== Taking a newborn care class during [[pregnancy]] can prepare caregivers for the real thing. But feeding and [[diaper]]ing a baby doll isn't quite the same. During the stay in a hospital or birthing center, clinicians and nurses help with basic baby care. These health providers will demonstrate basic infant care. Newborn care basics include:
* Handling a newborn, including supporting the baby's neck * Changing diapers * Bathing * Dressing * Swaddling * Feeding and burping * Cleaning the umbilical cord * Caring for a healing circumcision * Using a bulb syringe to clear the baby's nasal passages * Taking a newborn's temperature * Tips for soothing the baby<ref name = NIH2017/>
Before leaving the hospital, ask about home visits by a nurse or health care worker. Many new parents appreciate somebody checking in with them and their baby a few days after coming home. If breastfeeding, a mother can ask whether a lactation consultant visit in the home to provide follow-up support, as well as providing other resources in the community, such as peer support groups.<ref name = NIH2017/>
Many first-time parents also welcome the help of a family member or friend who has "been there." Having a support person stay with the newborn for a few days can give the mother the confidence to go at it alone in the weeks ahead. This can be to arranged before delivery.<ref name = NIH2017/>
The baby's first doctor's visit is another good time to ask about any infant care questions. Parents can ask about reasons to call the doctor and about what vaccines baby needs and when. Young children need vaccines because the diseases they protect against can strike at an early age and can be very dangerous in childhood. This includes rare diseases and more common ones, such as the flu.<ref name = NIH2017/>
Caring for a newborn also includes the health screening of the newborn, most of the times this occurs in the hospital or pediatrician's office shortly after birth. Every state screens babies for more than two dozen disorders. Early detection can help treat the disorder.<ref>https://www2c.cdc.gov/podcasts/player.asp?f=8629632</ref>
==Safe nutrition== {{Main|Infant food safety}} Handwashing helps to prevent the spread of foodborne illnesses to children. Pathogenic microorganisms can be transmitted from other children and their [[diapers]], and from uncooked meat, [[seafood]], [[poultry egg|eggs]], dogs, [[feline zoonosis|cats]], [[turtles]], [[snakes]], [[birds]], [[lizards]], and soil.<ref name = FDA2017>{{cite web|url=https://www.fda.gov/Food/ResourcesForYou/HealthEducators/ucm089629.htm|title=Health Educators - Food Safety for Moms to Be: Once Baby Arrives|first=Center for Food Safety and Applied|last=Nutrition|website=www.fda.gov|accessdate=25 July 2017}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
==Sudden infant death syndrome== {{Main | Sudden infant death syndrome}}
Since 1992, the American Academy of Pediatrics has recommended that infants be placed to sleep on their backs to reduce the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS), also called crib death. SIDS is the sudden and unexplained death of a baby under 1 year of age. Even though there is no way to know which babies might die of SIDS, recommendations include:
* Always place the baby on his or her back to sleep, even for naps. This is the safest sleep position for a healthy baby to reduce the risk of SIDS. * Place the baby on a firm mattress, such as in a safety-approved crib. Research has shown that placing a baby to sleep on soft mattresses, sofas, sofa cushions, waterbeds, sheepskins, or other soft surfaces raises the risk of SIDS. * Remove soft, fluffy, and loose bedding and stuffed toys from the baby's sleep area. Make sure all pillows, quilts, stuffed toys, and other soft items are kept away from the baby's sleep area. * Do not use infant sleep positioners. Using a positioner to hold an infant on his or her back or side for sleep is dangerous and not needed. * Make sure everyone who cares for the baby knows to place the baby on his or her back to sleep and about the dangers of soft bedding. Talk to child care providers, grandparents, babysitters, and all caregivers about SIDS risk. Remember, every sleep time counts. * Make sure the baby's face and head stay uncovered during sleep. Keep blankets and other coverings away from the baby's mouth and nose. The best way to do this is to dress the baby in sleep clothing so there will not have to use any other covering over the baby. If using a blanket or another covering, make sure that the baby's feet are at the bottom of the crib, the blanket is no higher than the baby's chest, and the blanket is tucked in around the bottom of the crib mattress. * Do not allow smoking around the baby. Don't smoke before or after the birth of the baby and make sure no one smokes around the baby. * Don't let the baby get too warm during sleep. Keep the baby warm during sleep, but not too warm. The baby's room should be at a temperature that is comfortable for an adult. Too many layers of clothing or blankets can overheat the baby.<ref name = NIH2017/> Some mothers worry if the baby rolls over during the night. However, by the time the baby is able to roll over by herself, the risk for SIDS is much lower. During the time of greatest risk, 2 to 4 months of age, most babies are not able to turn over from their backs to their stomachs.<ref name = NIH2017/>
==Car seats== {{Main | Child safety seat}} [[File:Rear facing car seat image from the CDC.png|thumb |100px|Rear facing car seat]] Newborns and older infants are to use rear-facing car seats. These are required until age 2 or when they reach the upper weight or height limit of that seat. After this, a forward-facing car seat is used.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/features/passengersafety/ingofraphic.html|title=CDC Features - Child Passenger Safety|website=www.cdc.gov|accessdate=26 July 2017}}{{PD-notice}}</ref> Motor vehicle crashes are a leading cause of death for children in the US. Buckling up is the best way to save lives and reduce injuries. Child passenger restraint laws result in more children being buckled up. Only 2 out of every 100 children live in states that require car seat or booster seat use for newborns and infants. A third of children who died in crashes in 2011 were not buckled up. Caregivers promote the safety their newborns by: Knowing how to use car seats, booster seats, and seat belts and using them on every trip, no matter how short.<ref>https://www.cdc.gov/vitalsigns/childpassengersafety/</ref>

[[File:Rupert Murdoch - WEF Davos 2007.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Rupert Murdoch]], chairman and chief executive officer of [[News Corporation]], the parent company of [[News International]]]] The '''News International phone-hacking scandal''' was a controversy involving the now defunct ''[[News of the World]]'' and other British newspapers published by [[News International]], a subsidiary of [[News Corporation]]. Employees of the newspaper were accused of engaging in [[phone hacking]], police bribery, and exercising improper influence in the pursuit of stories. Whilst investigations conducted from 2005 to 2007 appeared to show that the paper's phone hacking activities were limited to celebrities, politicians, and members of the [[British Royal Family]], in July 2011 it was revealed that the phones of murdered schoolgirl [[Murder of Milly Dowler|Milly Dowler]], relatives of deceased British soldiers, and victims of the [[7 July 2005 London bombings]] had also been hacked. The resulting public outcry against News Corporation and its owner [[Rupert Murdoch]] led to several high-profile resignations, including that of Murdoch as News Corporation director, Murdoch's son [[James Murdoch|James]] as executive chairman, [[Dow Jones]] chief executive [[Les Hinton]], News International legal manager [[Tom Crone]], and chief executive [[Rebekah Brooks]]. The [[Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis|commissioner]] of London's [[Metropolitan Police Service]] (MPS), [[Paul Stephenson (police officer)|Sir Paul Stephenson]], also resigned. Advertiser boycotts led to the closure of the ''News of the World'' on 10 July 2011, after 168 years of publication.<ref name=bbctimeline>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14124020 |title=Phone-hacking scandal: Timeline |publisher=BBC News |date=12 July 2011 |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref> Public pressure shortly forced News Corporation to cancel its proposed takeover of the British satellite broadcaster [[BSkyB]].
The prime minister [[David Cameron]] announced on 6 July 2011 that a public inquiry, known as the [[Leveson Inquiry]], would look into phone hacking and police bribery by the ''News of the World'', consider the wider culture and ethics of the British newspaper industry and that the [[Press Complaints Commission]] would be replaced "entirely".<ref name=bbctimeline/><ref name="telegraph1">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8634757/Phone-hacking-David-Cameron-announces-terms-of-phone-hacking-inquiry.html|title=Phone hacking: David Cameron announces terms of phone-hacking inquiry|accessdate=13 July 2011|work=The Telegraph|date=13 July 2011|location=London}}</ref> A number of arrests and convictions followed, most notably of the former ''News of the World'' managing editor [[Andy Coulson]].
Murdoch and his son, [[James Murdoch|James]], were summoned to give evidence at the [[Leveson Inquiry]]. Over the course of his testimony, Rupert Murdoch admitted that a cover-up had taken place within the ''News of the World'' to hide the scope of the phone hacking.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/27/world/europe/rupert-murdoch-testimony-leveson-inquiry-day-2.html?_r=2&hp At British Inquiry, Murdoch Apologizes Over Scandal], ''The New York Times'', 26 April 2012.</ref> On 1 May 2012, a parliamentary select committee report concluded that Murdoch "exhibited wilful blindness to what was going on in his companies and publications" and stated that he was "not a fit person to exercise the stewardship of a major international company".<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/02/world/europe/murdoch-hacking-scandal-to-be-examined-by-british-parliamentary-panel.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1&hp British Panel Finds Murdoch Unfit to Lead Media Empire], ''The New York Times'', 1 May 2012.</ref> On 3 July 2013, [[Channel 4 News]] broadcast a secret tape in which Murdoch dismissively claims that investigators were "totally incompetent" and acted over "next to nothing" and excuses his papers' actions as "part of the culture of [[Fleet Street]]".<ref>[http://www.channel4.com/news/murdoch-rupert-tape-police-the-sun-journalists Revealed: The Rupert Murdoch Tape], Channel 4 News, 3 July 2013.</ref>
==Early investigations, 1990s–2005== By 2002, an organised trade in confidential personal information had developed in Britain and was widely used by the British newspaper industry.<ref name=WhatPricePrivacy/><ref name=GuardianRees20020921a>{{cite news|last=McLagan|first=Graeme|title=Fraudster squad |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/sep/21/privacy2|accessdate=28 August 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=21 September 2011}}</ref> Illegal means of gaining information used included hacking the private voicemail accounts on mobile phones, hacking into computers, making false statements to officials, entrapment, blackmail, burglaries, theft of mobile phones and making payments to public officials.<ref name=NYTimesMcMullan201111>{{cite news|last=Lyall|first=Sarah|title=British Inquiry Is Told Hacking Is Worthy Tool|newspaper=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/30/world/europe/british-hacking-scandal-widens-to-government-secrets.html?pagewanted=all|date=29 November 2011|accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="channel4.com">{{cite news|title=Undercover at the News of the World|newspaper=Channel 4|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/undercover-at-the-news-of-the-world/episode-guide/series-1/episode-1|date=2 August 2012|accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref><ref name=GuardianFallon20120803>{{cite news|last=O'Carroll|first=Lisa|title=Kieren Fallon says he felt suicidal over News of the World sting|newspaper=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/aug/03/kieren-fallon-suicidal-news-of-the-world-sting|date=3 August 2012|accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref><ref name=DaviesRees20110609>{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Nick|title=The NoW’s merchant of secrets|url=http://www.nickdavies.net/2011/07/08/the-nows-merchant-of-secrets/|accessdate=19 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=9 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="Somaiya">{{cite news|last=Somaiya|first=Ravi|title=Murdoch Inquiry Extends to Cellphone Theft|newspaper=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/24/world/europe/murdoch-probe-extends-to-cellphone-theft.html?hp|date=23 July 2012|accessdate=23 July 2012}}</ref>
===Operation Nigeria=== Private investigators who were illegally providing information to the ''News of the World'' were also engaged in a variety of other illegal activities. Between 1999 and 2003, [[List of persons arrested in phone-hacking scandal|several were convicted]] for crimes including drug distribution, the theft of drugs, child pornography, planting evidence, corruption, and perverting the course of justice. [[Jonathan Rees]] and his partner Sid Fillery, a former police officer, were also under suspicion for the murder of private investigator [[Daniel Morgan (private investigator)|Daniel Morgan]]. The MPS undertook an investigation of Rees, entitled [[Metropolitan Police role in the News International phone hacking scandal#Operation Nigeria (1999)|Operation Nigeria]], and tapped his telephone. Substantial evidence was accumulated that Rees was purchasing information from improper sources and that, amongst others, Alex Marunchak of the ''[[News of the World]]'' was paying him up to £150,000 a year for doing so.<ref name=GuardianRees20110311/> [[Jonathan Rees]] reportedly bought information from former and serving police officers, Customs officers, a VAT inspector, bank employees, burglars, and from blaggers who would telephone the Inland Revenue, the [[Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency|DVLA]], banks and phone companies, and deceive them into releasing confidential information.<ref name=DaviesRees20110609/> Rees then sold the information to the ''[[News of the World]]'', the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'', the ''[[Sunday Mirror]]'' and the ''[[Sunday Times]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Sam|title=Blagging – the dark art of the men Gordon Brown calls 'known criminals'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/12/blagging-dark-art-gordon-brown|accessdate=18 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=12 July 2011}}</ref>
The Operation Nigeria bugging ended in September 1999 and Rees was arrested when he was heard planning to plant drugs on a woman so that her husband could win custody of their child.<ref name=GuardianRees20110311/><ref name=GuardianRees20020921b>{{cite news|last=McLagan|first=Graeme|title=Journalists caught on tape in police bugging|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/sep/21/privacy|accessdate=29 August 2011|newspaper=The Guaradian|date=21 September 2011}}</ref> Rees was convicted in 2000 and served a five-year prison sentence.<ref name=GuardianRees20110311>{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Nick|title=Jonathan Rees: private investigator who ran empire of tabloid corruption|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/mar/11/jonathan-rees-private-investigator-tabloid|accessdate=18 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=11 March 2011}}</ref><ref name=GuardianRees20110608>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jun/08/phone-hacking-scandal-jonathan-rees |title=Phone-hacking scandal: Jonathan Rees obtained information using dark arts |author=Davies, Nick |work=The Guardian |date=8 June 2011 |accessdate=14 August 2011 }}</ref> Other individuals associated with Rees who were taped during Operation Nigeria, including Detective Constable Austin Warnes, former detective Duncan Hanrahan, former Detective Constable Martin King and former Detective Constable Tom Kingston, were prosecuted and jailed for various offences unrelated to phone hacking.<ref name=GuardianRees20110311/><ref name=GuardianRees20020921b/><ref name="HackAttack"/>
In June 2002, Fillery had reportedly used his relationship with Alex Marunchak to arrange for private investigator [[Glenn Mulcaire]], then doing work for ''News of the World'', to obtain confidential information about Detective Chief Superintendent David Cook, one of the police officers investigating the murder of [[Daniel Morgan (private investigator)|Daniel Morgan]]. Mulcaire obtained Cook's home address, his internal Metropolitan police payroll number, his date of birth and figures for his mortgage payments as well as physically following him and his family. Attempts to access Cook's voicemail and that of his wife, and possibly hack his computer and intercept his post were also suspected.<ref name=GuardianCook20110706/> Documents reportedly held by Scotland Yard show that "Mulcaire did this on the instructions of [[Greg Miskiw]], assistant editor at ''News of the World'' and a close friend of Marunchak." The Metropolitan Police Service handled this apparent attempt by agents of the ''News of the World'' to interfere with a murder inquiry by having informal discussions with [[Rebekah Brooks]], then editor for the newspaper. "Scotland Yard took no further action, apparently reflecting the desire of Dick Fedorcio, Director of Public Affairs and Internal Communication for the Met who had a close working relationship with Brooks, to avoid unnecessary friction with the newspaper."<ref name=GuardianCook20110706/>
No one was charged with illegal acquisition of confidential information as a result of Operation Nigeria, even though the Met reportedly collected hundreds of thousands of incriminating documents during the investigation into Jonathan Rees and his links with corrupt officers.<ref name="GuardianRees20110608xy">{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Nick|title=Phone-hacking scandal widens to include Kate Middleton and Tony Blair|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/jun/08/phone-hacking-kate-middleton-tony-blair|accessdate=20 August 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=8 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="Dodd, Vikram and Sandra Laville">{{cite news|author1=Dodd, Vikram |author2=Sandra Laville |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Scotland Yard in spotlight as axe murder case collapses|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/mar/11/scotland-yard-murder-case-daniel-morgan|accessdate=26 August 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=11 March 2011}}</ref> Fillery was convicted for child pornography offences in 2003.<ref name=GuardianRees20110608/> Upon Rees' release from prison in 2005, he immediately resumed his investigative work for the ''News of the World'', where [[Andy Coulson]] had succeeded Rebekah Brooks as editor.
===Operation Motorman=== In 2002, under the title [[Operation Motorman (ICO investigation)|Operation Motorman]], the [[Information Commissioner's Office]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ico.gov.uk/ |title=Information Commissioner's Office |work=Information Commissioner's Office Website |publisher=Information Commissioner's Office |accessdate=23 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120920050609/http://www.ico.gov.uk/ |archivedate=20 September 2012 |df= }}</ref> raided the offices of various newspaper and private investigators, looking for details of personal information kept on unregistered computer databases. The operation uncovered numerous invoices addressed to newspapers and magazines, which detailed prices for the provision of personal information. 305 journalists, working for at least 30 publications, were identified as purchasing confidential information from private investigators.<ref name=WhatPricePrivacy>{{cite web|title=What Price Privacy?|url=http://www.ico.gov.uk/~/media/documents/library/Corporate/Research_and_reports/WHAT_PRICE_PRIVACY.ashx|publisher=Information Commissioner's Office|date=10 May 2006|accessdate=20 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110829133733/http://www.ico.gov.uk/~/media/documents/library/Corporate/Research_and_reports/WHAT_PRICE_PRIVACY.ashx|archivedate=29 August 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=PG36439/> The ICO raided a private investigator named John Boyall, whose specialty was acquiring information from confidential databases. [[Glenn Mulcaire]] had been Boyall's assistant, until the autumn of 2001 when the ''News of the World's'' assistant editor, [[Greg Miskiw]] gave him a full-time contract to do work for the newspaper.<ref name=GuardianRees20110311/> When the ICO raided Boyall's premises in November 2002 they seized documents that led them to the premises of another private investigator, Steve Whittamore.<ref name=WhatPricePrivacyNow>{{cite news|title=What Price Privacy Now?|url=http://www.ico.gov.uk/news/current_topics/what_price_privacy_now.aspx|accessdate=20 August 2011|newspaper=Information Commissioner's Office|date=December 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817034810/http://www.ico.gov.uk/news/current_topics/what_price_privacy_now.aspx|archivedate=17 August 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="GuardianMotorman20090830"/> There they found "more than 13,000 requests for confidential information from newspapers and magazines."<ref name=GuardianRees20110311/><ref name=GuardianCook20110706>{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Nick|title=News of the World surveillance of detective: what Rebekah Brooks knew|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/06/news-of-the-world-rebekah-brooks|accessdate=27 August 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=6 July 2011}}</ref> This established that confidential information was illegally acquired from telephone companies, the [[Driver & Vehicle Licensing Agency]] and the [[Police National Computer]]. "Media, especially newspapers, insurance companies and local authorities chasing council tax arrears all appear in the sales ledger" of the agency.<ref name=WhatPricePrivacyNow/> Whittamore's network gave him access to confidential records at telephone companies, banks, post offices, hotels, theatres, and prisons, including [[BT Group]], [[Crédit Lyonnais]], [[Goldman Sachs]], [[Hang Seng Bank]], [[Glen Parva (HM Prison)|Glen Parva prison]], and [[Stocken (HM Prison)|Stocken prison]].<ref name=GuardianMotorman20090830>{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Nick|title=Operation Motorman: the full story revealed|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/aug/31/press-privacy-information-commmissioner|accessdate=21 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=30 August 2009}}</ref>
Although the ICO issued two reports, "What price privacy?" in May 2006 and "What price privacy now?" in December 2006, much of the information obtained through Operation Motorman was not made public.<ref name=WhatPricePrivacyNow/><ref>{{cite web|title=Background information from "What Price Privacy?" report|url=http://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/background_information_from_what|work=What Do They Know.com- Make and explore Freedom of Information requests|publisher=What Do They Know.com|accessdate=10 October 2011}}</ref> Although there was evidence of many people being engaged in illegal activity, relatively few were questioned. Operation Motorman's lead investigator said in 2006 that "his team were told not to interview journalists involved. The investigator...accused authorities of being too 'frightened' to tackle journalists."<ref name=GuardianHenry20110914>{{cite news|last=Robinson, James and Ed Pilkington|title=Phone hacking: 7/7 disaster victim's mother to sue NoW publisher|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/sep/13/phone-hacking-disaster-victim-sues|accessdate=15 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=14 September 2011}}</ref> The newspaper with the highest number of requests was the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' with 952 transactions by 58 journalists; the ''News of the World'' came fifth in the table, with 182 transactions from 19 journalists.<ref name=PG36439/> The ''Daily Mail'' rejected the accusations within the report insisting it only used private investigators to confirm public information, such as dates of birth.<ref name=PG36439>{{cite web|url=http://businesstelephonequoter.co.uk/info-chiefs-broadside-press-data-crimes/|title=Info Chief's broadside at Press over data crimes|work=Press Gazette|date=15 December 2006|accessdate=18 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140523230441/http://businesstelephonequoter.co.uk/info-chiefs-broadside-press-data-crimes/|archivedate=23 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Operation Glade=== Learning that Steve Whittamore was obtaining information from the police national computer, the Information Commissioner contacted the Metropolitan Police and the Met's anti-corruption unit initiated [[Metropolitan Police role in the News International phone hacking scandal#Operation Glade (2003)|Operation Glade]].<ref name=GuardianRees20110311/> Whittamore's detailed records identified 27 different journalists as having commissioned him to acquire confidential information for which they paid him tens of thousands of pounds. Invoices submitted to [[News International]] "sometimes made explicit reference to obtaining a target's details from their phone number or their vehicle registration."<ref name=GuardianMotorman20090830/> Between February 2004 and April 2005, the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] charged ten men working for private detective agencies with crimes relating to the illegal acquisition of confidential information.<ref name=GuardianRees20110311/><ref name=GuardianGuilty20050416/><ref name="PressGazetteGunning20050422">{{cite news|last=Watts|first=Mark|title=Private eyes charged with breaking data law in search of news scoops|url=http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=30261&sectioncode=1|accessdate=23 September 2011|newspaper=PressGazette|date=22 April 2005|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130114020546/http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=30261&sectioncode=1|archivedate=14 January 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> No journalists were charged.<ref name="PressGazetteGunning20050422"/> Whittamore, Boyall, and two others pleaded guilty in April 2005. According to ICO head [[Richard Thomas (lawyer)|Richard Thomas]], "each pleaded guilty yet, despite the extent and the frequency of their admitted criminality, each was conditionally discharged [for two years], raising important questions for public policy."<ref name=GuardianRees20110311/><ref name=WhatPricePrivacyNow/>
==2005–2006: Royal phone hacking scandal== {{Main article|News of the World royal phone hacking scandal}}
On 14 November 2005, the ''[[News of the World]]'' published an article written by royal editor [[Clive Goodman]], claiming that [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]] was in the process of borrowing a portable editing suite from [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] correspondent [[Tom Bradby]]. Following the publication, the Prince and Bradby met to try to figure out how the details of their arrangement had been leaked, as only two other people were aware of it. Prince William noted that another equally improbable leak had recently taken place regarding an appointment he had made with a knee surgeon.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-399814/Moment-Prince-William-discovered-voicemail-scam.html |title=Moment Prince William discovered 'voicemail scam' |work=Daily Mail |location=UK |date=9 August 2006 |accessdate=5 April 2010 }}</ref> The Prince and Bradby concluded it was likely that their voicemails were being accessed.<ref>{{cite news|author=Julia Day |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/aug/09/royalsandthemedia.themonarchy |title=Phone tap investigation widens |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date= 9 August 2006|accessdate=5 April 2010 }}</ref>
The [[Metropolitan Police]] set up an investigation under Deputy Assistant Commissioner [[Peter Clarke (police officer)|Peter Clarke]] reporting to Assistant Commissioner [[Andy Hayman]], commander of the [[Specialist Operations]] directorate, which included royal protection.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/jul/29/july7.duncancampbell|title=The Guardian profile: Peter Clarke|author=Campbell, Duncan | author2 = Cowan, Rosie|date=29 July 2005|work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=8 February 2010}}</ref><ref name=guardian040410>Nick Davies. [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/apr/04/police-ignored-news-world-evidence "Police 'ignored News of the World phone hacking evidence'"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. 4 April 2010.</ref> By January 2006 Clarke's team had concluded that the compromised voice mail accounts belonged to Prince William's aides, not the Prince himself, and that there was an "unambiguous trail" to [[Clive Goodman]], the ''News of the World'' royal reporter, and to [[Glenn Mulcaire]], a private investigator.<ref name=BBC6301243/> The detectives put Goodman and Mulcaire under surveillance and, on 8 August 2006, searched Goodman's desk at the ''News of the World'' and raided Mulcaire's home. There they seized "11,000 pages of handwritten notes listing nearly 4,000 celebrities, politicians, sports stars, police officials and crime victims whose phones may have been hacked."<ref name=GuardianCorrupt20110707>{{cite news|author1=Laville, Sandra |author2=Vikram Dodd |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Phone hacking: the hunt for corrupt officers and 4,000 possible victims|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/07/phone-hacking-hunt-officers-victims|accessdate=17 July 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=7 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=NYTimesScotlandYard20110716>{{cite news|last=Van Natta|first=Don Jr.|title=Stain From Tabloids Rubs Off on a Cozy Scotland Yard|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/17/world/europe/17police.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all|accessdate=17 September 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=16 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=NYTimesRoyals20100901/> The names included eight members of the royal family and their staff.<ref name=NYTimesScotlandYard20110716/> There were dozens of notebooks, two computers containing 2,978 complete or partial mobile phone numbers and 91 PIN codes, plus 30 tape recordings made by Mulcaire. Significantly, there were at least three names of ''News of the World'' journalists other than Goodman and a recording of Mulcaire instructing a journalist how to hack into private voice mail.<ref name=NYTimesScotlandYard20110716/><ref name=NYTimesRoyals20100901/> All this material was taken to Scotland Yard.
In August 2006, Goodman and Mulcaire were arrested by the Metropolitan Police, and later charged with hacking the telephones of members of the royal family by accessing voicemail messages, an offence under section 79 of the [[Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4778159.stm |title=Two charged in 'phone-tap' probe |publisher=BBC News |date=9 August 2006 |accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref> The ''News of the World'' had paid Mulcaire £104,988 for his services. In addition, Goodman had paid Mulcaire £12,300 in cash between 9 November 2005 and 7 August 2006, using the code name Alexander on his expenses sheet for him.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/jan/26/newsoftheworld.pressandpublishing1|title=Clive Goodman sentenced to four months|author=Chris Tryhorn|work=The Guardian |location=UK|date=26 January 2007|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref> The court heard that Mulcaire had also hacked into the messages of supermodel [[Elle Macpherson]], publicist [[Max Clifford]], MP [[Simon Hughes]], football agent [[Sky Andrew]], and [[Gordon Taylor (footballer)|Gordon Taylor]].<ref name=BBC6301243>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6301243.stm |title= Pair jailed over royal phone taps |publisher=BBC News |date=26 January 2007 |accessdate=5 April 2010}}</ref> On 26 January 2007, both Goodman and Mulcaire pleaded guilty to the charges and were sentenced to four and six months imprisonment respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6301243.stm |title= Pair jailed over royal phone taps |publisher=BBC News |date=26 January 2007 |accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref> On the same day, [[Andy Coulson]] resigned as editor of the ''News of the World'', while insisting that he had no knowledge of any illegal activities. In March 2007, a senior aide to Rupert Murdoch told a parliamentary committee that a "rigorous internal investigation" found no evidence of widespread hacking at the ''News of the World''.
After Goodman and Mulcaire pleaded guilty, a [[breach of privacy]] claim was started by Gordon Taylor, chief executive of the [[Professional Footballers Association]] who was represented by his solicitor Mark Lewis.<ref name=timesofisrael-20170412>{{cite news |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/uks-foremost-libel-lawyer-sets-his-sights-on-israels-enemies/ |title=UK's foremost libel lawyer sets his sights on Israel's enemies |last=Frazer |first=Jenni |newspaper=The Times of Israel |date=12 April 2017 |accessdate=6 September 2017}}</ref> That claim settled for a payment of £700,000 including legal costs.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/05/magazine/05hacking-t.html?pagewanted=all |title=Tabloid Hack Attack on Royals, and Beyond |author=[[Don Van Natta, Jr.]], [[Jo Becker]], and Graham Bowley |date=1 September 2010 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> James Murdoch agreed the settlement.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jul/21/james-murdoch-gordon-taylor |title=James Murdoch 'agreed with payout to Gordon Taylor for privacy claim' |author=Stephen Brook |date=21 July 2009 |work=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref>
==PCC investigations== The [[Press Complaints Commission]], PCC, is the organisation charged with self-regulation of the newspaper and magazine industry in Britain. The PCC's inquiry into phone hacking in 2007 concluded that the practice should stop but that "there is a legitimate place for the use of subterfuge when there are grounds in the public interest to use it and it is not possible to obtain information through other means."<ref>{{cite news|title=PCC Report on Subterfuge and Newsgathering|url=http://www.pcc.org.uk/assets/218/PCC_subterfuge_report.pdf|accessdate=25 August 2011|publisher=Press Complaints Commission|date=May 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Preston|first=Peter|title=PCC editors failed to sound the phone-hacking alarm|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/feb/06/phone-hacking-press-complaints-commission-comment|accessdate=20 August 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=6 February 2011}}</ref> ''[[News of the World]]'' editor [[Colin Myler]] told the PCC that Goodman's hacking was "aberrational", "a rogue exception" of a single journalist. The PCC opted not to question Andy Coulson on the grounds that he had left the industry, and not to question any other journalist or executive on the paper, apart from Myler, who had no knowledge of what had been going on there before his appointment. The PCC's subsequent report failed to uncover any evidence of any phone hacking by any newspaper beyond that revealed at Goodman's trial.<ref name=GuardianCoulson20090708/>
In 2009 the PCC held another inquiry, to see whether they were misled by the ''[[News of the World]]'' in 2007, and if there was any evidence that phone hacking had taken place since then. It concluded it had not been misled and that there was no evidence of ongoing phone hacking.<ref>{{cite news|title=PCC report on phone message tapping allegations|url=http://www.pcc.org.uk/news/index.html?article=NjAyOA==|accessdate=25 August 2011|publisher=Press Complaints Commission|date=9 November 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902132404/http://pcc.org.uk/news/index.html?article=NjAyOA==|archivedate=2 September 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This report and its conclusions were withdrawn on 6 July 2011, two days after it was revealed that Milly Dowler's phone had been hacked.<ref name="Press Complaints Commission">{{cite news|title=Statement from the PCC on phone hacking following meeting today (6 July 2011) |url=http://www.pcc.org.uk/news/index.html?article=NzI0Mg== |accessdate=25 August 2011 |publisher=Press Complaints Commission |date=6 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910073940/http://www.pcc.org.uk/news/index.html?article=NzI0Mg%3D%3D |archivedate=10 September 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Letter from Baroness Buscombe to John Whittingdale|url=http://www.parliament.uk/documents/commons-committees/culture-media-and-sport/PH21-Baroness-Buscombe-to-Chairman.pdf|accessdate=26 August 2011|publisher=Press Complaints Commission|date=26 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=GuardianVerdicts20100224>{{cite news|last=Robinson|first=James|title=News of the World phone-hacking scandal: the verdicts|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/feb/24/phone-hacking-scandal-mps-verdicts|accessdate=20 August 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=24 February 2010}}</ref>
==2009–2011: Renewed investigations== {{Main article|News of the World phone hacking scandal investigations}} [[File:Trapped underground.jpg|thumb|It was reported that the ''News of the World'' may have hacked the phones of relatives of [[7 July 2005 London bombings|7/7 attack]] victims (survivors pictured aboard one of the bombed Underground trains)]]
After the 2006 conviction of [[Clive Goodman]] and [[Glenn Mulcaire]], and with assurances from ''[[News International]]'', the [[Press Complaints Commission]] and the [[Metropolitan Police Service]] that no one else had been involved in phone hacking, the public perception was that the matter was closed. [[Nick Davies]] and other journalists from ''The Guardian'', and eventually other newspapers, however continued to examine evidence from court cases and use [[Freedom of Information Act 2000]] requests to find evidence to the contrary.<ref name=GuardianRusbridger20110717>{{cite news | author =Rusbridger, Alan| title =How We Broke the Murdoch Scandal -Guardian editor Alan Rusbridger on his dogged reporter, a U.S Ally—and a gamble that finally paid off.| work =The Daily Beast| date =17 July 2011| url =http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2011/07/17/how-the-guardian-broke-the-news-of-the-world-hacking-scandal.html| accessdate =7 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Correspondence Between The New York Times and Scotland Yard|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2011/07/17/world/europe/20110717police-correspondence.html|accessdate=14 October 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=16 July 2011}}</ref>
===The ''Guardian'' July 2009 reports=== A small number of victims of phone hacking engaged solicitors and made civil claims for invasion of privacy. By March 2010, News International had spent over £2 million settling court cases with victims of phone hacking. As information about these claims leaked out, ''[[The Guardian]]'' continued to follow the story. On 8 & 9 July 2009, the newspaper published three articles alleging that: * [[News Group Newspapers]], NGN, a subsidiary of [[News International]], agreed to large settlements with hacking victims, including [[Gordon Taylor (footballer)|Gordon Taylor]]. The settlements included gagging provisions to prevent release of evidence that NGN journalists had used criminal methods to get stories. "News Group then persuaded the court to seal the file on Taylor's case to prevent all public access, even though it contained prima facie evidence of criminal activity."<ref name=GuardianGag20090708>{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Nick|title=Murdoch papers paid £1m to gag phone-hacking victims|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jul/08/murdoch-papers-phone-hacking|accessdate=23 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=8 July 2009}}</ref> That evidence included documents seized in raids by the [[Information Commissioner's Office]] as well as by the Met.<ref name=GuardianCoulson20090708>{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Nick|title=Trail of hacking and deceit under nose of Tory PR chief|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jul/08/murdoch-newspapers-phone-hacking|accessdate=23 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=8 July 2011}}</ref> * If the suppressed evidence became public, hundreds more phone hacking victims might be able to take legal action against [[News International]] newspapers and might lead to police inquiries being re-opened.<ref name=GuardianGag20090708/> * When [[Andy Coulson]] was editor of the ''[[News of the World]]'', journalists there openly engaged private investigators for illegal phone hacking and raised invoices that itemised illegal acts.<ref name=GuardianCoulson20090708/> * Everybody at the ''News of the World'' knew what was going on and knew that there was no public interest defense for phone hacking. The way investigations had been pursued raised serious questions about the Metropolitan Police, the Crown Prosecution Service, and the courts which, "faced with evidence of conspiracy and systemic illegal actions,...agreed to seal the evidence." rather than make it public.<ref name=GuardianNeil20090708>{{cite news|last=Dodd|first=Vikram|title=Ex-Murdoch editor Andrew Neil: News of the World revelations one of most significant media stories of our time|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jul/09/andrew-neil-murdoch-andy-coulson|accessdate=24 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=8 July 2009}}</ref> * The Met held evidence that thousands of mobile phones had been hacked into by agents of the ''News of the World'' and that Members of Parliament, including cabinet ministers, were among the victims.<ref name=GuardianGag20090708/> * "The Metropolitan Police took the decision not to inform all the individuals whose phones had been targeted and the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] decided not to take News Group executives to court."<ref name=GuardianCoulson20090708/> * News International executives had misled a Parliamentary select committee, the [[Press Complaints Commission]] and the public about the extent of their newspaper's illegal activities.<ref name=GuardianGag20090708/>
===Scotland Yard's response=== When the ''Guardian'' articles were published, [[Metropolitan Police Service]] Commissioner [[Paul Stephenson (police officer)|Sir Paul Stephenson]] asked Assistant Commissioner [[John Yates (police officer)|John Yates]] to look at the phone hacking case to see if it should be reopened. Yates reportedly took just eight hours to consult with senior detectives and Crown Prosecution lawyers to conclude there was no fresh material that could lead to further convictions.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Cherry|title=John Yates expresses 'massive regret' over phone hacking investigation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/jul/09/john-yates-massive-regret-phone-hacking-investigation|accessdate=23 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=9 July 2011}}</ref> His review did not include an examination of the thousands of pages of evidence seized in the 2006 Mulcaire raid.<ref name=TelegraphYates20110709>{{cite news|author1=Alasdair Palmer |author2=Robert Mendick |lastauthoramp=yes |title=John Yates: Phone hacking investigation was a 'cock up'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8627599/John-Yates-Phone-hacking-investigation-was-a-cock-up.html|accessdate=23 September 2011|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=9 July 2011}}</ref> In September 2009, Yates maintained his position to the Commons [[Culture, Media and Sport Committee]] saying, "There remain now insufficient grounds or evidence to arrest or interview anyone else and...no additional evidence has come to light."<ref name="ParliamentYates20110902">{{cite news|title=Examination of Witnesses (Question Numbers 1889–1899)-Assistant Commissioner John Yates and Detective Chief Superintendent Philip Williams|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200910/cmselect/cmcumeds/362/9090214.htm|accessdate=27 August 2011|publisher=UK Parliament|date=2 September 2009}}</ref> Upon review of the first inquiry, he concluded that there were "hundreds, not thousands" of potential victims."<ref name=GuardianCorrupt20110707/> Yates told the Committee, "It is very few, it is a handful" of persons that had been subject to hacking.<ref name=ParliamentYates20110902a/> Although Yates was aware of the "Transcript for Neville" email that indicated more than a single rogue reporter was involved, he did not interview [[Neville Thurlbeck]] nor any other journalist at the ''News of the World'', nor look into the cases of victims beyond the eight named in court in 2006.<ref name=ParliamentYates20110902a>{{cite news|title=Examination of Witnesses (Question Numbers 1900–1919)-Assistant Commissioner John Yates and Detective Chief Superintendent Philip Williams|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200910/cmselect/cmcumeds/362/9090215.htm|accessdate=27 August 2011|publisher=UK Parliament|date=2 September 2009}}</ref><ref name=GuardianYates20110127>{{cite news|title=Phone hacking: Transcript of MPs questioning Met police in 2009|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jan/27/transcript-mps-question-police-phone-hacking|accessdate=23 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=27 January 2011}}</ref> The Committee's findings, released in February 2010, were critical of the police for not pursuing "evidence that merited a wider investigation."<ref name=NYTimesRoyals20100901/><ref name=ParliamentCMSC20100209>{{cite web|title=Press standards, privacy and libel- Second Report of Session 2009–10 Volume I Report, together with formal minutes|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200910/.../362/362i.pdf|work=Press standards, privacy and libel|publisher=UK Parliament- Culture, Media and Sport Committee|accessdate=15 October 2011|date=9 February 2010}}</ref>
The Committee Chairman [[John Whittingdale]] also questioned whether the Committee had been misled by several of the News International executives who had testified before it in 2007 that Goodman alone was involved in phone hacking. The Committee again heard evidence from [[Les Hinton]], by then chief executive officer of [[Dow Jones & Company]], and Andy Coulson, by then director of communications for the Conservative Party. Their report concluded that it was "inconceivable" that no one, other than Goodman, knew about the extent of phone hacking at the paper, and that the Committee had "repeatedly encountered an unwillingness to provide the detailed information that we sought, claims of ignorance or lack of recall and deliberate obfuscation".<ref name=ParliamentCMSC20100209/>
Assistant Commissioner Yates returned to the Committee on 24 March 2011 and defended his position that only ten to twelve victims met the criteria given to the police by the [[Crown Prosecution Service]]. The CPS denied that what they had told the Met could be reasonably used to limit the scope of the investigation.<ref>{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Nick|title=Phone hacking: Metropolitan police chief keeps up row with DPP|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/mar/24/phone-hacking-metropolitan-police-dpp|accessdate=17 September 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=24 March 2011}}</ref> Further, they claimed to have been misled by the Met during consultations on the Royal Household inquiry. Met officials reportedly "didn’t discuss certain evidence with senior prosecutors, including the notes suggesting the involvement of other reporters."<ref name=NYTimesRoyals20100901/>
The [[Home Affairs Select Committee]] also questioned Yates in 2009 about the Met's continuing refusal to reopen the investigation "following allegations that 27 other [[News International]] reporters had commissioned private investigators to carry out tasks, some of which might have been illegal." Yates responded that he had only looked into the facts of the original 2006 inquiry into Goodmans activities.<ref name=RegisterTaylor20090715>{{cite news|last=Leyden|first=John|title=MPs shown 'email evidence' of wider NotW snooping alert print tweet'One bad apple' defence wormed into|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2009/07/15/notw_hack_hearings/|accessdate=27 September 2011|newspaper=The Register|date=15 July 2009}}</ref> The Home Affairs Committee began another inquiry on 1 September 2010 and later published a report highly critical of the Met, stating, "The difficulties were offered to us as justifying a failure to investigate further, and we saw nothing that suggested there was a real will to tackle and overcome those obstacles."
''The Guardian'' continued to be critical of Yates, who responded by hiring a firm of libel lawyers, paid for by the Met, to threaten legal action against anyone that claimed he had misled Parliament.<ref name=GuardianRees20110311/><ref name=GuardianYates20110825>{{cite news|last=Laville|first=Sandra|title=Scotland Yard paid John Yates's legal bills|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/aug/25/met-yates-legal-bills|accessdate=25 August 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=25 August 2011}}</ref> Eventually, as celebrities and politicians continued asking if they had been victims of hacking, Yates directed that the evidence from the Mulcaire raid, that had been stored in bin bags for three years, finally be entered into a computer database. Ten people were assigned the task. Yates himself did not look at the evidence saying later, "I’m not going to go down and look at bin bags. I am supposed to be an Assistant Commissioner."<ref name=TelegraphYates20110709/> He did not re-open the investigation.
Days after the settlement with Gordon Taylor was revealed by ''[[The Guardian]]'' in July 2009, [[Max Clifford]], another of the eight victims named in 2006, announced his intentions to sue. In March 2010, [[News International]] agreed to settle his suit for £1,000,000, a much greater than expected settlement if hacking Clifford's phone was the only issue.<ref name=GuardianClifford20100309>{{cite news|author1=Nick Davies |author2=Rob Evans |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Max Clifford drops News of the World phone hacking action in £1m deal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/mar/09/clifford-news-of-the-world-phone-hacking|accessdate=20 August 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=9 March 2010}}</ref> These two awards encouraged other victims to explore legal redress, resulting in more and more phone hacking queries to the Metropolitan Police, which they were often slow to respond to.<ref>{{cite news|last=Martin Hickman|title=Charlotte Harris: Nowhere to hide, says the lawyer on Murdoch's case|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/charlotte-harris-nowhere-to-hide-says-the-lawyer-on-murdochs-case-2269242.html|accessdate=26 September 2011|newspaper=The Independent|date=18 April 2010}}</ref> One commentator observed that "the Goodman-Mulcaire revelations and subsequent prosecution were supposed to have settled the hacking matter forever and might have done just that, except that successful law suits... kept popping up against News of the World after the convictions."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefeministwire.com/2011/07/29/dial-m-for-murdoch-and-mayhem/ |title=Dial M for Murdoch and Mayhem |author=Spillers, Hortense |work=The Feminist Wire |date=29 July 2011 |accessdate=12 August 2011}}</ref>
===The ''Guardian'' December 2010 report=== [[File:The Guardian Building Window in London.JPG|right|thumb|''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper was at the forefront of reporting on the phone hacking scandal.]] On 15 December 2010, ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that some of the documents seized from [[Glenn Mulcaire]] in 2006 by the [[Metropolitan Police Service]] and only recently disclosed in open court, implied that ''[[News of the World]]'' editor [[Ian Edmondson]] specifically instructed Mulcaire to hack voice messages of [[Sienna Miller]], [[Jude Law]], and several others. The documents also implied that Mulcaire was engaged by ''News of the World'' chief reporter [[Neville Thurlbeck]] and assistant editor [[Greg Miskiw]], who had then worked directly for editor [[Andy Coulson]].<ref name=GuardianMiller20101215/> This contradicted testimony to the [[Culture, Media and Sport Committee]] by News International executives and senior Met officials that there was no evidence of hacking by anyone other than Mulcaire and Goodman. Within five weeks of the article appearing, *[[Ian Edmondson]] was suspended from the ''News of the World'',<ref>{{cite news|author1=Robinson, James |author2=Vikram Dodd |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Andy Coulson resignation: Private eye's court claims sealed fate|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jan/21/glenn-mulcaire-edmondson-coulson-resignation|accessdate=21 August 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=21 January 2011}}</ref> *[[Andy Coulson]] resigned as Chief Press Secretary to David Cameron,<ref name=TelegraphCoulson20110121>{{cite news|title=Andy Coulson quits Number 10|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/david-cameron/8274940/Andy-Coulson-quits-Number-10.html|accessdate=20 August 2011|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=21 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="InItTo">{{cite book|author=Matthew D'Ancona|publisher=Penguin Books|year=2014|title=In It Together. The Inside Story of the Coalition Government |ISBN=978 0 670 91995 6}}</ref> *the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] began a review of evidence it had,<ref>{{cite news|last=Washbrook.|first=Cyril|title=UK: Prosecutor orders review of phone-hacking evidence|url=http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/01/15/uk-prosecutor-orders-review-of-phone-hacking-evidence/|accessdate=12 October 2011|newspaper=Media Spy- The Spy Report|date=15 January 2011}}</ref> *the Met renewed its investigation into phone hacking, something it had previously declined to do.<ref name=GuardianMiller20101215>{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Nick|title=Phone hacking approved by top News of the World executive – new files.|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/dec/15/phone-hacking-sienna-miller-evidence|accessdate=11 October 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=15 December 2010}}</ref>
==January–June 2011: Admission of liability==
===Operation Weeting begins=== {{main article|Operation Weeting}} The Metropolitan Police announced on 26 January 2011 that it would begin a new investigation into phone hacking, following the receipt of "significant new information" regarding the conduct of ''News of the World'' employees.<ref name=GuardMacD110719/> Operation Weeting would take place alongside the previously announced review of phone hacking evidence by the Crown Prosecution Service.<ref name="newscotlandyard">{{Cite news | title = News executive sacked, as police begin new phone-hacking probe | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 27 January 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/01/27/uk-news-executive-sacked-as-police-begin-new-phone-hacking-probe/ | accessdate =28 January 2011 }}</ref> Between 45 and 60 officers began looking over the 11,000 pages of evidence seized from Mulcaire in August 2006.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Milmo, Cahal |author2=Martin Hickman |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Freelance reporter held in phone-hacking investigation|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/freelance-reporter-held-in-phonehacking-investigation-2302079.html|accessdate=12 October 2011|newspaper=The Independent|date=24 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Laville|first=Sandra|title=Phone hacking: police make another arrest|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/sep/07/phone-hacking-police-make-arrest|accessdate=17 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=7 September 2011}}</ref>
In June 2011, the issue of computer hacking was addressed with the launch of [[Operation Tuleta]].
Having failed thus far to put the phone hacking issue to rest, [[News International]]'s law firm, Hickman & Rose, hired former [[Director of Public Prosecutions]] [[Ken Macdonald]] to review the emails that News International executives had used as the basis of their claim that no one at the ''[[News of the World]]'' but [[Clive Goodman]] had been involved in phone hacking. Macdonald immediately concluded, regardless of whether others had been involved, that there was clear evidence of criminal activity, including payments to serving police officers. Macdonald arranged for this evidence to be turned over to the Met, which led to their opening in July 2011 of [[Operation Elveden]], an investigation focused on bribery and corruption within the Met's ranks.
The first arrests as part of Operation Weeting were made on 5 April 2011. Ian Edmondson and the ''News of the World''{{'s}} chief reporter [[Neville Thurlbeck]] were arrested on suspicion of unlawfully intercepting voicemail messages.<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/09/world/europe/09hacking.html |work=The New York Times | first=Sarah | last=Lyall | title=British Tabloid Accepts Blame in Cell Hacking | date=8 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="arrests">{{Cite news | title = Police arrest News of the World phone-hacking suspects | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 6 April 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/04/06/uk-police-arrest-news-of-the-world-phone-hacking-suspects/ | accessdate =6 April 2011 }}</ref> Both men had denied participating in illegal activities. The paper's assistant news editor, [[James Weatherup]], was taken into custody for questioning by the Metropolitan Police on 14 April 2011.<ref name="dailymail1">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1376795/Phone-hacking-Third-News-World-journalist-James-Weatherup-arrested.html |title=Phone hacking: Third News of the World journalist James Weatherup arrested |work=Daily Mail |accessdate=16 July 2011 |location=London |date=15 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Amelia Hill |author2= Dan Sabbagh |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/apr/14/phone-hacking-arrest-news-of-world |title=Unexpected arrest in phone-hacking case leaves News of the World stunned |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=16 July 2011 |date=15 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Josh Halliday |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/apr/14/phone-hacking-james-weatherup |title=Phone hacking: who is James Weatherup? |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=14 April 2011 |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Amelia Hill |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/apr/14/news-of-the-world-journalist-arrested |title=Phone hacking: senior News of the World journalist arrested |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=14 April 2011 |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/15/world/europe/15hacking.html |work=The New York Times | first1=Ravi | last1=Somaiya | first2=J. David | last2=Goodman | title=Third British Journalist Is Arrested in Phone-Hacking Case | date=14 April 2011}}</ref> He had also dealt with some major fiscal issues, "managing huge budgets" and "crisis management" at the newspaper.<ref name="dailymail1"/><ref name="autogenerated5">{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Phone-Hacking-Inquiry-News-Of-The-World-Journalist-James-Weatherup-Arrested-By-Police/Article/201104215972234 |title=Phone-Hacking Inquiry: News Of The World Journalist James Weatherup Arrested By Police |publisher=BSkyB |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.linkedin.com/pub/james-weatherup/1a/400/542 |title=James Weatherup – United Kingdom |publisher=Uk.linkedin.com |accessdate=16 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120717110617/http://uk.linkedin.com/pub/james-weatherup/1a/400/542 |archivedate=17 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
''The Guardian'', referring to the Information Commissioner's report of 2006, queried why the Metropolitan Police chose to exclude a large quantity of material relating to [[Jonathan Rees]] from the scope of its Operation Weeting inquiry.<ref name="Guardian 10.6.2011">[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/jun/10/phone-hacking-scandal-time-for-public-inquiry "Phone-hacking scandal: Time for a public inquiry"] ''[[The Guardian]]''. 10 June 2011. Retrieved 9 July 2011.</ref> The ''News of the World'' was said to have made extensive use of Rees' investigative services, including phone hacking, paying him up to £150,000 a year.<ref name="Guardian 11.3.2011">Nick Davies; Vikram Dodd. [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/mar/11/news-of-the-world-police-corruption "Murder trial collapse exposes News of the World links to police corruption"] ''[[The Guardian]]''. 11 March 2011. Retrieved 9 July 2011.</ref> On the basis of evidence obtained during [[Metropolitan Police role in the News International phone hacking scandal#Operation Nigeria (1999)|Operation Nigeria]], Rees was found guilty in December 2000 of attempting to pervert the course of justice and received a seven-year prison sentence.<ref name="Guardian 20 November 2006">Hugh Muir; Duncan Campbell. [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/nov/20/ukcrime.duncancampbell "DNA may solve killing that shamed Met"], ''[[The Guardian]]''. 20 November 2006. Retrieved 9 July 2011.</ref> After he was released from prison the ''News of the World'', under the editorship of Andy Coulson, began commissioning Rees' services again.<ref name="Guardian 11.3.2011"/>
''The Guardian'' journalist [[Nick Davies]] described commissions from the ''News of the World'' as the "golden source" of income for Rees' "empire of corruption", which involved a network of contacts with corrupt police officers and a pattern of illegal behaviour extending far beyond phone hacking.<ref name="Guardian 12.3.2011">Nick Davies. [http://www.nickdavies.net/2011/03/16/jonathan-rees-empire-of-corruption/ "Jonathan Rees' empire of corruption"]. 12 March 2011. Retrieved 9 July 2011.</ref> Despite detailed evidence, the Metropolitan Police failed to pursue effective in-depth investigations into Rees' corrupt relationship with the ''News of the World'' over more than a decade.<ref name="Guardian 11.3.2011"/>
On 12 July 2011, Metropolitan Police deputy assistant commissioner Sue Akers told MPs and the Home Affairs committee chairman [[Keith Vaz]] that police had contacted 170 of the 3,870 people named in Glenn Mulcaire's files to date.<ref name="guardian1">{{cite news|author=Hélène Mulholland | author2 = Alan Travis; Vikram Dodd |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/12/thousands-phone-hacking-victims-contacted-met-sue-akers |title=Thousands of hacking victims yet to be contacted, says Met's Sue Akers |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=12 July 2011 |date=12 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/news-international-failed-to-co-operate |title=News International 'failed to cooperate' |publisher=Channel 4 News |accessdate=14 July 2011}}</ref>
===Apology and compensation=== [[News International]] announced on 8 April 2011 that it would admit liability in some of the [[breach of privacy]] cases being brought in relation to phone hacking by the ''News of the World''. The company offered an unreserved apology and compensation to eight claimants, but would continue to contest allegations made by other litigants.<ref name="apology1">{{Cite news | title = News of the World phone hacking victims get apology from Murdoch | first = James | last = Robinson |work=The Guardian |location=UK | date = 9 April 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/apr/08/phone-hacking-victims-apology-news | accessdate =9 April 2011 }}</ref><ref name="apology2">{{Cite news | title = News of the World offers apology in some phone-hacking cases | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 9 April 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/04/09/news-of-the-world-offers-apology-in-some-phone-hacking-cases/ | accessdate =9 April 2011 }}</ref>
The eight claimants were identified in media reports as:<ref name="nytimes.com" /><ref name="apology3">{{Cite news | title = News International says sorry for phone hacking | first = Robert | last = Peston |publisher=BBC News | date = 8 April 2011 | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/thereporters/robertpeston/2011/04/news_international_says_sorry.html | accessdate =9 April 2011 }}</ref><ref name="guardian2">{{cite news |author=James Robinson |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/apr/08/news-corp-phone-hacking |title=Phone hacking: NI to apologise to victims including Sienna Miller |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=8 April 2011 |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated4">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/news-says-it-will-settle-phonehacking-suits-20110409-1d83h.html |title=News says it will settle phone-hacking suits |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=9 April 2011 |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref> * [[Sienna Miller]], actress * [[Kelly Hoppen]], interior designer and Miller's stepmother * [[Tessa Jowell]], Member of Parliament and former cabinet minister * [[David Mills (lawyer)|David Mills]], lawyer and Jowell's former husband * [[Andy Gray (footballer born 1955)|Andy Gray]], sports pundit and former footballer * Joan Hammell, aide to the former [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Deputy Prime Minister]] [[John Prescott]] * [[Sky Andrew]], sports talent agent * Nicola Phillips, assistant to the publicist [[Max Clifford]]
At the time of News International's announcement, 24 individuals were in the process of taking legal action against the ''News of the World'' on breach of privacy grounds.<ref name="apology1" /> Comic actor [[Steve Coogan]] was reported to be one of the suspected victims of phone hacking.<ref name="nytimes.com"/><ref name="guardian2"/><ref name="autogenerated4"/>
Hoppen lodged a further claim against the ''News of the World'' and one of its reporters, Dan Evans, for "accessing or attempting to access her voicemail messages between June 2009, and March 2010".<ref name="The Independent x2">{{Cite news| last = Milmo | first = Cahal | title = New claims suggest that phone hacking is still going on | magazine = The Independent | date =28 January 2011 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/new-claims-suggest-that-phone-hacking-is-still-going-on-2196753.html | accessdate =30 January 2011 | location=London}}</ref> News International has not admitted liability in relation to the claim.<ref name="apology2" /><ref name="The Independent x2"/>
On 10 April, Tessa Jowell and her former husband David Mills, Andy Gray, Sky Andrew, Nicola Phillips, Joan Hammell, and Kelly Hoppen all received the official apology and compensation, but actor Leslie Ash and John Prescott, who both had also claimed breach of privacy, did not.<ref name="The Independent x2"/><ref name="kennedy1">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/apr/10/now-phone-hacking-reject-apology |location=UK |work=The Guardian | first=Maev | last=Kennedy | title=News of the World phone-hacking victims reject apology | date=10 April 2011}}</ref>
Scottish politician [[Danny Alexander]] predicted further arrests would be made. The shadow [[Secretary of State for Wales]] [[Peter Hain]] called on the legal authorities to conduct a "full and proper public investigation" and then claimed the police investigation had been "tardy".<ref name="kennedy1"/>
The first individual to accept the ''News of the World''{{'s}} apology and compensation was actress Sienna Miller, who received £100,000 plus legal costs.<ref name="millercomp"> {{Cite news | title = Sienna Miller accepts £100,000 payout from News of the World | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 14 May 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/05/14/uk-sienna-miller-accepts-100000-payout-from-news-of-the-world/ | accessdate =5 July 2011 }}</ref> Sports pundit Andy Gray followed in June, accepting a payout of £20,000 plus legal costs.<ref name="graycomp">{{Cite news | title = Andy Gray accepts settlement in phone hacking case | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 22 June 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/06/22/uk-andy-gray-accepts-settlement-in-phone-hacking-case/ | accessdate =5 July 2011 }}</ref> Prior to the settlements, both individuals' litigation claims had been identified as phone hacking "test cases" to be heard in January 2012.
In January 2012 it was reported that [[Respect Party|Respect]] politician [[George Galloway]], who was not an MP at the time, had settled out of court.<ref>Jason Deans, Amelia Hill & Lisa O'Carroll [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/jan/19/phone-hacking-payment-victims "Phone hacking: News International to pay out to 37 victims"], theguardian.com, 19 January 2012</ref> Galloway had begun legal proceedings for breach of privacy in 2010 after being told by the Met that he had probably been targeted by Mulcaire. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed.<ref name="BBC News">{{Cite news| title = Former MP George Galloway 'offered payout over hacking' |work=BBC News | date =30 January 2011 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12319722}}</ref> Galloway said the apology was a cynical attempt to protect Rebekah Brooks.
In April, ''[[The Observer]]'' reported claims from a former minister that Rupert Murdoch tried to persuade Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] early in 2010 to help in resisting attempts by Labour MPs and peers to investigate the affair, and to go easy on ''News of the World'' in the run-up to the UK's general election of May 2010.<ref>Toby Helm; James Robinson. [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/apr/09/phone-hacking-rupert-murdoch-gordon-brown "Phone hacking: Rupert Murdoch 'urged Gordon Brown' to halt Labour attacks"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. 9 April 2011.</ref> News International described the report as "total rubbish"; a spokesperson for Brown declined to comment.
The BBC reported on 20 May 2011 that a senior ''News of the World'' executive was implicated, according to actor [[Jude Law]]'s barrister in the High Court. This report also said that the number of people whose phones may have been hacked may be much larger than previously thought. The High Court was said to have been told that "notebooks belonging to a private investigator hired by News Group Newspapers contained thousands of mobile phone numbers" and "police also found 149 individual personal identification numbers and almost 400 unique voicemail numbers which can be used to access voice mail".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-13473347 |publisher=BBC News | title=Hacking row: News of the World executive 'implicated' | date=20 May 2011}}</ref>
==July 2011: new allegations==
