===Milly Dowler's voicemail=== It was first reported by ''The Guardian'' on 4 July 2011 that police had found evidence suggesting that the private investigator [[Glenn Mulcaire]] collected personal information about the family of the missing [[Surrey]] teenager [[Murder of Milly Dowler|Milly Dowler]], following her disappearance in March 2002 and the discovery of her body six months later.<ref name="dowlerallegation"> {{Cite news | title = Missing Milly Dowler's voicemail was hacked by News of the World |author1=Davies, Nick |author2=Hill, Amelia |lastauthoramp=yes |work=The Guardian |location=UK | date = 4 July 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/jul/04/milly-dowler-voicemail-hacked-news-of-world | accessdate =5 July 2011 }}</ref> According to the paper, journalists working for the ''News of the World'' had hired private investigators to hack into Dowler's voicemail inbox shortly after her disappearance. It was alleged that they had deleted some messages, giving false hope to police and to Dowler's family, who thought that she might have deleted the messages and therefore might still be alive and potentially destroying valuable evidence about her abduction and any evidence against a potential abductor and murderer.
[[Levi Bellfield]] had been convicted of the murder just two weeks before these revelations – he had already been convicted of two murders and an attempted murder which took place after Milly's disappearance and the discovery of her body. It was later established that Dowler's phone had deleted the messages automatically, 72 hours after being listened to.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fiveash|first=Kelly|title=NotW didn't delete Milly Dowler 'false hope' voicemail|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/12/12/notw_dowler_voicemail/|work=The Register|accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> ''The Guardian'' commented that the ''News of the World'' did not conceal from its readers in an article on 14 April 2002 that it had intercepted telephone messages and also informed Surrey police of this fact on 27 March 2002, six days after Milly went missing.<ref name="dowlerallegation" />
In July 2011, it was announced that the Dowler family was preparing a claim for damages against the ''News of the World''.<ref name="damagesclaimdowler">{{Cite news | title = Milly Dowler phone hacking: Family shocked by NoW revelations | first = James | last = Robinson |work=The Guardian |location=UK | date = 4 July 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/jul/04/milly-dowler-family-phone-hacking | accessdate =5 July 2011 }}</ref> News Group Newspapers described the allegation as "a development of great concern".<ref name="dowlerallegation" /> Reacting to the revelation, Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] said that the alleged hacking, if true, was "truly dreadful". He added that police ought to pursue a "vigorous" investigation to ascertain what had taken place.<ref name="cameronreact">{{Cite news | title = Milly Dowler phone hacking: Cameron condemns News of the World |author1=Gabbatt, Adam |author2=Davies, Nick |author3=Hill, Amelia |work=The Guardian |location=UK | date = 5 July 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/jul/05/milly-dowler-phone-hacking-cameron | accessdate =5 July 2011 }}</ref><ref name="cameronmilibandreact">{{Cite news | title = Cameron joins Milly Dowler hacking outrage, condemning 'a truly dreadful act' | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 5 July 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/05/uk-cameron-joins-milly-dowler-outrage-condemning-a-truly-dreadful-act/ | accessdate =5 July 2011 }}</ref> Leader of the opposition [[Ed Miliband]] called on Rebekah Brooks, the ''News of the World''{{'s}} editor in 2002, and then the chief executive of News International, to "consider her conscience and consider her position".<ref name="cameronmilibandreact" /> Brooks denied knowledge of phone hacking during her editorship.<ref name="brooks">{{Cite news | title = News International's Rebekah Brooks 'won't resign' | first = Robert | last = Peston | authorlink = Robert Peston | publisher=BBC News | date = 5 July 2011 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-14026369 | accessdate =5 July 2011 }}</ref><ref>Rebekah Brooks [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/05/milly-dowler-phone-hacking-rebekah-brooks-email "Milly Dowler phone hacking: the full text of Rebekah Brooks's email"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. 5 July 2011.</ref>
It was in the wake of the Dowler allegations that a significant number of people, including former deputy prime minister [[John Prescott]] and other politicians, began seriously to question whether the takeover of [[BSkyB]] by News Corporation should be vetoed by the appropriate government authorities.<ref name="prescottcomment">{{Cite news | title = Milly Dowler phone hacking: Politicians hit out over revelations | author=Mulholland, Hélène | author2 = Robinson, James |work=The Guardian |location=UK | date = 4 July 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/jul/04/milly-dowler-phone-hacking-politicians | accessdate =5 July 2011 }}</ref> The [[Media Standards Trust]] formed the pressure group ''[[Media Standards Trust#Hacked Off|Hacked Off]]'', to campaign for a [[public inquiry]]. Soon after launch, the campaign gained the support of suspected hacking victim, the actor [[Hugh Grant]], who became a public spokesperson, appearing on ''[[Question Time (TV series)|Question Time]]'' and ''[[Newsnight]].''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mediastandardstrust.org/mst-news/hacked-off-campaign-for-a-public-inquiry-into-phone-hacking/ |title=Hacked Off: Campaign for a Public Inquiry into Phone Hacking |publisher=Media Standards Trust |accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
In January 2012, it was revealed that Surrey Police had discovered during the early stages of their inquiries that News of the World staff had accessed Amanda Dowler's mobile phone messages but did not take issue with this. Instead, a senior Surrey officer invited News of the World staff to a meeting to discuss the case.<ref name=telegraph-20120123>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9032994/News-of-the-World-reporter-played-police-Milly-Dowler-voicemail.html |title=News of the World reporter played police Milly Dowler voicemail |author=Gordon Rayner |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=23 January 2012 |accessdate=18 April 2012 |location=London}}</ref>
===British soldiers' relatives=== On 6 July 2011, ''The Daily Telegraph'' reported that the voicemail accounts of some relatives of British soldiers killed in action in [[Iraq War|Iraq]] since 2003 and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]] since 2001 may have been eavesdropped by the ''News of the World''.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Phone hacking: How scandal unfolded |author1=Wilkinson, Peter |author2=Gilbert, Dave | work= CNN World | url = http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/08/16/uk.phone.hacking.explainer/index.html | date = 16 August 2011 | accessdate = 2 February 2013}}</ref> The personal details and phone numbers belonging to relatives of dead service personnel were found in the Glen Mulcaire's files.<ref name="soldiers">{{Cite news | title = Phone hacking: families of war dead 'targeted' by News of the World |author1=Hughes, Mark |author2=Gardham, Duncan |author3=Bingham, John |author4=Bloxham, Andy | work=The Daily Telegraph | date = 7 July 2011 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8621797/Phone-hacking-families-of-war-dead-targeted-by-News-of-the-World.html | accessdate =7 July 2011 | location=London }}</ref> In response to the allegations, [[The Royal British Legion]] announced that it would suspend all ties with the ''News of the World'', dropping the newspaper as its campaigning partner.<ref name="rbldrop">{{Cite news | title = Citing 'revulsion', veterans charity cuts ties with News of the World | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 7 July 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/07/uk-citing-revulsion-veterans-charity-cuts-ties-with-news-of-the-world/ | accessdate =7 July 2011 }}</ref><ref name="advertisers">{{Cite news | title = Royal British Legion suspends NoW ties over 'hacking' | publisher=BBC News | date = 7 July 2011 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-14059572 | accessdate =7 July 2011}}</ref>
===7/7 London attack victims=== On the day before the sixth anniversary of the [[7 July 2005 London bombings]], it was reported that relatives of some victims may have had their telephones snooped on by the ''[[News of the World]]'' in the aftermath of the attacks. A man who lost two children in the bombings told the BBC that police officers investigating phone hacking had warned him that their contact details were found on a target list, while a former firefighter who helped rescue injured passengers also said he had been contacted by police who were looking into the hacking allegations.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14040841 |title=News of the World 'hacked 7/7 family phones' |publisher=BBC News |date=6 July 2011 |accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref> A number of survivors from the bombings revealed that police had warned them their phones may have been hacked and their messages intercepted; in some cases they were advised to change security codes and PINs.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hutchinson |first=Lisa |url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/north-east-news/evening-chronicle-news/2011/07/07/tyneside-7-7-bombings-survivor-lisa-french-has-been-contacted-by-detectives-investigating-news-of-the-world-phone-hacking-scandal-72703-29009171/ |title=Tyneside 7/7 bombings survivor Lisa French has been contacted by detectives investigating News of the World phone hacking scandal. – Chronicle News – News |publisher=ChronicleLive |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate=18 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201141110/http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/north-east-news/evening-chronicle-news/2011/07/07/tyneside-7-7-bombings-survivor-lisa-french-has-been-contacted-by-detectives-investigating-news-of-the-world-phone-hacking-scandal-72703-29009171/ |archivedate=1 February 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kentnews.co.uk/news/london_bombing_survivor_threatens_to_sue_over_hacking_1_956554 |title=London bombing survivor threatens to sue over hacking – News |publisher=Kent News |accessdate=18 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812034940/http://www.kentnews.co.uk/news/london_bombing_survivor_threatens_to_sue_over_hacking_1_956554 |archivedate=12 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Susan Ryan |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/warnings-of-potential-irish-victims-of-notw-phone-hacking-172128-Jul2011/ |title=Warnings of potential Irish victims of NOTW phone hacking · TheJournal |publisher=Thejournal.ie |accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
===Sara Payne=== On 28 July, ''The Guardian'' reported that the ''News of the World'' hacked into the voicemail of media campaigner [[Sara Payne]], whose eight-year-old daughter, [[Murder of Sarah Payne|Sarah Payne]], was murdered in [[West Sussex]] by [[paedophile]] [[Roy Whiting]], in July 2000. This news was arguably met with even more public outrage than the Dowler revelations, given the prominent role that Rebekah Brooks and the ''News of the World'' played in the passage of [[Sarah's Law]], which changed [[sex offender]] laws in the UK. Sara Payne has been an active campaigner in favour of such laws with News International and other media and charity organisations since her daughter's death.
Brooks developed a long-standing friendship with Sara Payne in the years after her daughter's death; Payne wrote a column praising the ''News of the World''{{'s}} support for Sarah's Law in its final issue, writing that the paper's staff "supported me through some of the darkest, most difficult times of my life and became my trusted friends".<ref>Nick Davies; Amelia Hill. [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/28/phone-hacking-sarah-payne "News of the World targeted phone of Sarah Payne's mother"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. 28 July 2011.</ref> Brooks used the Sarah's Law campaign to defend the ''News of the World'' when she was questioned by the [[Culture, Media and Sport Committee]].
Scotland Yard had reportedly found materials pertaining to Payne in Glenn Mulcaire's notes. They also discovered that Payne's voicemail was on a mobile phone given to her by Brooks, ostensibly to help her keep in touch with supporters. Brooks issued a statement denying that the ''News of the World'' was aware of Mulcaire's targeting of Payne, saying that such an idea was "unthinkable". Payne was said to be "absolutely devastated and deeply disappointed" at the disclosure.
===Other victims=== Some email messages were discovered suggesting Jonathan Rees<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/mar/11/phone-hacking-dark-arts-jonathan-rees |title=Phone hacking: The dark arts of Jonathan Rees |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=11 March 2011 |accessdate=12 July 2011}}</ref> made requests for sums of around £1,000 for contact details of senior members of the Royal Family and friends.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14107410 |title=News of the World 'paid royal police officer' |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=12 July 2011 |date=11 July 2011}}</ref>
Former deputy prime minister [[John Prescott]] claimed he knew of "direct evidence" indicating ''The Sunday Times'' was involved in illegal news gathering activities.<ref name="thisislondon1">{{cite web |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23969209-sunday-times-is-being-investigated-over-more-illegal-practices-claims-prescott.do |title=Sunday Times is being investigated over more illegal practices, claims Prescott |work=London Evening Standard |location=UK |accessdate=12 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714055739/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23969209-sunday-times-is-being-investigated-over-more-illegal-practices-claims-prescott.do |archivedate=14 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Former prime minister [[Gordon Brown]] alleged his bank account was accessed by ''The Sunday Times'' in 2000, and that ''The Sun'' gained private medical records about his son, Fraser, who has [[cystic fibrosis]].<ref name="thisislondon1"/> [[Rebekah Brooks]] telephoned Brown to tell him that ''The Sun'' was going to reveal that his son had been diagnosed with [[cystic fibrosis]] and tried to persuade him not to spoil the newspaper's exclusive by announcing it himself first.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.stv.tv/scotland/east-central/262125-gordon-brown-genuinely-shocked-at-actions-of-news-international/ |title=Gordon Brown 'genuinely shocked' at News International hacking claim |publisher=News.stv.tv |date=5 July 2011 |accessdate=12 July 2011}}</ref> ''The Guardian'' later ran a front-page story accusing ''The Sun'' of improperly obtaining the medical records of Brown's son, but was later forced to issue an apology upon discovering that the information came from a member of the public.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2015067/Rebekah-Brooks-resigns-head-News-International-refuses-apologise.html | title = Rebekah Brooks resigns head News International refuses apologise |work=Daily Mail |location=London |first=Richard |last=Hartley-Parkinson |date=15 July 2011}}</ref>
Other victims of hacking included former Metropolitan Police assistant commissioner John Yates, who revealed on 12 January 2011 that his phone was hacked between 2004 and 2005.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8632506/John-Yates-reveals-his-own-phone-was-hacked-as-he-appears-before-MPs.html |title=John Yates reveals his own phone was hacked as he appears before MPs |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=12 July 2011 |location=London |first=Victoria |last=Ward |date=12 July 2011}}</ref> The phone of chat show host [[Paul O'Grady]] was also hacked by the ''News of the World'' after he suffered a heart attack in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/news/a330169/news-of-the-world-hacked-paul-ogrady-after-heart-attack.html |title=News of the World 'hacked Paul O'Grady after heart attack' – Showbiz News |work=Digital Spy |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Dyson |first=Ed |url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/view/201368/LILY-SAVAGES-HACKERS/ |title=Simply The Best 7 Days A Week :: News :: LILY SAVAGES HACKERS |work=Daily Star |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref>
In May 2012 it was reported that billionaire [[Robert Agostinelli]] had been targeted by a private detective named Steve Whitamore working for [[Rupert Murdoch]]'s newspaper to gain confidential information pertaining to Agostinelli's business affairs – this evidence brought to light the fact that high-profile U.S citizens were targeted by private investigators in the UK within Rupert Murdoch's empire. This was revealed once the [[Information Commissioner's Office]] raided Steve Whittamore's offices and was subsequently convicted of illegally trading personal information.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2150111/Murdoch-private-detective-tricked-Claridges-handing-U-S-financier.html | work=Daily Mail | first=Damien | last=Gayle | title=Murdoch private detective tricked Claridge's into handing over bill of top U.S. financier | date=25 May 2012}}</ref>
In July 2011 it was reported that [[Mark Stephens (solicitor)|Mark Stephens]] had been one of a group of high-profile lawyers who may have been the victim of "News International phone hacking scandal".<ref name="Channel 4 News">{{cite news|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/solicitors-phones-hacked-by-news-of-the-world|title=Solicitors' phones 'hacked by News of the World'|publisher=Ch4 News|date=22 July 2011|accessdate=29 August 2011}}</ref>
Mary Ellen Field, the former business manager of model [[Elle Macpherson]], lost her job after Field was accused of leaking confidential information to the ''News of the World'', which had published a story about Macpherson's split with [[Arpad Busson]]. Field realised their voicemails could have been intercepted after Glenn Mulcaire admitted in court to accessing Macpherson's phones.<ref>{{cite web|last=Alberici |first=Emma |url=http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2011/s3272250.htm |title=Australian link to phone hacking scandal |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date= 18 July 2011|accessdate=20 July 2011}}</ref>
A cousin of [[Jean Charles de Menezes]], the Brazilian man shot dead by police who mistook him for a fugitive suspected of involvement in the [[21 July 2005 London bombings|21 July 2005 attempted bombings]] in London, may also have had his phone hacked by the ''[[News of the World]]'' after Menezes's death.<ref name="telegraph2">{{cite news|last=Bingham |first=John |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8638563/Phone-hacking-Jean-Charles-de-Menezes-cousin-may-have-been-targeted.html |title=Phone hacking: Jean Charles de Menezes cousin may have been targeted |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=22 July 2005 |accessdate=16 July 2011 |location=London}}</ref><ref name="politics1">{{cite web|url=http://www.politics.co.uk/news/2011/07/14/de-menezes-family-dragged-into-phone-hacking- |title=De Menezes family dragged into phone-hacking row |publisher=Politics.co.uk |date=22 July 2005 |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Yapp |first=Robin |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8639265/Phone-hacking-Jean-Charles-de-Menezess-cousin-attacks-Rupert-Murdoch.html |title=Phone hacking: Jean Charles de Menezes's cousin attacks Rupert Murdoch |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=22 July 2005 |accessdate=16 July 2011 |location=London}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated6">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/call-for-police-chief-to-resign-over-hacking-20110715-1hi0v.html |title=Call for police chief to resign over hacking |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=14 September 2010 |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref> A spokesperson from the Justice4Jean campaign group said: "The Menezes family are deeply pained to find their phones may have been hacked at a time at which they were at their most vulnerable and bereaved."<ref name="telegraph2"/><ref name="politics1"/>
[[Carole Caplin]], the former fitness adviser to Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]], announced that the Metropolitan police had told her that her mobile phone was probably hacked, dating back to 2002 – along with the Milly Dowler case in the same year, this is one of the earliest cases so far discovered.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/nov/01/phone-hacking-carole-caplin |title=Phone hacking: Carole Caplin told she was target |author=James Robinson |newspaper=The Guardian |date=1 November 2011 |accessdate=1 November 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
==Aftermath==
===Closure of the ''News of the World''===
[[File:Final NOTW cover.jpeg|thumb|The final edition of ''[[News of the World]]'', published on 10 July 2011.]] The closure of the ''News of the World'' after 168 years in print, was the first significant effect of the scandal. In the days leading up to 7 July 2011, [[Virgin Holidays]], [[The Co-operative Group]], [[Ford Motor Company]] and [[General Motors]] (owner of [[Vauxhall Motors]]) had all pulled their advertisements from the ''News of the World'' in response to the unfolding controversy. Several other major advertisers also considered doing the same.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news|author=Laura Smith-Spark, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/BUSINESS/07/06/uk.phonehacking.ads/index.html |title=Firms reconsider ad deals over newspaper phone hacking scandal |publisher=CNN |accessdate=12 July 2011 |date=7 July 2011}}</ref>
James Murdoch announced on 7 July 2011 that after 168 years in print the ''News of the World'' would publish its last-ever edition on 10 July, with the loss of 200 jobs.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/07/news-of-the-world-to-close |title=News of the World axed by News International|date=7 July 2011|work=The Guardian |location=UK|accessdate=7 July 2011|first1=James|last1=Robinson|first2=Kirsty|last2=Scott|first3=Mark|last3=Sweney}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/07/07/end-of-the-world-rupert-murdochs-news-of-the-world-to-close-after-phone-hacking-scandal/|title=End of the 'World': Rupert Murdoch's News of the World To Close After Phone Hacking Scandal|date=7 July 2011|work=Time |accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/dj-taylor-for-168-years-news-of-the-world-was-as-english-as-roast-beef-2308954.html |title=DJ Taylor: For 168 years News of the World was as English as roast beef |work=The Independent |location=UK |accessdate=8 July 2011 |date=8 July 2011}}</ref> News Corporation said that all profits from the final edition would go to good causes. Downing Street said it had no role in the decision.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8623589/News-of-the-World-to-close-on-Sunday-says-James-Murdoch.html|title=News of the World to close on Sunday, says James Murdoch|date=7 July 2011|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=7 July 2011|location=London}}</ref> James Murdoch conceded the paper was "sullied by behaviour that was wrong", saying "if recent allegations are true, it was inhuman and has no place in our company."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0707/hacking.html|title=News of the World to cease publication|date=7 July 2011|publisher=RTÉ News|accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref>
Other executives of the company said the phone hacking was more widespread than previously believed and that they are co-operating with investigations into the allegations.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14070733 |title=News of the World to close amid hacking scandal |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=7 July 2011 |date=7 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Mills |first=Elinor |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-27080_3-20077563-245/british-tabloid-to-shutter-in-wake-of-phone-hacking-scandal/ |title=British tabloid to shutter in wake of phone hacking scandal cnet 7 July 2011 |publisher=[[CNET Networks]] |accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/phone-hacking-scandal-closes-news-of-the-world/2011/07/07/gIQAy5RA2H_story.html|title=Phone hacking scandal closes News of the World|date=7 July 2011|work=The Washington Post |accessdate=7 July 2011|first=Ellen|last=McCarthy}}</ref> Editor Rebekah Brooks told staff at a meeting, that she recognised following an internal investigation that "other shoes would drop", a phrase indicating that further revelations of wrongdoing would follow.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/media/july-dec11/notw2_07-08.html |title=How Will News of the World Scandal Affect Murdoch's Power, Media Empire? |publisher=PBS |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=12 July 2011}}</ref>
There was immediate speculation that News International would launch a Sunday edition of ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' to replace its sister paper ''News of the World''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/davidhughes/100095915/the-news-of-the-world-is-sacrificed-how-long-before-we-have-the-sun-on-sunday/|title=The News of the World is sacrificed – how long before we have The Sun on Sunday?|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=7 July 2011|accessdate=7 July 2011|location=London}}</ref> ''The Sun on Sunday'' was launched on 26 February 2012.

furore.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14124020 |title=Phone hacking scandal: Timeline |publisher=BBC News |date=12 July 2011 |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref><ref name="bskybpullout">{{Cite news |title=Facing overwhelming pressure, News Corp pulls out of bid for BSkyB |work=The Spy Report |publisher=Media Spy |date=13 July 2011 |url=http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/13/facing-overwhelming-pressure-news-corp-pulls-out-of-bid-for-bskyb/ |accessdate=16 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716094851/http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/13/facing-overwhelming-pressure-news-corp-pulls-out-of-bid-for-bskyb/ |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name="bskybpullout2">{{Cite news |title=Rupert Murdoch gives up BSkyB takeover bid |author1=Wintour, Patrick |author2=Sabbagh, Dan |author3=Watt, Nicholas |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=14 July 2011 |url=http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/13/facing-overwhelming-pressure-news-corp-pulls-out-of-bid-for-bskyb/ |accessdate=16 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716094851/http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/13/facing-overwhelming-pressure-news-corp-pulls-out-of-bid-for-bskyb/ |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df= ===New York State contract lost by subsidiary of News Corporation=== In the week of 22 August 2011, Wireless Generation,<ref name="wiregen">{{cite web|url=http://www.wirelessgeneration.com/ |title=Wireless Generation |publisher=Wireless Generation |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> a subsidiary of News Corporation, lost a no-bid contract with New York State to build an information system, for tracking student performance as a consequence of the News International phone hacking scandal. Citing, "... vendor responsibility issues with the parent company of Wireless Generation," state comptroller [[Thomas DiNapoli]] said that the revelations surrounding News Corporation had made the final approval of the contract "untenable".<ref name="nyscontractlost">{{Cite news | title = Subsidiary of News Corp. Loses Deal With State | author=Otterman, Sharon |work=The New York Times | date = 29 August 2011 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/30/education/30wireless.html | accessdate =1 September 2011 }}</ref>
===Resignations=== A number of senior employees and executives resigned from News International and its parent company, after the emergence of the new allegations, along with high-ranking officers of the [[Metropolitan Police Service]]. News International's legal manager [[Tom Crone]] left the company on 13 July.<ref name="croneresign">{{Cite news | title = News of the World legal manager Tom Crone to leave News International |author1=Sabbagh, Dan |author2=Martinson, Jane |work=The Guardian |location=UK | date = 13 July 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/13/news-of-the-world-tom-crone-to-leave | accessdate =16 July 2011 }}</ref> As part of his role at the publisher, Crone had served as the ''News of the World''{{'s}} chief lawyer and gave evidence before parliamentary committees, that he had uncovered no evidence of phone hacking beyond the criminal offences committed by the royal editor Clive Goodman. He maintained that he did not see an internal report suggesting that phone hacking at the paper went beyond Goodman.<ref name="cronebackground">{{Cite news | title = Tom Crone: News International's go-to man on legal issues | author=Martinson, Jane |work=The Guardian |location=UK | date = 11 July 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/11/tom-crone-chief-lawyer-now | accessdate =16 July 2011 }}</ref>
On 15 July, [[Rebekah Brooks]], the chief executive of News International, quit following widespread criticism of her role in the controversy.<ref name="brooksresign">{{Cite news | title = Phone hacking: News International chief Brooks quits |publisher=BBC News | date = 15 July 2011 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14166162 | accessdate =16 July 2011 }}</ref> In a statement, Brooks said that "my desire to remain on the bridge has made me a focal point of the debate" and stated that she would "concentrate on correcting the distortions and rebutting the allegations about my record".<ref name="brooksmurdochstatement">{{Cite news | title = Rebekah Brooks' resignation letter and James Murdoch's statement | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 15 July 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/15/rebekah-brooks-statement-announcing-her-resignation-from-news-international/ | accessdate =16 July 2011 }}</ref> Her exit was welcomed by political leaders. Prime Minister [[David Cameron]]'s office said that her departure was "the right decision", while Leader of the Opposition [[Ed Miliband]] agreed but suggested that she should have departed ten days earlier.<ref name="brooksresign" /> [[Tom Mockridge]], the long-time chief executive of the Italian satellite broadcaster [[Sky Italia]], was announced as Brooks' replacement at the head of News International.<ref name="brooksresign" />
Later that day, [[Les Hinton]] resigned as the chief executive of the News Corporation subsidiary [[Dow Jones & Company]].<ref name="hintonresign">{{Cite news | title = Rupert Murdoch's bloody Friday as Rebekah Brooks and Les Hinton quit | author=Martinson, Jane | author2 = Watt, Nicholas |work=The Guardian |location=UK | date = 16 July 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/15/rupert-murdoch-sorry-rebekah-brooks-out | accessdate =16 July 2011 }}</ref><ref name="hintonresign2">{{Cite news | title = Les Hinton, Murdoch's right-hand man, quits over News International scandal | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 16 July 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/16/les-hinton-murdochs-right-hand-man-quits-over-news-international-scandal/ | accessdate =16 July 2011 }}</ref> Hinton had served as chief executive of News International between 1997 and 2005. He had told parliamentary committees that there was "never any evidence" of phone hacking beyond the case of Clive Goodman. In his resignation announcement, Hinton said that he was not told of "evidence that wrongdoing went further" but indicated that he nevertheless felt it "proper" to resign from his position.<ref name="hintonresign2" />
On 17 July, the [[Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis|Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police]] and Britain's most senior police officer, [[Paul Stephenson (police officer)|Sir Paul Stephenson]], announced his resignation with immediate effect. He had faced criticism for hiring former ''News of the World'' executive editor [[Neil Wallis]] as an advisor and for having received free hospitality at a luxury health spa owned by a company for which Wallis also worked.<ref name="stephensonresign">{{Cite news |title=Met Police Chief Quits Amid Hacking Claims |publisher=Sky News |date=17 July 2011 |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Metropolitan-Police-Commissioner-Sir-Paul-Stephenson-Resigns-Amid-Phone-Hacking-Inquiry/Article/201107316032138?lpos=Home_Carousel_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_16032138_Metropolitan_Police_Commissioner_Sir_Paul_Stephenson_Resigns_Amid_Phone_Hacking_Inquiry |accessdate=17 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720231110/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Metropolitan-Police-Commissioner-Sir-Paul-Stephenson-Resigns-Amid-Phone-Hacking-Inquiry/Article/201107316032138?lpos=Home_Carousel_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_16032138_Metropolitan_Police_Commissioner_Sir_Paul_Stephenson_Resigns_Amid_Phone_Hacking_Inquiry |archivedate=20 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> Stephenson's resignation was followed by that of [[Assistant Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis|assistant commissioner]] [[John Yates (police officer)|John Yates]] on 18 July. Yates had been criticised for failing to re-open the original 2006 investigation into phone hacking at News International, despite new evidence coming to light in 2009. In the wake of the later 2012 allegations against ''The Sun'' and arrests of executives, senior reporters and other personnel, James Murdoch resigned from his posts as News International executive chairman and BSkyB chairman on 1 March 2012. Later that July, Rupert Murdoch resigned from his directorships at Times Newspaper Holdings, NewsCorp Investments and News International Group Limited.
===Dismissals=== Matt Nixson was escorted by security from the Wapping headquarters of ''The Sun'' newspaper the evening of 20 July 2011. His computer was seized by News International officials and the police were said to have been informed. Nixson was a features editor at ''The Sun''. It was reported that Nixson's dismissal was related to the time he spent at the ''News of the World'' from 2006, when it was edited by Coulson. At the ''News of the World'' he reported to assistant editor [[Ian Edmondson]]. <ref name="nixsonsack"> {{Cite news | title = Phone Hacking: The Sun dragged into scandal after senior journalist sacked | work=The Daily Telegraph | date = 21 July 2011 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8653738/Phone-Hacking-The-Sun-dragged-into-scandal-after-senior-journalist-sacked.html | accessdate =24 July 2011 | location=London | first=Andrew | last=Porter }}</ref> On 20 September it was reported that the Metropolitan police had written to News International to inform them that they did not intend to question Nixson over phone hacking. Nixson was reported to be considering bringing a case for [[Unfair dismissal in the United Kingdom|unfair dismissal]] against his former employers.<ref>{{cite news |title=Phone hacking: sacked Sun journalist will not face police questioning |author=James Robinson |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/sep/20/phone-hacking-sun-journalist |newspaper=The Guardian |date=20 September 2011 |accessdate=21 September 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
===Leaves/suspensions=== Pending the result of an Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC – see below) enquiry into his dealings with Neil Wallis (see below), a former assistant editor of the News of the World, Dick Fedorcio,<ref name="fedorcioxref">{{cite web|url=http://www.met.police.uk/about/fedorcio.htm |title=Dick Fedorcio |publisher=Met.police.uk |accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref> director of public affairs and internal communication for the Metropolitan Police, was put on extended leave 10 August 2011. <ref name="fedorcioleave"> {{Cite news | title = Met PR man Dick Fedorcio put on leave | work=The Guardian | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | date = 10 August 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/aug/10/phone-hacking-enquiry-dick-fedorcio | accessdate =11 August 2011 | location=London | first=James | last=Robinson }}</ref>
===Cautions=== Details emerged 7 September 2011 that senior journalist Amelia Hill of ''[[The Guardian]]'' was questioned under caution but not arrest, for several hours by officers from Operation Weeting the previous week. Hill had reported the names of individuals linked to the phone hacking scandal minutes after their arrests and it is thought her questioning was linked to the earlier arrest of a 51-year-old detective suspected of leaking information to the newspaper. <ref name="hillcaution"> {{Cite news | title= Phone hacking: Guardian journalist interviewed over police inquiry leaks | work=The Telegraph | date =7 September 2011 | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8746900/Phone-hacking-Guardian-journalist-interviewed-over-police-inquiry-leaks.html | accessdate= 10 September 2011 | location=London | first=Andrew | last=Hough }}</ref>
===Apologies=== [[File:Rupert-Murdoch-ad-001.jpeg|thumb|A full-page apology ad published in British newspapers by News International. The letter, signed by Rupert Murdoch, begins: "The ''News of the World'' was in the business of holding others to account. It failed when it came to itself."<ref name="Sorrypage">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/14/phone-hacking-apologise-national|title=Phone hacking: NI plans full page apology in national press|last=Sweney|first=Mark|date=14 July 2011|work=The Guardian |location=UK|accessdate=15 July 2011}}</ref>]] From 15 July, onwards, News Corp began to change its position through a series of public apologies. On 15 July, Rupert Murdoch in interview with the News Corp owned ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' apologised for the ''News of the World'' letting slip the group's standards of journalism.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} Murdoch also alleged that the group's legal advisers, Harbottle & Lewis, had made "a major mistake" in its part in the internal investigation into phone-hacking in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legalweek.com/legal-week/news/2094408/murdoch-cites-major-mistakes-legal-adviser-culmination-drama|title=Murdoch cites 'major mistake' at legal adviser in culmination of a week of high drama|author=Suzi Ring|publisher=LegalWeek.com|date=15 July 2011|accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref> On 18 July, Harbottle & Lewis issued an open letter outlining its position, and appointed [[George Pitcher#Luther Pendragon|Luther Pendragon]] to handle PR issues relating to the affair.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legalweek.com/legal-week/news/2094792/harbottle-defends-hackgate-position-grabiner-tipped-lead-newscorp-clean|title=Harbottle Defends Hackgate Position|publisher=LegalWeek.com|date=18 July 2011|accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref>
On 16 and 17 July, News International published two full-page apologies in many of Britain's national newspapers. The first apology took the form of a letter, signed by Rupert Murdoch, in which he said sorry for the "serious wrongdoing" that occurred. The second was titled "Putting right what's gone wrong", and gave more detail about the steps News International was taking to address the public's concerns.
On the afternoon before the ads were published, Rupert Murdoch also attended a private meeting in London with the family of [[Murder of Milly Dowler|Milly Dowler]], where he apologised for the hacking of their murdered daughter's voicemail. The Dowler family's solicitor later said Murdoch appeared shaken and upset during the talks. He added that the Dowlers were surprised Murdoch's son James did not attend and called on the News International chairman to "take some responsibility" in the affair.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14170756 |title= Rupert Murdoch 'sorry' in newspaper adverts |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=16 July 2011 |date=16 July 2011}}</ref>
In March 2012 the ''Daily Mail'' published a story which it claimed was "evidence of the incestuous relationship between the Metropolitan Police and News International" and a political connection to David Cameron. In late 2010 the Mail had sought confirmation from the Prime Minister's office of a rumour that Cameron had been seen out riding horses with Rebekah Brooks's husband, Charlie Brooks, a horse trainer. Coulson, as Communications Director for Cameron had denied this. In March 2012, after the PM's office had denied the story again for three days, the Mail reported that Cameron had finally admitted that he had been out riding with Brooks back in 2010. He also admitted that the horse had been Raisa, a horse on loan to Rebekah Brooks from the Metropolitan Police.<ref name="horsegate">{{Cite news | title = How No10 misled the Mail on Sunday about Cameron and THAT police horse | work=Daily Mail | date = 4 March 2012 | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2109886/Horsegate-How-No10-misled-Mail-Sunday-Cameron-THAT-police-horse.html | accessdate =16 March 2012 | location=London | first=Simon | last=Walters }}</ref>
In February 2013 News International expressed "sincere" contrition and paid undisclosed "substantial" damages for a total of 144 cases. Among 17 phone-hacking victims given public apologies by News International in the High Court were [[Sarah, Duchess of York]], actors [[Hugh Grant]] and [[Christopher Eccleston]], the Catholic parish priest of singer [[Charlotte Church]], singer [[James Blunt]], [[Uri Geller]], [[Geoffrey Robinson]], the former Labour minister, and Colin Stagg, the man wrongly accused of the [[murder of Rachel Nickell]]. Mr Stagg, one of the few to have his damages disclosed, was awarded £15,500. Others who settled but opted to keep the terms of the arrangement private, included [[Cherie Blair]], the wife of the former prime minister, [[UK Independence Party]] leader [[Nigel Farage]], TV presenters [[Jamie Theakston]] and [[Chris Tarrant]], Ted Beckham, the father of the former England football captain, former Tory minister [[David Maclean]], Baron Blencathra, actor [[James Nesbitt]], footballer [[Wayne Rooney]] and BBC reporter [[Tom Mangold]].<ref name=JCusick>{{cite web |author=James Cusick|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/hugh-grant-gets-an-apology-from-murdoch-8486935.html |title=Hugh Grant gets an apology from Murdoch |date=8 February 2013|accessdate=1 June 2016|work= The Independent}}</ref>
===Further arrests=== {{main article|Phone hacking scandal reference lists#Arrests}}
Since 1999, [[News International phone hacking scandal reference lists#Arrests|over 100 people have been arrested]] in conjunction with illegal acquisition of confidential information. Over 90 of these have been arrested or rearrested since police investigations were renewed in 2011. Of these, [[News International phone hacking scandal reference lists#Charged with crimes|26 have been formally charged with crimes.]]
====Andy Coulson==== ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported on 7 July 2011, that former ''News of the World'' editor and David Cameron's former spokesman [[Andy Coulson]] was to be arrested the following day, along with a senior journalist the paper refused to name.<ref name="GuardianJuly2011">{{Cite news | title = Andy Coulson to be arrested over phone hacking tomorrow |work=The Guardian |location=UK | date = 7 July 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/07/andy-coulson-arrest-phone-hacking | accessdate =7 July 2011 | first=Amelia | last=Hill }}</ref> [[Sky News]] reported on 8 July 2011, that Coulson had been formally arrested,<ref name="SkyNewsCoulsonArrest20110707">{{Cite news | title = NOTW Closes: Ex-Editor To Be Quizzed By Cops | publisher=Sky News | location=UK | date = 8 July 2011 | url = http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/News-Of-The-World-Andy-Coulson-Former-Editor-Arrested-By-Police-Investigating-Phone-Hacking/Article/201107216026496?lpos=UK_News_Top_Stories_Header_1&lid=ARTICLE_16026496_News_Of_The_World%3A_Andy_Coulson%2C_Former_Editor%2C_Arrested_By_Police_Investigating_Phone_Hacking | accessdate =8 July 2011 }}</ref> although the [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] would only confirm that a "43-year-old man" had been arrested for "conspiring to intercept communications", he was then released without charge.<ref name="TimesCoulsonArrestBlog20110708">{{Cite news | title = News of the World phone hacking live 8 July 2011 | work=The Telegraph | location=UK | date = 8 July 2011 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8617707/News-of-the-World-phone-hacking-live.html | accessdate =8 July 2011 | first1=Sarah | last1=Rainey | first2=Lucy | last2=Jones | first3=Gordon | last3=Rayner | first4=Mark | last4=Hughes }}</ref>
On 30 May 2012, Coulson was charged with perjury,<ref name="Andy Coulson charged with perjury">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/may/30/andy-coulson-charged-with-perjury | location=London | work=The Guardian | first1=Severin | last1=Carrell | first2=Patrick | last2=Wintour | title=Andy Coulson charged with perjury | date=30 May 2012}}</ref> and later that year his and Rebekah Brooks' trial date was set for 9 September 2013.<ref name="Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson in 2013 trial">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19725264| date=26 September 2012 | publisher=BBC News | title=Phone hacking: Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson in 2013 trial}}</ref>
====Neil Wallis==== Former ''News of the World'' executive editor [[Neil Wallis]] was arrested in west London on 14 July, on suspicion of conspiring to intercept communications. He joined the paper in 2003 as a deputy to Coulson and in 2007, became an executive editor before leaving in 2009. Later that year his media consultancy company began to advise [[Paul Stephenson (police officer)|Paul Stephenson]] and [[John Yates (police officer)|John Yates]], two high-ranking Metropolitan Police officers, providing "strategic communications advice" until September 2010. During that time, Yates made the decision that the phone hacking needed no further investigation, despite ''The Guardian'' alleging that the previous investigation had been inadequate.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/blog/2011/jul/14/phone-hacking-scandal-live-coverage?commentpage=all#block-65|title=Phone hacking scandal – live coverage – 4.32 pm|author=Paul Owen|date=14 July 2011|accessdate=14 July 2011|work=The Guardian |location=UK}}</ref> He was also paid to advise commissioner Stephenson and Yates.<ref name="autogenerated6"/>
====Rebekah Brooks==== [[Rebekah Brooks]], the former editor of the ''News of the World'' and former chief executive of News International, was arrested on 17 July 2011 on suspicion of conspiring to intercept communications and on suspicion of corruption. She was arrested by appointment at a London police station<ref name="arrest">{{cite news | title = Rebekah Brooks arrested by hacking police |publisher=BBC News | date = 17 July 2011 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14178051 | accessdate =17 July 2011 }}</ref><ref name="arrest2">{{cite news | title = Phone hacking: Rebekah Brooks arrested | work=The Telegraph | date = 17 July 2011 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8643449/Phone-hacking-Rebekah-Brooks-arrested.html | accessdate =17 July 2011 | location=London | first=Raf | last=Sanchez}}</ref> by detectives working on [[Operation Weeting]], the Metropolitan Police's phone hacking investigation, and [[Operation Elveden]], the probe examining illicit payments to police officers.<ref name="arrest3">{{cite news | title = Rebekah Brooks arrested over phone hacking and corruption allegations | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 17 July 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/17/rebekah-brooks-arrested-over-phone-hacking-and-corruption-allegations/ | accessdate =17 July 2011 }}</ref>
Following twelve hours in custody, Brooks was released on bail until late October.<ref name="brooksbail">{{cite news | title = Rebekah Brooks released on bail | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 18 July 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/18/rebekah-brooks-released-on-bail/ | accessdate =18 July 2011 }}</ref>
On 18 July, police reported the discovery of a rubbish bag containing a laptop, documents, a phone dumped in an underground parking garage near Brooks' home.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/detectives-seize-computer-found-in-bin-near-brooks-flat-20110719-1hnae.html |title=Detectives seize computer found in bin near Brooks' flat |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=18 August 2011 |date=20 July 2011}}</ref> Brooks' husband had initially tried to claim the trash bag, which he said contained his property unrelated to the investigation.<ref>{{cite news|last=Evans |first=Martin |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8647877/Phone-Hacking-Brooks-husband-denies-cover-up-after-bag-found-near-flat.html |title=Phone Hacking: Brooks' husband denies cover up after bag found near flat |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=20 July 2011 |accessdate=18 August 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
Ms. Brooks was arrested again in March 2012, this time on suspicion of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sabbagh, Dan and Josh Halliday and Vikram Dodd|title=Rebekah Brooks and husband arrested in new twist in phone-hacking inquiry|newspaper=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/mar/13/rebekah-brooks-and-husband-arrested-phone-hacking|date=13 March 2012|accessdate=20 May 2012|location=London}}</ref> Her husband, [[Charles Patrick Evelyn Brooks|Charlie Brooks]], was arrested with her. Two months later, on 15 May 2012, they were both [[Phone hacking scandal reference lists#Charged with crimes|charged along with four others]] with conspiracy to pervert the course of justice by allegedly removing documents and computers from ''News International'' offices to conceal them from investigating detectives.<ref name=GuardianBrooks20120515xx>{{cite news|last=Laville|first=Sandra|title=Rebekah Brooks charged with perverting the course of justice|newspaper=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/may/15/rebekah-brooks-charged-perverting-course-justice|date=15 May 2012|accessdate=20 May 2012|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Burns, John F. |author2=Alan Cowell |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Top Murdoch Aide Is Charged in Hacking Case|newspaper= The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/16/world/europe/rebekah-brooks-to-learn-if-she-will-face-charges.html?pagewanted=all|date=15 May 2012|accessdate=20 May 2012}}</ref>
====Stuart Kuttner, Greg Miskiw, James Desborough, Dan Evans and others==== [[Stuart Kuttner]], the former managing editor of the ''News of the World'', was arrested on 2 August 2011 on suspicion of conspiring to intercept communications and on suspicion of corruption. He was arrested by appointment at a London police station by [[Operation Weeting]] and [[Operation Elveden]] detectives.<ref name="kuttner1">{{cite news | first = Amelia | last = Hill | title = Phone-hacking scandal: Stuart Kuttner is latest NoW exec to be arrested | work=The Guardian | date = 2 August 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/aug/02/phone-hacking-stuart-kuttner-arrested | accessdate =2 August 2011 | location=London}}</ref><ref name="kuttner2">{{cite news | title = Police arrest former News of the World managing editor | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 2 August 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/08/02/police-arrest-former-news-of-the-world-managing-editor/ | accessdate =2 August 2011 }}</ref> (Kuttner was re-arrested 30 August, for further questioning.<ref name="kuttner3">{{cite news | title = Former NOTW managing editor Stuart Kuttner is re-arrested| work=The Independent| publisher=Independent Press| date = 31 August 2011 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/former-notw/-managing-editor-stuart-kuttner-is-re-arrested-2346592.html | accessdate =1 September 2011 | location=London | first=Andy | last=McSmith}}</ref>) On 24 July 2012, he was formally charged with conspiracy to intercept communications between 3 October 2000 to 9 August 2006 without lawful authority regarding communications of [[Murder of Milly Dowler|Milly Dowler]] and [[David Blunkett]], MP.<ref name="CPS20120724">{{cite press release|title=Alison Levitt QC's announcement on charges arising from Operation Weeting|url=http://blog.cps.gov.uk/|date=24 July 2012|publisher=Crown Prosecution Service|accessdate=24 July 2012}}</ref><ref name="GuardianCharged20120724">{{cite news|title=Phone hacking: full list of charges|newspaper=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/jul/24/phone-hacking-charges|date=24 July 2012|accessdate=24 July 2012}}</ref>
Eight days later, [[Greg Miskiw]], a former ''News of the World'' news editor, was arrested on suspicion of unlawful interception of communications and conspiring to intercept communications. He was arrested by appointment at a London police station by detectives working on Operation Weeting, the police investigation into phone hacking.<ref name="miskiw1">{{cite news | title = Phone hacking: former News of the World news editor Greg Miskiw arrested | work=The Daily Telegraph | date = 10 August 2011 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8693486/Phone-hacking-former-News-of-the-World-news-editor-Greg-Miskiw-arrested.html | accessdate =10 August 2011 | location=London}}</ref><ref name="miskiw2">{{cite news | title = Former News of the World news editor arrested | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 10 August 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/08/11/former-news-of-the-world-news-editor-arrested/ | accessdate =10 August 2011 }}</ref> On 24 July 2012, he was charged with conspiracy to intercept communications without lawful authority during the period from 3 October 2000 to 9 August 2006 from the phones of [[Murder of Milly Dowler|Milly Dowler]], [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]], [[Abi Titmus|Abigail Titmuss]], John Leslie Andrew Gilchrist, [[David Blunkett]] MP, [[Delia Smith]], [[Charles Clarke]] MP, [[Jude Law]], [[Sadie Frost]], [[Sienna Miller]], and [[Wayne Rooney]] .<ref name="CPS20120724"/><ref name="GuardianCharged20120724"/>
[[James Desborough]] was arrested after arriving, by appointment, at a south London police station the morning of 18 August 2011 for questioning concerning criminal activities at the ''News of the World''. His arrest was based on suspicion of conspiring to intercept communications. Desborough was promoted to be the newspaper's Los Angeles-based US editor in 2009. Prior to that appointment, he was an award-winning show-business reporter based in London. <ref name="desborough">{{cite news | first = Amelia | last = Hill | title = Phone hacking: News of the World Hollywood reporter is arrested| work=The Guardian | date = 18 August 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/aug/18/phone-hacking-news-of-the-world| accessdate =18 August 2011 | location=London}}</ref>
Dan Evans, a former reporter for ''News of the World'', was arrested and later bailed on 19 August 2011.<ref>{{cite news |title=Phone hacking: Met police detective arrested |author=James Robinson |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/aug/19/phone-hacking-detective-arrested |newspaper=The Guardian |date=19 August 2011 |accessdate=19 August 2011 |location=London}}</ref> An unnamed 30-year-old man was arrested and later bailed on 2 September 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14766406 |title=Phone hacking: Man bailed in News of the World probe |date=2 September 2011 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref>
In an early morning raid on his North London home on 7 September 2011, deputy football editor of ''[[The Times]]'' Raoul Simons (on extended leave from his job since September 2010) was arrested and held for questioning on suspicion of conspiracy to intercept voicemail messages by police officers from Operation Weeting.<ref name="raoul">{{cite news|title=Times deputy football editor held in pre-dawn raid by phone hacking detectives|work= Daily Mail| date = 8 September 2011| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2034279/Phone-hacking-scandal-The-Times-deputy-football-editor-sixteenth-person-arrested-probe.html| accessdate=8 September 2011| location=London| first1=Kirsty| last1=Walker| first2=Oliver| last2=Pickup}}</ref>
A reporter working for ''The Sun'' was arrested and taken to a southwest London police station at 10.30 am on 4 November 2011. The man is the sixth person to be arrested in the UK under the ''News International''-related legal probe, Operation Elveden.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hughes |first=Mark |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8869598/Sun-journalist-arrested-over-payments-to-police.html |title='Sun journalist' arrested over 'payments to police' |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=4 November 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011 |location=London}}</ref> The 48-year-old ''The Sun'' journalist Jamie Pyatt had been arrested by detectives on 4 November 2011 investigating illegal payments to police officers by journalists and has been released on bail.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hughes |first=Mark |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8869998/Sun-journalist-arrested-by-police-named-as-Jamie-Pyatt.html |title=Sun journalist arrested by police named as Jamie Pyatt |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=4 November 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/home/uk-news/article/16103268 |title=Police Payments: Sun Reporter Bailed By Met |publisher=Sky News |date= 5 November 2011|accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://journalisted.com/jamie-pyatt |title=Jamie Pyatt |publisher=journalisted.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}{{verify source|date=April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-11-10/news-corp-inquiry-turns-on-staff-ahead-of-u-k-hearing.html |title=News Corp. Inquiry Turns on Staff Ahead of U.K. Hearing |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date=8 December 2009 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/oct/31/phone-hacking-milly-dowler-police | location=London | title = Phone hacking: Milly Dowler police investigation may have been targeted | work = The Guardian | first=James | last=Robinson | date=31 October 2011}}</ref>
====Jonathan Rees and Alex Marunchak==== On 2 October 2012, two individuals associated with the [[News media phone hacking scandal#Operation Nigeria|earliest investigations (1999) into the phone hacking scandal]] were arrested. Private investigator [[Jonathan Rees]] and ''[[News of the World]]'' journalist Alex Marunchak were arrested for alleged offences under section 3 of the Computer Misuse Act 1990 and sections 1 and 2 of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 by police officers working on [[Operation Kalmyk]], part of [[Operation Tuleta]] dealing with computer hacking.<ref name=GuardianRees20121002>{{cite news|author1=Dodd, Vikram |author2=Jason Deans |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Alex Marunchak and Jonathan Rees held as part of Operation Kalmyk|newspaper=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/02/alex-marunchak-jonathan-rees-operation-kalmy |date=2 October 2012|accessdate=2 October 2012}}</ref> These arrests came thirteen years after Rees' premises were raided under Operation Nigeria, during which large amounts of evidence indicating widespread illegal trafficking in confidential information was seized by the [[Metropolitan Police Service]]. Marunchak was arrested by Scotland Yard detectives on 2 October 2012 and remained on bail for 23 months until 16 September 2014 when he was released from bail. In a formal letter to him the following year, on 9 September 2015, the Crown Prosecution Service stated it had "concluded that there is insufficient evidence to provide a realistic prospect of conviction in respect of offences contrary to the Computer Misuse Act (for ‘computer hacking’ offences)", "that there is insufficient evidence to provide a realistic prospect of conviction for any associated or alternative offences" and "that no further action be taken in relation to this matter." Despite Marunchak's arrest in 2012 he was never charged nor brought to court.<ref name=PGPons>{{cite web |author=Dominic Ponsford|url=http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/former-news-world-executive-editor-alex-marunchak-cleared-computer-hacking-three-years-after-his |title=Former NoW executive editor Alex Marunchak in the clear on computer hacking three years after his arrest |date=9 September 2015|accessdate=11 November 2015|work=[[Press Gazette]]}}</ref>
===Murdochs and Brooks summonsed <!-- The word is summonsed, it's not a typo -->to Parliament=== On 14 July, the [[Culture, Media and Sport Committee]] of the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] served a [[summons]] on Rupert Murdoch, James Murdoch and Rebekah Brooks, expecting them to appear before the parliamentary committee on 19 July. After an initial invitation to give evidence to the committee, Brooks stated she would attend but the Murdochs declined. Rupert Murdoch claimed to be unavailable on that date but said he would be "fully prepared" to give evidence in Leveson's inquiry, while James Murdoch offered to appear on an alternative date, the earliest of which was 10 August. The Murdochs did, however, later confirm they would attend after the committee issued them a summons to Parliament.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-14148658 Phone hacking: Murdochs agree to appear before MPs]. [[BBC News]], 14 July 2011. Retrieved 18 July 2011.</ref>
[[Tom Watson (Labour politician)|Tom Watson]] and Martin Hickman report in their book ''Dial M For Murdoch'' that:
<blockquote>Unbeknown to members of the Culture Committee, the NOTW established a team to investigate their private lives. For several days, as chief reporter Neville Thurlbeck would later tell Tom Watson, reporters searched for any secret lovers or extra-marital affairs that could be used as leverage against the MPs.
Thurlbeck said: "All I know is that, when the DCMS [Department of Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee] was formed or rather when it got onto all the hacking stuff, there was an edict came down from the editor and it was find out every single thing you can about every single member: who was gay, who had affairs, anything we can use.
"Each reporter was given two members and there were six reporters that went on for around 10 days. I don't know who looked at you. It fell by the wayside; I think even Ian Edmondson [the news editor] realised there was something quite horrible about doing this."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/exclusive-extracts-from-dial-m-for-murdoch-7661728.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Tom | last=Watson | date=20 April 2012 | title=Exclusive extracts from 'Dial M for Murdoch'}}</ref></blockquote>
At their appearance before the committee, Rupert Murdoch said it had been "the most humble day of my life" and argued that since he ran a global business of 53,000 employees and that the ''News of the World'' was "just 1 percent" of this, he was not ultimately responsible for what went on at the tabloid; he added that he had not considered resigning. Meanwhile, his son James described the "illegal voicemail interceptions" as a "matter of great regret" but that the company was "determined to put things right and make sure they do not happen again". James Murdoch stated that News International had based its "push back" against new allegations on the combination of three pieces of evidence: that the Metropolitan Police had closed their investigation, that the Crown Prosecution Service had closed their prosecution and that they had received written advice from their legal advisors Harbottle & Lewis, that there was nothing to suggest phone hacking was not the work of one "rogue reporter" working with private investigator Glenn Mulcaire.<ref name=BBC14195259>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-14195259|title=Phone hacking: 'Humbled' Murdoch rejects blame|publisher=BBC News |date=19 July 2011|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref> Towards the end of the Murdochs' two hours of evidence, a protestor sitting in the public gallery, identified as comedian Jonnie Marbles, threw a [[Shaving cream|shaving-foam]] pie at Rupert Murdoch.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8648117/News-of-the-World-phone-hacking-live.html|title=Rupert Murdoch attacked by protester|date=19 July 2011|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=19 July 2011|location=London|first=Andrew|last=Hough}}</ref> The incident propelled Murdoch's wife, [[Wendi Deng Murdoch]], into the media spotlight for her athletic response in defence of her husband.<ref>{{cite news|title=Protester Attacks Rupert Murdoch in UK Parliament|url=http://www.newsmax.com/Newsfront/rupertmurdoch-pieattack/2011/07/19/id/404155|accessdate=20 August 2011|newspaper=NewsMax|year=2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wendi Deng: just who is the smack-down sister?|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/wendi-deng-just-who-is-the-smack-down-sister|accessdate=20 August 2011|newspaper=Channel 4 News|year=2011}}</ref> Marbles later said that he had "much respect" for Deng for fighting back.<ref>{{cite news|title=Murdoch pie thrower has respect for Wendi|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/murdoch-pie-thrower-has-respect-for-wendi|accessdate=23 July 2011|newspaper=Channel 4 News|year=2011}}</ref> Marbles, real name Jonathan May-Bowles, was sentenced to six weeks in prison for the attack.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14370398 |title=Murdoch foam attack: 'Jonnie Marbles' jailed |date=2 August 2011 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2 August 2011}}</ref>
Harbottle & Lewis later commented that it could not respond to "any inaccurate statements or contentions" about the 2007 letter to News International due to client confidentiality.<ref name=BBC14195259/> Later on the same day, giving evidence to the Home Affairs Select Committee, former director of public prosecutions Lord MacDonald stated that it took him "three to five minutes" to decide that the same emails contained in the file passed to Harbottle & Lewis contained "blindingly obvious" evidence of corrupt payments to police officers, which had to be immediately passed to the Metropolitan Police.<ref name=GuardMacD110719>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/19/news-corp-police-payments-macdonald|title=News Corp board shocked at evidence of payments to police, says former DPP|author=Owen Bowcott|work=The Guardian |location=UK|date=19 July 2011|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=BBC14197962>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-14197962 |title=Ex-Met Police chief denies 'swipe' at prime minister |publisher=BBC News |date=20 July 2011 |accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
Brooks answered questions at the committee after the Murdochs and independently of them.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2011/07/19/live-blog-police-murdoch-brooks-to-testify-in-phone-hacking-scandal/|title=Murdochs, Brooks, Police testify in phone-hacking scandal|date=19 July 2011|publisher=CNN|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/20/world/europe/20hacking.html |title=Murdochs Say Top Executives Didn't Know of Phone Hacking|date=19 July 2011|work=The New York Times|accessdate=19 July 2011|first=Sarah|last=Lyall}}</ref> She began by calling the practice of phone hacking at the newspaper she edited as "pretty horrific".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2011/07/19/general-broadcasting-amp-entertainment-eu-britain-phone-hacking_8572873.html |title=Rebekah Brooks testifies to UK lawmakers |date=19 July 2011 |work=Forbes |accessdate=19 July 2011 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Upon questioning, she confirmed that under her editorship she knew the ''News of the World'' hired private detectives but denied having ever met Glenn Mulcaire.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0719/hacking_tracker.html|title=Live – Hacking Inquiry|date=19 July 2011|publisher=RTÉ News |accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref>
The testimony of James Murdoch was questioned by two former News International executives. Murdoch had denied reading or being aware of an email, sent after he authorised an out-of-court payment to Gordon Taylor over the hacking of his phone, which suggested the practice was more widely used than just by a rogue ''News of the World'' reporter. A former editor of the newspaper, Colin Myler and Tom Crone, the former News International legal manager, both said they "did inform" him of the email.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14242763 |title=James Murdoch evidence questioned by former executives |publisher=BBC News |date=21 July 2011 |accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref>
===News Corporation's management standards committee=== On 18 July, News Corporation announced that its UK management standards committee would be removed from News International. It will now be housed in a separate building,<ref name=BBC14183505/> under the chairmanship of [[Anthony Grabiner, Baron Grabiner|Lord Grabiner]], and reporting to News Corporation director [[Joel Klein]]. As a result, existing News International executives Will Lewis and Simon Greenberg will resign their existing positions with News International and become News Corporation employees, focused initially on the clean-up of News International.<ref name=BBC14183505>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-14183505|title=BSkyB: Decision expected on James Murdoch's role|first=Robert |last=Peston |authorlink=Robert Peston |publisher=BBC News |date=18 July 2011|accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref> In September 2011 it was reported that the MSC was not issuing employees of News International who had had their contracts terminated with the reasons for their dismissal in case this would compromise the ongoing police inquiry.<ref>{{cite news |title=Phone hacking: Neville Thurlbeck says 'truth will out' |author=Lisa O'Carroll |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/sep/30/phone-hacking-neville-thurlbeck |newspaper=The Guardian |date=30 September 2011 |accessdate=30 September 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
===Death of Sean Hoare=== On 18 July, former ''News of the World'' journalist [[Sean Hoare]], who was the first reporter to tell of "endemic" phone hacking at the publication for which he used to work, was found dead at his home in [[Watford]], Hertfordshire. A police spokesperson said the death was treated as "unexplained" but not suspicious.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14194623 |title=NoW phone-hacking whistle-blower Sean Hoare found dead |publisher=BBC News |date=19 July 2011 |accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Amelia Hill, James Robinson |author2=Caroline Davies |lastauthoramp=yes |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/18/news-of-the-world-sean-hoare |title=News of the World phone-hacking whistleblower found dead |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=18 August 2011 |date=18 July 2011}}</ref> In November 2011, the coroner for Hertfordshire concluded that Hoare died of natural causes after suffering from liver disease.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-NoW reporter Sean Hoare 'died of natural causes'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15855935|newspaper=BBC News|date=23 November 2011|accessdate=19 August 2014}}</ref>
===''Daily Mirror'' allegations=== [[File:Piers Morgan - 2011 cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Piers Morgan]] was editor of ''The Daily Mirror'' from 1995 to 2004]] On 20 July, ''[[Private Eye]]'' asked how the ''[[Sunday Mirror]]'' had, early in 2003, obtained a transcript of phone calls by [[Angus Deayton]] and in October 2003 had come into possession of every call and text message made by [[Rio Ferdinand]] one afternoon (when he claimed to have missed a drugs test due to having his mobile switched off). The latter story was co-written by [[James Weatherup]], who moved to the ''[[News of the World]]'' the following year.<ref>''[[Private Eye]]'', "Brooks and Brooksmen", issue 1293, p9</ref>
On 22 July, former ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' financial journalist [[James Hipwell]] spoke to ''[[The Independent]]'', claiming that the practice had been "endemic" at the Mirror during his time there under the editorship of [[Piers Morgan]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Former-Mirror-Reporter-James-Hipwell-Makes-New-Hacking-Claim-Against-Daily-Mirror/Article/201107416035919?lpos=UK_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_16035919_Former_Mirror_Reporter_James_Hipwell_Makes_New_Hacking_Claim_Against_Daily_Mirror |title=Ex-Mirror Journalist Makes New Hacking Claim |work=Sky News |date=23 July 2011 |accessdate=23 July 2011 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name=Independent>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/press/hacking-was-endemic-at-the-mirror-says-former-reporter-2319039.html|title= Hacking was endemic at the 'Mirror', says former reporter|first= James|last= Burrell|first2= Ian|last2= Burrell|publisher=Independent Print Limited|work=The Independent |location=UK |date= 23 July 2011|accessdate=23 July 2011}}</ref> {{cquote|"They would call a celebrity with one phone and when it was answered they would then hang up. . . . After they'd hacked into someone's mobile, they'd delete the message so another paper couldn't get the story. There was great hilarity about it."<ref>[[Press Association]], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 23 July 2011, [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/23/phone-hacking-piers-morgan-mirror Phone hacking also rife under Piers Morgan at Mirror, claims ex-reporter]</ref>}}
He also alleged that phone hacking took place at some of the Mirror's sister publications. [[Trinity Mirror]], the publisher of the ''Daily Mirror'' and ''Sunday Mirror'', rejected Hipwell's claims. A spokesman said: "Our position is clear.... Our journalists work within the criminal law and the Press Complaints Commission code of conduct."<ref name=Independent/> The BBC's ''[[Newsnight]]'' programme reported other sources at the ''Sunday Mirror'' confirming use of phone hacking, with one source saying "At one point in 2004, it seemed like it was the only way people were getting scoops." It was also said that the paper made use of private investigators.<ref>''The Guardian'', 23 July 2011, [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/23/phone-hacking-sunday-mirror-newsnight Phone hacking used by Sunday Mirror, claims BBC Newsnight]</ref> On 26 July Trinity Mirror announced an internal review of its editorial procedures.<ref>''[[The Guardian]]'', 26 July 2011, [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/26/daily-mirror-publisher-to-review-editorial-controls Daily Mirror publisher to review editorial controls]</ref>
On 3 August, [[Heather Mills]] alleged that a senior journalist working for Trinity Mirror had admitted to her in 2001 that the company had access to voicemail messages which they knew to have been obtained by hacking. In response Trinity Mirror repeated the statement used in rejecting James Hipwell's claims, saying "Our position is clear. All our journalists work within the criminal law and the PCC code of conduct."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14393925 |title=Heather Mills 'told she was phone-hacking target' |date=3 August 2011 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=3 August 2011}}</ref>
Also on 3 August, [[Piers Morgan]] issued a statement through CNN, his employer, that "I have never hacked a phone, told anyone to hack a phone, nor to my knowledge published any story obtained from the hacking of a phone."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/05/world/europe/05hacking.html?pagewanted=all |title=Calls for CNN Host to Testify in Hacking Scandal |author=Burns, John F. |date =4 August 2011 |work=The New York Times| accessdate=5 August 2011}}</ref> The statement omitted comment on whether he had any knowledge of phone hacking by employees or paid contractors of the Mirror during the period he was editor there.
That Morgan did have knowledge of phone hacking is suggested in his own 2006 article in the ''Daily Mail'', regarding a phone message from [[Paul McCartney]] to his girlfriend Heather Mills in which Morgan stated, "At one stage I was played a tape of a message Paul had left for Heather on her mobile phone. It was heartbreaking. . . The couple had clearly had a tiff, Heather had fled to India, and Paul was pleading with her to come back. He sounded lonely, miserable and desperate, and even sang 'We Can Work It Out ' into the answer phone."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-411323/Im-sorry-Macca-introducing-monster.html |title=I'm sorry, Macca, for introducing you to this monster |author=Morgan, Piers |date=19 October 2006 | work=Daily Mail |accessdate=5 August 2011 |location=London}}</ref> On 3 August, Heather Mills told BBC's Newsnight: "There was absolutely no honest way that Piers Morgan could have obtained that tape ... unless they had gone into my voice messages."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14393925 |title=Heather Mills 'told she was phone-hacking target' | date=3 August 2011 |publisher=BBC News | accessdate=5 August 2011}}</ref>
===Harbottle and Lewis=== During the internal investigation into the unfair dismissal claim against News Group Newspapers Limited by Clive Goodman, News International hired law firm [[Harbottle & Lewis]] (H&L) and passed on hundreds of internal emails to them.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2015461/News-World-phone-hacking-Why-did-Prince-Williams-lawyers-hide-evidence.html|title = Why did Prince William's lawyers hide hacking evidence? Firm that advises Royals entangled in row over 'cover up'|work=Daily Mail |location=UK|date=17 July 2011|accessdate=1 August 2011|first=Glen|last=Owen}}</ref> Lawrence Abramson of [[Harbottle & Lewis]] wrote a letter on 29 May 2007, to News International head of legal affairs Jon Chapman which said that they had
{{cquote|reviewed e-mails to which you have provided access from the accounts of Andy Coulson, Stuart Kuttner, Ian Edmondson, Clive Goodman, Neil Wallis, Jules Stenson... did not find anything in those e-mails which appeared to us to be reasonable evidence that Clive Goodman's illegal actions were known about and supported by both or either of Andy Coulson, the editor, and Neil Wallis, the deputy editor, and/or that Ian Edmondson, the news editor, and others were carrying out similar illegal procedures.<ref name="smoking gun">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-14099102|title=News International found 'smoking gun' e-mails in 2007|publisher=BBC News |date=12 July 2011 |accessdate=17 July 2011}}</ref>}}
The letter from Mr Abramson to Mr Chapman makes no mention of whether the e-mails contain evidence of wrongdoing by journalists other than Mr Goodman.<ref name="smoking gun" />
