{{about|the dance|the album by Kenny Barron|Quickstep (album)|the cycling team|Quick Step}} [[File:Ballroom.jpg|thumb|200px|Quickstep]] [[File:Quick Step dance pattern.png|thumb|right|250px|"Quick Step" dance [[rhythm]] figure.<ref name="Blatter">Blatter, Alfred (2007). ''Revisiting Music Theory: A Guide to the Practice'', p.28. {{ISBN|0-415-97440-2}}.</ref>]]
The '''quickstep''' is a light-hearted [[dance]] of the standard [[ballroom dance]]s. The movement of the dance is fast and powerfully flowing and sprinkled with [[syncopation]]s. The upbeat [[melodies]] that quickstep is danced to make it suitable for both formal and informal events. Quickstep was developed in the 1920s in [[New York City]] and was first danced by Caribbean and African dancers. Its origins are in combination of slow [[foxtrot]] combined with the [[Charleston (dance)|Charleston]], a dance which was one of the precursors to what today is called [[swing dancing]].
==History== The quickstep evolved in the 1920s from a combination of the [[foxtrot]], [[Charleston (dance)|Charleston]], [[Collegiate shag (dance)|shag]], [[Peabody (dance)|peabody]], and [[One-Step|one-step]]. The dance is English in origin and was standardized in 1927. While it evolved from the foxtrot, the quickstep now is quite separate. Unlike the modern foxtrot, the man often closes his feet, and [[syncopated step]]s are regular occurrences (as was the case in early foxtrot). Three characteristic dance figures of the quickstep are the [[chassé]]s, where the feet are brought together, the [[quarter turns]], and the [[Lock step (dance move)|lock step]].<ref name=VS>Silvester, Victor 1982. ''Modern ballroom dancing: history and practice''. Paul, London.</ref><sup>p126</sup>
This dance gradually evolved into a very dynamic one with a lot of movement on the dance floor, with many advanced patterns including hops, runs, quick steps with a lot of momentum, and rotation. The tempo of quickstep dance is rather brisk, as it was developed to [[ragtime]] era [[jazz]] music, which is fast-paced when compared to other dance music.
By the end of the 20th century the complexity of quickstep as done by advanced dancers had increased, with the extensive use of syncopated steps with [[eighth note]] durations. While in older times quickstep patterns were counted with "quick" (one beat) and "slow" (two beats) steps, many advanced patterns today are cued with split beats, such as "quick-and-quick-and-quick, quick, slow", with there being further steps on the 'and's.
==Style== The quickstep is elegant like the [[foxtrot]] and should be smooth and glamorous. The dancers should appear to be very light on their feet. It is very energetic and form-intensive.{{citation needed|date=July 2009}} The quickstep is danced to 4/4 music of 48-52 measures per minute.<ref name=BallroomGuide>{{cite web|title=Ballroom Guide - Dance Music!|url=http://ballroomguide.com/resources/music.html|website=Ballroom Guide|publisher=Ballroom Guide|accessdate=24 May 2015}}</ref>
==Syllabus== The two [[International Style (dance)|International Style]] syllabi of [[Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing|ISTD]] and [[IDTA]] for quickstep differ very little.
The [[American Style]] [[dance competition]] program does not include quickstep, but a limited version of the dance is taught and [[social dance|danced socially]] in some American dance venues.
===Pre-bronze=== # Quarter turn to right # Natural turn # Natural turn with hesitation # Natural pivot turn # Natural spin turn # Progressive chassé # Chassé reverse turn # Forward lock # Heel pivot (quarter turn to left)
===Bronze=== # Closed impetus # Back lock # Reverse pivot # Progressive chassé to right # Tipple chassé to right # Running finish # Natural turn and back lock # Double reverse spin # Zig-zag, back lock, and running Finish # Cross chassé # Change of direction
===Silver=== # Quick open reverse # Fishtail # Running right turn # Four quick run # [[V6 (quickstep)|V6]] # Closed telemark
===Gold=== # Cross swivel # Six quick run # Rumba cross # Tipsy to right # Tipsy to left # Hover corté
==References== {{reflist}}

{{use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The Star Wars Holiday Special | image = StarWarsHS.jpg | caption = {{Plainlist| * An advertisement for the special in a * 1978 ''TV Guide'' }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * [[Pat Proft]] * Leonard Ripps * [[Bruce Vilanch]] * [[Rod Warren]] * Mitzie Welch }} | director = {{Plainlist| * [[Steve Binder]] * [[David Acomba]] {{small|(uncredited)}} }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Harrison Ford]] * [[Peter Mayhew]] * [[Mark Hamill]] * [[Carrie Fisher]] * [[Anthony Daniels]] * Mickey Morton * Paul Gale * [[Patty Maloney]] * [[Art Carney]] * [[Bea Arthur]] * [[Diahann Carroll]] * [[Harvey Korman]] * [[Jefferson Starship]] * [[David Prowse]] }} | voices = {{Plainlist| * Mark Hamill * Harrison Ford * Carrie Fisher * Anthony Daniels * [[James Earl Jones]] * [[Don Francks]] }} | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * Gary Smith * [[Dwight Hemion]] }} | producer = {{Plainlist| * Joe Layton * Jeff Starsh * Ken Welch * Mitzie Welch }} | country = United States | language = English | company = {{Plainlist| * Smith-[[Dwight Hemion]] Productions * Winters Hollywood Entertainment Holdings Corporation * [[20th Century Fox Television]] * [[Nelvana]] {{small|(animated segment)}} }} | channel = [[CBS]] | released = {{Film date|y=TV|1978|11|17}} | runtime = 98 minutes | composer = {{Plainlist| * [[John Williams]] * {{small|(''[[Star Wars]]'' theme)}} * [[Ian Fraser (composer)|Ian Fraser]] * {{small|(Score)}} * Ken Welch * Mitzie Welch * {{small|(Songs)}} }} }} '''''The Star Wars Holiday Special''''' is a 1978 American [[Musical film|musical]] [[Science fiction film|science fiction]] [[television film]] set in the [[Star Wars galaxy|''Star Wars'' galaxy]]. It stars [[Star Wars (film)|the original film]]'s main cast, [[Chewbacca]]'s family, and introduces [[Boba Fett]], who would appear in later films. It is the first official ''[[Star Wars]]'' [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] film and was directed by [[Steve Binder]].
In the storyline that ties the special together, following the events of the original film, Chewbacca and [[Han Solo]] attempt to visit [[Kashyyyk|the Wookiee home world]] to celebrate "Life Day". They are pursued by agents of the [[Galactic Empire (Star Wars)|Galactic Empire]], who are searching for members of the [[Rebel Alliance]] on the planet. The special introduces three members of Chewbacca's family: his father Itchy, his wife [[Chewbacca#Expanded Universe|Malla]], and his son [[Lumpawarrump|Lumpy]].
The program also features the rest of the main ''Star Wars'' characters, including [[Luke Skywalker]], [[C-3PO]], [[R2-D2]], [[Darth Vader]] and [[Princess Leia]], all portrayed by the original cast. The program includes footage from the 1977 film, and a [[Animated cartoon|cartoon]] produced by [[Toronto]]-based [[Nelvana]] featuring the [[bounty hunter]] Boba Fett. A few scenes take place in space and in spacecraft including the ''[[Millennium Falcon]]'' and a [[Star Destroyer]]. The variety show segments and cartoon also take place in a few other locales, such as the [[Mos Eisley]] cantina seen in the original film, and a newly introduced red [[ocean planet]] known as Panna.
The special is notorious for its extremely negative reception and has never been rebroadcast or officially released on home video.<ref name="abc1">{{cite news|publisher=[[ABC News]]|title=Holiday Specials Gone Bad; The 'Star Wars Holiday Special' Flop Lives On|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Nightline/story?id=4034365&page=1|date=December 20, 2007|first=John|last=Berman|author2=Ted Gerstein|accessdate=October 15, 2007}}</ref><ref name=Hofstede>{{cite book|author=David Hofstede|title=What Were They Thinking? The 100 Dumbest Events in Television History|publisher=Back Stage Books|year=2004|pages=204–206|isbn=0-8230-8441-8}}</ref> It has, therefore, become something of a cultural legend, because of the [[Underground film|underground]] quality of its existence. It has been viewed and distributed in off-air recordings made from its original telecast by fans as [[Bootleg recording|bootleg copies]], and later adapted to content-sharing websites.
==Plot== On Life Day, Chewbacca, accompanied by Han Solo, is headed home to see his family. Along the way, the duo are chased by two [[Star Destroyer]]s, but they escape into [[Hyperspace (science fiction)#Star Wars|hyperspace]].
Meanwhile, on [[Kashyyyk]], Chewbacca's family is preparing for his return. Hoping to find the ''[[Millennium Falcon]]'', his wife, Malla, runs a computer scan for starships in the area but is unsuccessful. Malla contacts [[Luke Skywalker]], who, along with [[R2-D2]], is working on his [[X-wing]] starfighter. Luke tells her that he does not know what happened. Malla contacts Saun Dann, a local human trader. He tells her through a carefully worded message that Han and Chewbacca are on their way and should be arriving soon. Malla then attempts (unsuccessfully) to prepare a meal, the instructions of which are being aired via a local cooking show by an eccentric four-armed alien cook, Chef Gormaanda ([[Harvey Korman]]).
Saun arrives with Life Day gifts for everyone, including a virtual reality fantasy program (featuring [[Diahann Carroll]]) for Itchy. Back on the ''Falcon'', Chewbacca and Han have just come out of hyperspace not far from Kashyyyk. Han notices an increased Imperial presence, so they decide to land in an unguarded area to the north. As they enter the atmosphere, Lumpy hears the roaring of the ship. Believing Han and Chewie might be arriving, Malla opens the door, but instead finds two [[Stormtrooper (Star Wars)|stormtroopers]] and officers.
The Imperials force their way into the house. An officer orders a search for Chewbacca. As they search, Saun and the others attempt to distract them with food and Malla's music video box (which features a video by [[Jefferson Starship]]). When the music finishes, the head officer orders the search to continue. The head officer tells Malla to keep Lumpy busy while they search his room, so Lumpy (and the viewing audience) watches a [[Animated cartoon|cartoon]] on a viewscreen of one of his father's many adventures:
:During a search for a [[talisman]], the ''Millennium Falcon'' crashes on the water planet of Panna. Upon landing, they run into [[Boba Fett]], who claims to want to help them after saving Luke from a giant monster that attacks him from behind. They all board the ''Falcon'', where Han has been infected by a mysterious sleeping virus caused by the talisman. Luke then contracts the virus as well.
:Fett and Chewie go into Panna City to get the cure. Once they get into the Imperial-occupied city, Fett instructs Chewie to stay behind while he gets the cure, and contacts [[Darth Vader]]. On the ''Falcon'', as C-3PO is caring for Han and Luke, R2-D2 intercepts the call between Vader and Fett, causing worry for C-3PO. Evading the Imperials, Fett and Chewie return to the ''Falcon'' with the cure. After everyone recovers from the virus, they learn of Fett's true allegiances. Fett blasts away in his jetpack, promising that they'll meet again. Everyone then escapes from the planet and back to the Rebel base aboard the ''Falcon''.
When the cartoon finishes, Lumpy works to create a translation device from his Amorphian machine that will fool the Imperials into returning to their base by faking their commander's voice. To do so, he first must watch the manual for the device, being presented by a malfunctioning, incompetent robot (also played by Korman).
While the Imperials are searching downstairs, the living room viewscreen activates, announcing that [[Tatooine]] is now being put under curfew by the Empire, because of "[[subversion|subversive]] forces". The video is announced as required viewing for all Imperial forces and much of it features Ackmena ([[Bea Arthur]]) running the [[Mos Eisley]] cantina. Ackmena is approached by an admirer: Krelman, an amorous alien, who has misunderstood something she said to him recently. When the Empire announces the curfew, Ackmena announces [[Last call (bar term)|last call]], and when she is ignored, sings "Good Night, But Not Goodbye".
Lumpy uses this opportunity to put his plan into motion, faking a repeated call for the Imperials to "return to base." They leave, but one stormtrooper stays behind and realizes they were tricked. He finds Lumpy and destroys the machine, then chases Lumpy outside.
As they both run onto the deck, Han and Chewbacca arrive. Chewie protects Lumpy as Han dispatches the stormtrooper. After they are reunited, an Imperial officer appears on the viewscreen, giving a general alert for the missing stormtrooper. Saun quickly responds that the trooper stole supplies and deserted. The danger averted, the family prepares to go to the festival at the great [[Tree of life|Tree of Life]]. They hold glowing orbs, and appear in space wearing red robes.<ref name=latimes>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/herocomplex/la-et-hc-star-wars-holiday-special-20181117-story.html|title=‘The Star Wars Holiday Special’ aired only once. 40 years later, it’s still weird|last=Roy|first=Jessica|date=November 17, 2018|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref>
Wookiees walk into a bright star and arrive at the Tree of Life, where many are gathered, including C-3PO and R2-D2. Luke, Leia, and Han also appear. Leia gives a short speech and sings a song in celebration. Chewie remembers his adventures during the events of the original film. Finally, the Wookiee family sits around a table and bows their heads.
==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Harrison Ford]] as [[Han Solo]] * [[Peter Mayhew]] as [[Chewbacca]] * [[Mark Hamill]] as [[Luke Skywalker]] * [[Carrie Fisher]] as [[Princess Leia]] * [[Anthony Daniels]] as [[C-3PO]] * [[James Earl Jones]] as [[Darth Vader]] (voice) * [[David Prowse]] (''[[archive footage]]'') as [[Darth Vader]] * [[Bea Arthur]] as Ackmena * [[Art Carney]] as Trader Saun Dann * [[Diahann Carroll]] as Mermeia [[Holography|Holographic]] * [[Jefferson Starship]] ([[Marty Balin]], [[Craig Chaquico]], [[Paul Kantner]], [[Pete Sears]], [[John Barbata]]) as Holographic Band * [[Harvey Korman]] as Krelman / Chef Gormaanda / Amorphian instructor * Mickey Morton as Malla * Paul Gale as Itchy * [[Patty Maloney]] as Lumpy * [[Alec Guinness]] (''archive footage'') as [[Obi-Wan Kenobi]] * [[Leslie Schofield]] (''archive footage'') as Chief Moradmin Bast * Yuichi Sugiyama as the "Ring-Master" * [[Jack Ryder (actor)|Jack Ryder]] as Imperial Guard Officer * Lev Mailer and Michael Potter as Imperial Guards * [[Marcus Powell]] as Rycar Ryjerd * Claude Woolman as Imperial Officer {{div col end}} [[Kenny Baker (English actor)|Kenny Baker]], who played {{nowrap|[[R2-D2]]}} in the films, was not involved in the special. The droid was performed entirely by a radio-controlled unit, operated by [[Mick Garris]] (Lucas's receptionist). In the credits, R2-D2 is credited by announcer [[Art James]] as playing himself.
Because James Earl Jones was originally uncredited in ''Star Wars'', the special marked the first time he was credited as the voice of Darth Vader.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://amp.usatoday.com/amp/2027329002|title=Remembering that infamously bad 'Star Wars' holiday special, 40 years later|last=McKairnes|first=Jim|date=November 19, 2018|website=USA Today|accessdate=November 19, 2018}}</ref>
Malla's mask was repurposed from a Chewbacca mask from the original film.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://comicbook.com/starwars/amp/2018/11/20/star-wars-holiday-special-mask-chewbacca-wookiee-malla/|title='Star Wars Holiday Special' Wookiee Mask Gets Impressive Restoration|last=Cavanaugh|first=Patrick|date=November 20, 2018|website=comicbook.com|accessdate=November 20, 2018}}</ref> The names of Chewbacca's family were later explained to have been nicknames, their full names being Mallatobuck (Malla), Attichitcuk (Itchy), and Lumpawarrump or Lumpawaroo (Lumpy).<ref>{{cite book|last=Ehrhardt|first=Eleanor|title=Star Wars: The Wookiee Storybook|publisher=[[Random House]]|year=1979|isbn=0-394-94256-6}}</ref><ref name=itchy>{{cite web|url=https://comicbook.com/starwars/2018/09/18/star-wars-solo-movie-chewbacca-holiday-special-connection/|title='Solo: A Star Wars Story' Bonus Features Confirm Connection to 'Star Wars Holiday Special'|last=Cavanaugh|first=Patrick|date=September 17, 2018|website=comicbook.com|accessdate=November 20, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://screenrant.com/star-wars-aftermath-empires-end-chewbacca-son/|title=Star Wars: Empire's End Confirms Chewbacca Is a Father In New Canon|last=Agar|first=Chris|date=February 21, 2017|website=Screen Rant|accessdate=November 20, 2018}}</ref>
==Production== While outlining the original ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'' and planning its potential sequels, Lucas imagined a "film just about Wookiees, nothing else."<ref>Steranko, "George Lucas", ''Prevue'' #42, September–October 1980.</ref> After the original film's success, its cast made a few appearances on TV [[variety show]]s.<ref name=latimes/> According to Charles Lippincott, who was head of marketing of [[the Star Wars Corporation]], [[CBS]] brought the idea of doing a TV special to him and Lucas, although there is some internal dispute about this claim.<ref name=WeirdTV>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/magazine/2008/12/star_wars_special200812|title=The Han Solo Comedy Hour!|last=Digiacomo|first=Frank|date=December 2008|website=Vanity Fair|accessdate=December 21, 2015}}</ref> According to J.W. Rinzler, "Everybody agreed that a television special was a good idea." Lucas was busy moving his production company to a new location, which was not heavily involved in the special. Though Lucas is uncredited, it was his idea to build the narrative around Chewbacca's family.<ref name=latimes/>
CBS hired experienced variety show writers and producers.<ref name=latimes/> Writer [[Bruce Vilanch]] was concerned about the decision to center the special on a species who grunt in a fictional language without subtitles, and feared that the special would turn into "one long episode of ''[[Lassie (1954 TV series)|Lassie]]''." Regardless, Lucas would not budge on his vision.<ref name=WeirdTV/> The special went through two directors. The first, David Acomba, was brought in through an attempt to "make us different in variety shows", according to Lippencott. Acomba, a classmate of George Lucas at [[USC School of Cinematic Arts|USC film school]], was unfamiliar with a [[multiple-camera setup]], which caused some problems. Acomba also felt that there was a divide between himself and the producers, and chose to leave the project after finishing only a few scenes, including the cantina and Jefferson Starship. He was replaced by [[Steve Binder]], whose only contact with [[Lucasfilm]] was a "Wookiee [[Bible (screenwriting)|bible]]" detailing how the species should look and behave.<ref name=WeirdTV/> [[Stan Winston]] was hired to design the Wookiee family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/72863/dark-side-oral-history-star-wars-holiday-special|title=The Dark Side: An Oral History of The Star Wars Holiday Special|last=Rossen|first=Jake|website=Mental Floss|date=December 3, 2017|accessdate=October 15, 2018}}</ref>
The special was broadcast in its entirety in the United States only once, on Friday, November 17, 1978 (the week before [[Thanksgiving]]), on the television network [[CBS]] from 8:00 pm to 10:00 pm, [[North American Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Standard Time]] (EST), pre-empting ''[[Wonder Woman (TV series)|Wonder Woman]]'' and ''[[The Incredible Hulk (1978 TV series)|The Incredible Hulk]]''. It was also broadcast on the Canadian television network [[CTV Television Network|CTV]] from 7:00 pm to 9:00 pm, Eastern Standard Time.<ref name="abc1"/>, in [[New Zealand]] on [[TVNZ]], and in Australia on the [[Seven Network]].{{cn|date=December 2017}}
==Reception== The ''Star Wars Holiday Special'' has become notorious for its extremely negative reception, both by ''Star Wars'' fans and the general public.<ref name="abc1"/> [[Anthony Daniels]], in a documentary promoting the worldwide tour of ''Star Wars: In Concert'', notes with a laugh that the ''Star Wars'' universe includes "The horrible ''Holiday Special'' that nobody talks about". [[Nathan Rabin]] of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' wrote, "I'm not convinced the special wasn’t ultimately written and directed by a sentient bag of [[cocaine]]."<ref>{{cite web|title=The Star Wars Holiday Special Was the Worst Thing on Television|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/the-star-studded-star-wars-holiday-special-was-the-worst-thing-on-television-ever|last=Pasternack|first=Alex|date=December 24, 2014|publisher=Vice|work=Motherboard|accessdate=October 15, 2018}}</ref> [[George Lucas]] did not have significant involvement with the film's production and was reportedly unhappy with the results; however, [[Patty Maloney]], who played Lumpy, stated in 2008 that Lucas was sent [[dailies]] of each day's shooting for approval.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kirkwood, SKot|date=November 8, 2008|url=http://www.starwarsholidayspecial.com/text/patty_maloney.htm|title=Interview with Patty Maloney, 'Lumpy'|publisher=The Star Wars Holiday Special|accessdate=July 2, 2016}}</ref>
David Hofstede, author of ''What Were They Thinking?: The 100 Dumbest Events in Television History'', ranked the holiday special at number one, calling it "the worst two hours of television ever".<ref name=Hofstede/> [[Shepard Smith]], a news anchor for the [[Fox News Channel]], referred to it as a "'70s train wreck, combining the worst of ''Star Wars'' with the utter worst of [[variety television]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/jppgzd/a-star-wars-holiday-special-you-were-not-supposed-to-see-this|title=In Praise of The Ominous Star Wars Holiday Special|last=Pasternack|first=Alex|date=December 25, 2010|publisher=Vice|work=Motherboard|accessdate=October 15, 2018}}</ref> On the [[review-aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film received a 33% approval rating, based on nine reviews, with an [[average rating]] of 3.5/10.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/star_wars_holiday_special |title=Star Wars: Holiday Special (1978) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]] |accessdate=May 28, 2018}}</ref>
In December 2018, a comedy play will be released about the special's production, entitled ''Special''.<ref name=latimes/>
===Recognition=== The special was ranked at #3 in "The Five Goofiest Moments of the Star Wars Mythos" in the 62nd issue of UK's ''Star Wars'' magazine.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Abel G. Pena and Enrique Guerrero|title=20 Most Memorable Moments of the Expanded Universe|url=https://imgur.com/a/Ifcd5|accessdate=10 January 2018|work=Star Wars Insider|page=47}}</ref> ''[[TV Guide]]'' ranked it at number 11 on their "25 Most Hilarious Holiday TV Moments", mentioning that it was "unintentionally hilarious."<ref name="Night">{{cite web|last1=Thomas|first1=Bryan|title="The Star Wars Holiday Special": The colossally-awful variety show that George Lucas would rather you forget existed|url=http://nightflight.com/the-star-wars-holiday-special-the-colossally-awful-variety-show-that-george-lucas-would-rather-you-forget-existed/|website=Night Flight|accessdate=10 January 2018|date=17 December 2015}}</ref> Both ''TV Guide'' and [[TV Land]] ranked the special at #59 on their "Top 100 Unexpected Television Moments" in a five-part special that aired from December 5 until December 9, 2005.<ref name="Night" /> In a 2008 [[online poll]] on [[Christmas in the media|Christmas specials]] by the [[Paley Center for Media]], ''The Star Wars Holiday Special'' was selected to be shown at the Center by 59% of the voters (who selected 5 titles each). It beat ''[[A Charlie Brown Christmas]]'' (34.6%), ''[[How the Grinch Stole Christmas! (TV special)|How the Grinch Stole Christmas!]]'' (31.3%) and ''[[Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (TV special)|Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer]]'' (28.4%), among others.<ref>[http://www.paleycenter.org/poll-pick-your-holiday-cheer Poll: Pick Your Holiday Cheer] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160514012157/http://www.paleycenter.org/poll-pick-your-holiday-cheer |date=May 14, 2016 }} The Paley Center for Media</ref>
===Reception from cast and crew=== [[George Lucas]] himself disliked the special.<ref>{{Cite web|publisher=TVParty.com |title=When the Force Was a Farce |url=http://www.tvparty.com/70starwars.html |first=L. Wayne |last=Hicks|date=n.d.|archivedate= May 24, 2005| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050524104154/http://www.tvparty.com/70starwars.html|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://theweeklings.com/rbwarren/2014/12/15/the-flaw-in-the-force-the-star-wars-holiday-special/|title=The Flaw in the Forces: The Star Wars Holiday Special|first=Robert Burke|last=Warren |publisher=TheWeeklings.com| date= December 15, 2014|archivedate= February 20, 2018|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180220192942/http://www.theweeklings.com/rbwarren/2014/12/15/the-flaw-in-the-force-the-star-wars-holiday-special/|accessdate=September 4, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref> In a May 2005 interview, Lucas was asked if the film had soured him on working in television. He replied: {{quote|The special from 1978 really didn't have much to do with us, you know. I can't remember what network it was on, but it was a thing that they did. We kind of let them do it. It was done by... I can't even remember who the group was, but they were variety TV guys. We let them use the characters and stuff and that probably wasn't the smartest thing to do, but you learn from those experiences.<ref>{{Cite web|date=10 September 2005|first=R.|last=Burke |publisher=StaticMultimedia.com|url=http://www.staticmultimedia.com/content/film/features/feature_1115643931|title=The Greatest Story Ever Told: An Interview With George Lucas|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050528090452/http://www.staticmultimedia.com/content/film/features/feature_1115643931 |archivedate=May 28, 2005 |df= }}</ref>}}
The official ''Star Wars'' site states that the special "delivered mixed results" and states that its highlight was the Boba Fett animated segment.<ref>{{Cite web|publisher=StarWars.com |url=http://www.starwars.com/episode-ii/bts/me2/9.html |title=Making Episode II, Part 9: Bucket Head |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051103040257/http://www.starwars.com/episode-ii/bts/me2/9.html |archivedate=November 3, 2005 |df= }}</ref> The official site also says, when referring to the fan interest in seeing the [[Wookiee]]s on screen, "the 1978 Holiday Special didn't cut it."<ref>{{Cite web|date=22 December 2004 |publisher=StarWars.com |title=Star Wars: The Best of 2004 – 8 The Return of Chewbacca |url=http://www.starwars.com/welcome/about/news/f20041222/indexp4.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061230030727/http://www.starwars.com/welcome/about/news/f20041222/indexp4.html |archivedate=December 30, 2006 |df= }}</ref> The official site also refers to the Boba Fett animated segment as "a [[cult film|cult classic]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.starwars.com/hyperspace/member/kessel/f20031119/index.html |publisher=StarWars.com |title=Hyperspace: Kessel Run |date=19 November 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517050749/http://www.starwars.com/hyperspace/member/kessel/f20031119/index.html |archivedate=May 17, 2008 |df= }}</ref> In 2006, [[Harrison Ford]] made an appearance on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', and claimed to have never seen it.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Clark|first1=Mark|title=Star Wars FAQ: Everything Left to Know About the Trilogy That Changed the Movies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pAjYCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT172&lpg=PT172|page=172|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|accessdate=18 September 2017}}</ref>
On the 2010 television program ''Times Talk'', ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' columnist [[David Carr (journalist)|David Carr]] asked [[Carrie Fisher]] about the special; she said that she made George Lucas give her a copy of the special in exchange for recording [[DVD commentary|commentary]] for the ''Star Wars'' trilogy so that she would "have something for parties...when [she] wanted everyone to leave."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/video/arts/1247466499926/times-talks-carrie-fisher.html|title=Times Talks: Carrie Fisher|newspaper=The New York Times|first=David|last=Carr|date=10 January 2010|accessdate=27 December 2016}}</ref> In 2018, Mark Hamill admitted to not having seen the entire special.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.syfy.com/syfywire/mark-hamill-admits-hes-never-sat-through-the-entire-star-wars-holiday-special|title=Mark Hamill admits he's never sat through the entire Star Wars Holiday Special Mark Hamill admits he's never sat through the entire Star Wars Holiday Special|last=Jackson|first=Matthew|date=November 19, 2018|website=SYFY WIRE|accessdate=November 19, 2018}}</ref>
==Segments== All the acts were loosely linked together with material which involves the Wookiees' preparation for Life Day on [[Kashyyyk]], Han and Chewie's attempt to bypass the Imperial blockade and make it to Chewie's family, and the Imperial garrison's search for rebels. The plot strings together a series of musical numbers, celebrity [[Cameo appearance|cameos]] and other variety show acts. These include songs and comedy routines by such 1970s talents as [[Jefferson Starship]], [[Diahann Carroll]], [[Art Carney]], [[Harvey Korman]] and [[Bea Arthur]], and a circus-style [[acrobatics]] routine including [[uneven bars]] and [[juggling]]. The most notable segment is an animated cartoon featuring the onscreen debut of [[Boba Fett]].
===Music=== Original music was composed for ''The Star Wars Holiday Special'' by Ken and Mitzie Welch, while Ian Fraser was brought in to adapt [[John Williams]]' orchestral themes from ''Star Wars''.<ref name=WeirdTV /> The special features four songs: # "This Minute Now" is sung by [[Diahann Carroll]]. Carroll – who is supposed to be an image created by a [[virtual reality]] machine – tells Chewbacca's father, Itchy, that she is his "fantasy" and suggestively invites him to "experience" her. # "Light the Sky on Fire", performed by [[Jefferson Starship]], which is presented as a [[3-D film|3D]] music video watched by one of the Imperial guards; during production the song was given the working title "Cigar-Shaped Object (Vanished Without a Trace)" (the song was included as a bonus 45 [[Revolutions per minute|rpm]] single in the Jefferson Starship greatest hits collection ''[[Gold (Jefferson Starship album)|Gold]]''). (The clip marked [[Marty Balin]]'s final appearance with Jefferson Starship, as he had left the band in October 1978, a month before the special was broadcast. He later rejoined the band in 1993.) # Later, [[Bea Arthur]], who plays a bartender in the [[Mos Eisley]] [[cantina]], sings "Good Night, But Not Goodbye" set to the "Cantina Band" theme. Some of the same aliens seen in the cantina in ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'' reappear, including the band [[Figrin D'an and the Modal Nodes]], as back-up musicians.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RzXKySxPFCI|title=Bea Arthur sings in the Star Wars Holiday Special|date=July 11, 2006|work=YouTube}}</ref> # Finally, at the end of the special, [[Carrie Fisher]] sings a song in celebration of [[Life Day]] to the tune of the ''Star Wars'' main theme by [[John Williams]].
===Comedy=== [[Harvey Korman]] provides comedy in three of the special's skits, including the cantina skit with Bea Arthur where he plays a barfly who drinks through a hole in the top of his head. He also performs two solo routines: one as Chef Gormanda, a four-armed parody of [[Julia Child]] (the four arms allow her to work much faster than [[Mallatobuck|Malla]] can keep up with) and one as a malfunctioning Amorphian [[android (robot)|android]] in an instruction video watched by [[Chewbacca#Expanded Universe|Lumpy]]. Art Carney has a more integral role in the story, playing a trader named Saun Dann on [[Kashyyyk]] who is a member of the rebellion and helps Chewie's family. His segments are also largely played for laughs and at one point includes a scene alluding to his character Ed Norton from ''[[The Honeymooners]]'', where an Imperial officer demands that he "get on with it" while Carney dallies with a prop, thus introducing the Jefferson Starship performance.
===Cartoon=== The high point of the special is generally considered to be the animated segment known as "The Faithful Wookiee",<ref name=special>{{cite web|url=http://starwars.com/movies/saga/20081210.html|title=Tooning Out the "Holiday Special": Nelvana Studios|last=Plesset|first=Ross|date=December 10, 2008|accessdate=October 4, 2018|work=StarWars.com|archivedate=September 4, 2011| archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110904220415/http://starwars.com/movies/saga/20081210.html|deadurl=yes}}</ref> which is the first official ''Star Wars'' cartoon ever made.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/dec/01/star-wars-holiday-special-1978-tv-george-lucas|title=May the farce be with you: the ''Star Wars Holiday Special'' they want us to forget|last=Conterio|first=Martyn|website=[[The Guardian]]|date=December 1, 2015|accessdate=March 2, 2017}}</ref> It was written by Lucas and produced by Toronto animation firm [[Nelvana|Nelvana Ltd.]], which would later produce ''[[Star Wars: Droids|Droids]]'' and ''[[Ewoks (TV series)|Ewoks]]'', two Saturday-morning series based on the franchise in the mid-1980s.<ref name="SWI">{{cite journal |url=http://www.lucasfan.com/swtv/ewdrhistory.html |title=A ''Star Wars'' CELibration |first=Jon Bradley |last=Snyder |work=[[Star Wars Insider]] |date=1995 |issue=27 |pages=63–65|accessdate=March 1, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160409183613/http://www.lucasfan.com/swtv/ewdrhistory.html |archivedate=April 9, 2016}}</ref><ref name=AnimationHouse>{{cite news|last=Taylor|first=Paul|title=Toronto's animation houses gain international reputation for expertise|newspaper=The Globe and Mail (Canada)|date=June 11, 1979}}</ref> The visual style was inspired by [[Jean Giraud|Moebius]],<ref name=special/> and it features the vocal talents of the main cast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.starwars.com:80/vault/collecting/news20080818b.html|title=Early Star Wars Animation Collectibles: ''The Star Wars Holiday Special'', ''Droids'' and ''Ewoks''|last=Vilmur|first=Pete|date=August 18, 2008|accessdate=October 4, 2018|work=StarWars.com|archivedate=September 13, 2011| archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110913131319/http://www.starwars.com:80/vault/collecting/news20080818b.html|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Intended as an in-universe flashback, Luke Skywalker wears a yellow jacket similar to his outfit at the end of ''A New Hope''.
The cartoon introduces [[Boba Fett]], whose appearance was based on footage of the unpainted costume from ''The Empire Strikes Back'', and according to Nelvana co-founder [[Clive A. Smith|Clive Smith]], their suggestion to "scuff up his costume a little bit" influenced the character's live-action appearance.<ref name=special/> The final costume design made a public parade appearance two months before the ''Holiday Special'' aired.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.starwars.com:80/episode-v/bts/article/f20061019/index.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110827013528/http://www.starwars.com:80/episode-v/bts/article/f20061019/index.html|title=Proto-Fett: The Birth of Boba|date=October 19, 2006 |archivedate=August 27, 2011|last=Vilmur|first=Pete|accessdate=October 15, 2018}}</ref> The simplified color scheme for the cartoon was later repeated for Fett's appearance in ''Droids''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.starwars.com:80/episode-v/bts/article/f20061019/index.html?page=2|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110825002942/http://www.starwars.com:80/episode-v/bts/article/f20061019/index.html?page=2|title=Proto-Fett: The Birth of Boba page 2|last=Vilmur|first=Pete|date=October 19, 2006 |archivedate=August 27, 2011|accessdate=October 15, 2018}}</ref>
According to the official ''Star Wars'' website, Fett was voiced by [[Don Francks]] in the special.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.starwars.com/news/the-star-wars-holiday-special-boba-fett|title=The Star Wars Holiday Special and the Debut of Boba Fett|last=Seastrom|first=Lucas|date=November 15, 2018|website=StarWars.com|accessdate=November 16, 2018}}</ref> ''[[Inverse (website)|Inverse]]'' also credited the role to him based on his work in later Nelvana productions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/23942-star-wars-holiday-special-boba-fett|title=38 Years Ago Today, Boba Fett Was Spotted for the First Time|first=Ryan|last=Britt|date=November 17, 2016|accessdate=May 26, 2018|work=[[Inverse (website)|Inverse]]|archivedate=May 26, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180526214906/https://www.inverse.com/article/23942-star-wars-holiday-special-boba-fett|deadurl=no}}</ref>{{efn|The article mistakenly lists Fett as appearing in ''[[Ewoks (TV series)|Ewoks]]'', when he actually appears in ''Droids''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.starwars.com/news/the-vintage-vault-exploring-kenners-droids-and-ewoks-toys|title=The Vintage Vault: Exploring Kenner's Droids and Ewoks Toys|last=Veekhoven|first=Tim|date=September 18, 2015|website=StarWars.com|accessdate=November 16, 2018}}</ref>}}{{efn|Previously, a Lucasfilm-licensed magazine inaccurately listed Fett's voice as being provided by [[Gabriel Dell]] and [[George Buza]] in ''The Empire Strikes Back'' and ''Droids'', respectively,<ref>{{cite journal|editor1=Bob Woods|editor2=Chip Lovitt|editor3=[[Steve Sansweet]]|date=April 1998|magazine=Star Wars: Boba Fett|title=Multiple Actors|location=Brooklyn|publisher=[[Topps]]}}</ref> causing some to speculate that the information was intended for the ''Holiday Special''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bobafettfanclub.com/fettpedia/gabriel-dell/|title=Gabriel Dell|website=Fettpedia - Boba Fett Fan Club}}</ref>}}
==Versions and availability== ''The Star Wars Holiday Special'' was mostly forgotten after its only airing in 1978, until some time in the early-to-mid-1990s when individuals came forward and offered original videotape recordings of the TV airing. These have since been duplicated and reduplicated so that most copies of the special available today are based on second- to sixth-generation VHS dubs. Some of these fan-made copies include the original commercials that aired during the show, as well as the news breaks; the most notable news item was the sentencing of [[William Kampiles]]. One such recording from [[WCBS-TV]] in [[New York City]] featured anchor [[Rolland Smith]] teasing a story on "fighting the frizzies" for that night's 11 p.m. news, an ID which itself has gained popularity over the years on the Internet and television shows such as ''[[South Park]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.starwarsholidayspecial.com/multimedia.htm|title=Holiday Special Multimedia|publisher=The Star Wars Holiday Special|accessdate=July 2, 2016}}</ref>
It soon became a [[cult classic]] among ''Star Wars'' fans. While originally shared or sold as a [[Bootleg recording|bootleg]] video at conventions or via outlets such as [[eBay]], [[peer-to-peer file sharing]] networks have made the special more widely available to fans curious to see it for themselves.<ref name="abc1"/> Online video sites such as YouTube have also hosted clips of the special. However, the special has not been officially released. The so-called "Platinum Edition" DVD mentioned in a review by [[Lawrence Person]] on Locus Online was an [[April Fools' Day|April Fools]] hoax.<ref>{{Cite web|publisher=Locus Online |url=http://locusmag.com/2005/Features/0401_StarWarsDVD.html |title=DVD review of The Star Wars Holiday Special}}</ref>
Animation cels sold in the mid-1990s came from the special's animated Boba Fett segment. Segments of that cartoon appear in the 2002 ''[[Star Wars: Episode II – Attack of the Clones|Attack of the Clones]]'' web documentary "Bucket Head" and [[Jeremy Bulloch]], who portrayed Fett in the [[Star Wars original trilogy|original films]], introduces the segment as coming from the ''Holiday Special''. In 2004, the official ''Star Wars'' site confirmed that documentary filmmaker [[Kevin Burns]] was allowed access to the original print for use in his ''[[Empire of Dreams]]'' documentary; however, the segment using footage from the holiday special was ultimately left out of the final cut.
The entire Fett cartoon would get an official home video release as an [[Easter Egg (media)|Easter Egg]] on the 2011 ''Star Wars: the Complete Saga'' [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] set and therefore the only portion of the Holiday Special officially released in any home video format.
===International distribution=== The program was seen in Canada on [[CTV Television Network|CTV]] on the [[simsub|same evening as the CBS broadcast]]. [[Toronto]] CTV station [[CFTO-DT|CFTO-TV]] aired the program at 7 pm, an hour earlier than seen on the nearest American outlet, [[WIVB-TV]] in [[Buffalo, New York]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Star Wars special reunites cast on planet of Kazzook |work=Globe and Mail |location=Canada | date=17 November 1978 | page=18 | author=Associated Press }}</ref> It was also distributed and seen in Australia and New Zealand.{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} It was shown on Swedish [[Sveriges Television|SVT]] on May 31, 1979 as ''Stjärnornas krig - och fred'' (literally "Star Wars - and Peace", a pun on the Swedish title of the first film).<ref>[http://smdb.kb.se/catalog/search?q=%22stj%C3%A4rnornas+krig+och+fred%22+typ%3Atv+datum%3A1978-2013&x=0&y=0 "Stjärnornas krig och fred"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911143444/http://smdb.kb.se/catalog/search?q=%22stj%C3%A4rnornas%20krig%20och%20fred%22%20typ%3Atv%20datum%3A1978-2013&x=0&y=0 |date=September 11, 2016 }}. [http://smdb.kb.se/english/ "Svensk Mediedatabas"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929124703/http://smdb.kb.se/english/ |date=September 29, 2015 }}.</ref> The special was also broadcast in [[Venezuela]] on [[Venevision]],{{citation needed|date=November 2013}} [[Honduras]] on [[Televicentro (Honduras)|Canal 5]], [[Brazil]] on [[Rede Bandeirantes|TV Bandeirantes]] (on Christmas Day, 1981)<ref>{{cite journal|title=Programação de TV|journal=Folha de São Paulo|date=December 25, 1981|volume=Ilustrada|page=24|url=http://acervo.folha.uol.com.br/fsp/1981/12/25/21/}}</ref> and at least twice in Argentina. It aired in France on January 1, 1979, on [[TF1]], in a shortened 72-minute version, dubbed in French.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nanarland.com/Chroniques/Main.php?id_film=starwarspecial|title=Nanarland - Star Wars Holiday Special - la chronique de Nanarland|publisher=}}</ref>
==Related media tie-ins== * Prior to the special's airing, the [[Kenner Products|Kenner]] toy company considered creating a toy line based on the special. While the project was canceled because of the unpopularity of the special, several prototype versions of the figures are known to have been created. Those depict the Chewbacca family and seem to be simply modifications of Kenner's officially released Chewbacca figure.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://io9.gizmodo.com/9-star-wars-toys-that-were-canceled-before-anybody-coul-1723640150|title=9 Star Wars Toys That Were Canceled Before Anybody Could Buy Them|last=Whitbrook|first=James|website=io9|date=August 18, 2018|accessdate=October 15, 2018}}</ref> * A press kit was released prior to the special to promote its airing. * [[Jefferson Starship]] released their song from the special, "Light the Sky On Fire", as a b-side to ''Hyperdrive''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2008/01/jefferson-starship-light-the-sky-on-fire234.html|title=Jefferson Starship - Light The Sky On Fire|date=January 1, 2008|website=Paste Magazine|accessdate=October 15, 2018}}</ref> * In 2007, [[Hasbro]] released a Boba Fett action figure, using the likeness from the animated cartoon and titled "Boba Fett (Animated Debut)".<ref>{{Cite web|publisher=Rebelscum.com |work=Star Wars: The 30th Anniversary Collection Photo Archives|url=http://www.rebelscum.com/TAC24bobaanimated.asp|title=Boba Fett (Animated Debut)}}</ref>
==Role in greater ''Star Wars'' continuity== ===Canonicity of the special=== {{See also|Star Wars expanded to other media#Holocron database and canonicity}} Despite the unpopularity of the special, [[Lucasfilm]] maintained its status as part of the continuity, placing it halfway between Episodes ''IV'' and ''V''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forums.starwars.com/thread.jspa?threadID=152583&start=0870|title=Star Wars: Message Boards: Holocron continuity database questions|last=Chee|first=Leland|website=StarWars.com|date=October 12, 2006|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080610163311/http://forums.starwars.com/thread.jspa?threadID=152583&start=0870|archivedate=June 10, 2008|accessdate=November 17, 2018|deadurl=yes}}</ref> From 1978 to 2014, most elements of ''Holiday Special'' fell under the [[Star Wars expanded to other media#Holocron database and canonicity|S-canon]], a secondary level of canon superseded by other licensed works.
This was clarified in 2007 by Leland Chee, who maintains Lucasfilm's internal continuity database called "the Holocron". According to Chee, the Holocron contained at least 28 entries about ''The Star Wars Holiday Special'' by that point. These placed all elements referred to in other works, such as Life Day and Chewbacca's family members, in the {{nowrap|C-canon}}. He stated that elements not subsequently referred to were given the lower rank of {{nowrap|S-canon}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forums.starwars.com/thread.jspa?threadID=152583&start=870|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061115064750/http://forums.starwars.com/thread.jspa?threadID=152583&start=870|dead-url=yes|archive-date=November 15, 2006|title=Holocron continuity database question|last=Chee|first=Leland|website=StarWars.com|date=October 4, 2006|accessdate=October 23, 2018}}</ref> Chee also confirmed that [[Leslie Schofield]] appears as an unnamed character in ''The Star Wars Holiday Special'' and not the character he played in ''A New Hope'' named [[Chief Bast]]. Previously this confusion had caused fans (drawing on a hint in the ''[[Star Wars Customizable Card Game|Customizable Card Game]]'') to question whether Bast's death aboard the Death Star was genuine.
After Lucasfilm was acquired by [[The Walt Disney Company]], the Holocron was retired. Only the episodic films and animated series beginning with ''[[Star Wars: The Clone Wars (2008 TV series)|The Clone Wars]]'' were declared to be part of the new canon. However, {{nowrap|J. J.}} Abrams sarcastically referred to ''The Star Wars Holiday Special'' as canon in a 2015 interview.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2230940/j-j-abrams-star-wars-the-force-awakens-yes-no/|title=J. J. Abrams answers several very important 'Force Awakens' questions|first=Victoria|last=McNally|publisher=MTV|date=August 3, 2015|accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref>
===Later appearances=== After being introduced by the special, the character [[Boba Fett]] and the planet [[Kashyyyk]] have gone on to play integral roles in the franchise, making their first film appearances in ''[[The Empire Strikes Back]]'' and ''[[Star Wars: Episode III – Revenge of the Sith|Revenge of the Sith]]'', respectively. Apart from this, more specific references to ''The Star Wars Holiday Special'' have been made including: * In 1979, one year after the special's broadcast, [[Lucasfilm]] published ''Star Wars: The Wookiee Storybook'', a children's storybook which reunited characters from the special.<ref>{{cite book|title=Star Wars FAQ: Everything Left to Know About the Trilogy That Changed the Movies|last=Clark|first=Mark|page=172|year=2015|publisher=Applause Theatre & Cinema Books|isbn=978-1480360181}}</ref> * An untitled 1979 newspaper comic strip by [[Russ Manning]] which featured another venture by Han, Luke, Leia and Chewie to Kashyyyk for Life Day.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://cinemasentries.com/review/book-review-star-wars-the-complete-classic-newspaper-comics-vol-1/ |title=Book Review: Star Wars: The Complete Classic Newspaper Comics, Vol. 1 |last=Miller |first=Gordon S. |date=2017-05-26 |website=Cinema Sentries |language=en |access-date=2018-11-15 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> * ''Wookiee World'' (1985) is issue No. 91 of [[Marvel Comics]]' ''Star Wars'' run. It featured Chewie's family in another adventure on Kashyyyk.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.marvel.com/comics/issue/53881/star_wars_1977_91 |title=Star Wars (1977) #91 |website=www.marvel.com |access-date=2018-11-15 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> * ''Tyrant's Test'' (1996, {{ISBN|9780553572759}}) is the third and final book of [[Michael P. Kube-McDowell]]'s "Black Fleet Crisis" trilogy. It featured Lumpy and his rites of passage. * ''[[Rebel Dawn]]'' (1997, {{ISBN|9780553574173}}) is the third book in [[A. C. Crispin]]'s "Han Solo trilogy". It dealt with Solo's early years and his early relation with Chewbacca and his family. {{Infobox music festival | name =Street Parade | image =Image:Zurich Street Parade 2007 001.jpg | caption =Street Parade n°16–11 August 2007 - Respect | location =[[Lake Zurich]], [[Zurich]], [[Switzerland]] | years_active =1992-present | founders =Marek Krynski | dates = | genre = [[Electronic music]] | attendance =1,000,000+ | capacity = | website =[http://www.streetparade.com Official Website] }} [[File:Route Streetparade.png|thumb|City map of Zurich, made with Openstreetmap, showing the track of Street Parade as orange line. Until 2003 Streetparade started at the Western Bank of Zurich Lake, since then, it starts at the Eastern Bank]] The '''Street Parade''' is the most attended{{Citation needed|date=August 2016}} [[technoparade]] in the world, since the [[Love Parade stampede|end of Love Parade 2010]]. It takes place in [[Zurich]], [[Switzerland]] and is the largest annual event in Zurich. Officially a demonstration for freedom, love and tolerance attended by up to a one million people, it proceeds along the side of [[Lake Zurich]] on the second Saturday of August. ==History== {{Unreferenced section|date=August 2016}} *'''1992 — participants: 1,000'''
The first Street Parade (the [[English language|English]] name is used in [[German language|German]]) took place on September 5, 1992, initiated by student Marek Krynski and officially called the Demonstration for Love, Peace, Liberty, Generosity and Tolerance ({{lang-de|Demonstration für Liebe, Frieden, Freiheit, Grosszügigkeit und Toleranz}}). About 1,000 took part in dancing behind two [[Lovemobile]]s. {| align=right width=300 cellspacing=2 | | colspan=4 |[[Image:Zurich Street Parade 2004 002.jpg|center|270px|thumb|Street Parade n° 13–7 August 2004 - Elements of Culture]] |- | colspan=4 |[[Image:Zurich Street Parade 2005 002.jpg|center|270px|thumb|Street Parade n° 14–13 August 2005 - Today is Tomorrow]] |- |} *'''1993 — participants: 10,000 — temp: 27 °C'''
In only its second year, 10,000 [[rave]]rs participated. *'''1994 — participants: 20,000'''
The parade was nearly banned by the head of the police department Robert Neukomm (Socialist Party) and Monika Stocker (Green Party), but strong protests from the media, the population and the techno music scene forced the city to back down. Since then the parade takes place every August with a lengthened route around the corner of Lake Zurich. The first compilation was published that year: ''Energy 94 Streetparade - The Disc.'' *'''1995 — participants: 150,000 — temp: 24 °C'''
As many as 150,000 Swiss and foreign ravers come to the Street Parade. The double-disc ''Street Parade 95'' is the first dedicated release. *'''1996 — participants: 350,000 — motto: The Rave-olution continues'''
For the first time, the Street Parade is organized by its own dedicated Association, founded by Marek Krynski, Barbara Suter and Christoph Soltmannowski. The official logo of the Street Parade is conceived: a stylized "P" inside a rounded red star. *'''1997 — participants: 475,000 — temp: 27 °C — motto: Climb & Dance''' *'''1998 — participants: 450,000 — temp: 28 °C — motto: It's All In Your Hands'''
The Street Parade can be first heard in a live CD, directly recorded on a Lovemobile. As music plays, the crowds are heard cheering and celebrating in the background. In this way the disc uniquely portrays the voice of the Street Parade. *'''1999 — participants: 550,000 — temp: 30 °C — motto: More than Words'''
Radio Street Parade goes on the air for about two weeks prior to and about a week following the Street Parade. Radio Street Parade broadcasts techno music, electronica and dance, interviews with DJs and musicians as well as reports about the Street Parade. *'''2000 — participants: 750,000 — temp: 32 °C — motto: Believe in Love'''
The Street Parade is for the first time broadcast live on Swiss television SF1, 3sat and Tele 24. The German music television [[Viva (TV station)|VIVA]] showed two-hour summaries in the following week. *'''2001 — participants: 1,000,000 — temp: 21 °C — motto: Love, Freedom, Tolerance'''
The event reaches record heights with one million participating ravers. The Zurich Street Parade came out of the shadow of the Berlin Love Parade. *'''2002 — participants: 650,000 — temp: 17 °C — motto: Peace!'''
Rain dampens success of the event. *'''2003 — participants: 900,000 — temp: 37 °C — motto: Let the Sun Shine'''
Very hot weather with partly clouded sky. Attendance slightly down to an estimated 900,000. However, this contrasts to far more drastic declines in the Berlin event. The direction of the route was reversed in this year in order to reduce noise levels on certain streets, and to provide better exits for the trucks. *'''2004 — participants: 1,000,000 — temp: 37 °C — motto: Elements of Culture'''
The Street Parade again reaches a 1,000,000-person count. *'''2005 — participants: 1,000,000 — temp: 23 °C — motto: Today is Tomorrow'''
A million [[rave]]rs and visitors are officially cited once again. The Street Parade Radio ran into some financial difficulties, but was rescued by the Zurich local radio station [[Energy Zürich]] and the free newspaper [[20 Minuten]]. Beer was for the first time available at official drink stands. It was perceived by many that the Street Parade took on a more aggressive tone than before. *'''2006 — participants: 800,000 — temp: 17 °C — motto: Move Your Mind''' *'''2007 — participants: 800,000 — temp: 23 °C — motto: Respect'''
The Street Parade attracts 800,000 people despite the bad weather forecast. *'''2008 — participants: 820,000 — temp: 24 °C — motto: Friendship''' *'''2009 — participants: 600,000 — temp: 19 °C — motto: Still have a Dream''' *'''2010 — participants: 650,000 — temp: 22 °C — motto: Celebrate the Spirit of Street Parade *'''2011 — participants: 900,000 — temp: 28 °C — motto: 20 Years Love, Freedom, Tolerance & Respect''' *'''2012 — participants: 950,000 — temp: 24 °C — motto: Follow your Heart''' * '''2013 — participants: 950,000 — temp: 25 °C — motto: Dance for Freedom''' * '''2014 — participants: 950,000 — temp: 25 °C — motto: Enjoy the Dancefloor - and save it!''' * '''2015 — participants: 1'000,000 — temp: 32 °C — motto: Magic Moments''' * '''2016 — participants: 1'000,000 — temp: 26 °C — motto: Zurich is unique''' ==Organization== Since 1996, the event is organized by the Verein Street Parade (Street Parade Association). Today,{{When|date=August 2016}} the Street Parade has all the character of a popular festival, however legally it is still a political demonstration. This frees the organisation of security costs, among all else that the city takes under its charge. ==Political aspects== According to the official website, "The Street Parade is still a demonstration that calls on everyone to live together in peace and tolerance." [http://www.streetparade.com/content/slogan?lang=en-us&id=1&content=67&main=18 20 Years Love, Freedom, Tolerance & Respect] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110831012027/http://www.streetparade.com/content/slogan?lang=en-us&id=1&content=67&main=18 |date=2011-08-31 }} on streetparade.com, accessed March 2012. ==Alternatives== Since 1996 the counterparade ''Antiparade'' takes place in Zurich on the same day as the Street Parade to provide an alternative to it. Similar to the [[Fuckparade]] in Berlin, the goal of this smaller technoparade is to demonstrate against the increasing commercialisation of club culture.{{cite web|title=The Antiparade – Parade of the Nerds| url=http://www.nzz.ch/die-antiparade--umzug-der-nerds-1.11912321|publisher=[[Neue Zürcher Zeitung]]|date=15 August 2011|accessdate=9 August 2016|language=de}}{{cite web|title=The Parade of the Orthodox| url=http://www.tagesanzeiger.ch/zuerich/stadt/Der-Umzug-der-Orthodoxen/story/29592019 |publisher=[[Tages-Anzeiger]]|date=15 August 2010|accessdate=9 August 2016| language=de}} ==Gallery== Image:Zurich Street Parade 2005 005.jpg|Street Parade n° 14–13 August 2005 - Today is Tomorrow Image:Zurich Street Parade 2008 002.jpg|Street Parade n°17–9 August 2008 - Friendship Image:Zurich Street Parade 2009 001.jpg|Street Parade n° 18–8 August 2009 - Still Have a Dream Image:Zurich Street Parade 2009 002.jpg|Street Parade n° 18–8 August 2009 - Still Have a Dream ==See also== {{Portal|Electronic music}} *[[List of electronic music festivals]] *[[List of technoparades]] {{Clear}} ==References== ''This article is based on the article [[:de:Street Parade|Street Parade]] in the German-language Wikipedia.'' ==External links== {{Commons category|Street Parade}} * [http://www.streetparade.com Official Website] * [http://www.friends-of-streetparade.ch Friends of the Street Parade] * [http://www.swissparades.ch The photographic book on Lake & Street Parades by Claudio Bonavolta]; 35 pages of the book are available online. {{Electronic music festival}} {{coord missing|Switzerland}} [[Category:Technoparade]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Zürich]] [[Category:Electronic music festivals in Switzerland]] [[Category:Free parties]] [[Category:Music festivals established in 1992]] [[Category:Summer events in Switzerland]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Economy of Turkey}} The '''Turkish currency and debt crisis of 2018''' ({{Lang-tr|Türkiye döviz ve borç krizi}}) is an ongoing financial and economic crisis in [[Turkey]] with international repercussions due to [[financial contagion]]. It is characterised by the [[Turkish lira]] (TRY) plunging in value, high [[inflation]], rising borrowing costs, and correspondingly rising [[Default (finance)|loan defaults]]. The crisis was caused by the Turkish economy's excessive [[current account]] deficit and foreign-currency debt, -for some analyists- in combination with President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]]'s increasing [[authoritarianism]] and his unorthodox ideas about [[interest rate]] policy.<ref name=e101 /><ref name=challenge /><ref name=crash /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.caixinglobal.com/2018-08-19/turkeys-lessons-for-emerging-economies-101316583.html|title=Turkey’s Lessons for Emerging Economies - Caixin Global|website=www.caixinglobal.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref> Some analyists also stress the leveraging effects of the geopolitical frictions with the United States and recently enforced tariffs by Trump administration on some Turkish products such as steel and aluminum.<ref>{{cite web |last1= Goujon |first1=Reva |title= Aug 16, 2018 {{!}} 09:00 GMT 11 mins read Making Sense of Turkey's Economic Crisis |url= https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkish_currency_and_debt_crisis,_2018&action=submit |accessdate= 31 October 2018}}</ref>
While the crisis was prominent for waves of major devaluation of the currency, later stages were characterised by debt defaults and finally by contraction of the economic growth. With the inflation rate stuck in the double digits, [[stagflation]] ensued. The crisis ended a period of overheating economic growth under Erdoğan-led governments, built largely on a construction boom fuelled by easy credit and government spending.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/17/business/turkey-lira-currency.html|title=Life in Turkey Now: Tough Talk, but Fears of Drug Shortages|date=17 August 2018|publisher=New York Times|author=Jack Ewing}}</ref>
== Current account deficit and foreign-currency debt ==
[[File:Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge IMG 3065.jpg|thumb|right|Previous economic growth had been led by fiscal and monetary stimulus to the construction industry,<ref name=bentley /><ref name=bet /> resulting in a huge backlog of unsold new houses,<ref name=houses /> and unprofitable grand projects like the [[Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge]].<ref name=selim />]]
A longstanding characteristic of Turkey's economy is a low savings rate.<ref name=economist>{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2018/05/19/how-turkey-fell-from-investment-darling-to-junk-rated-emerging-market|title=How Turkey fell from investment darling to junk-rated emerging market|date=19 May 2018|work=The Economist}}</ref> Since [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] assumed control of the government, Turkey has been running huge and growing [[current account]] deficits, $33.1 billion in 2016 and $47.3 billion in 2017,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkeys-current-account-deficit-at-5-4-billion-in-april-133114|title=Turkey’s current account deficit at $5.4 billion in April|date=11 June 2018|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> climbing to US$7.1 billion in the month of January 2018 with the rolling 12-month deficit rising to $51.6 billion,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-economy/turkish-current-account-deficit-more-doubles|title=Turkish current account deficit more than doubles|date=12 March 2018|work=Ahval}}</ref> one of the largest current account deficits in the world.<ref name=economist /> The economy has relied on capital inflows to fund private-sector excess, with Turkey's banks and big firms borrowing heavily, often in foreign currencies.<ref name=economist /> Under these conditions, Turkey must find approximately $200 billion a year to fund its wide current account deficit and maturing debt, while being always at risk of inflows drying up; the state has gross foreign currency reserves of just $85 billion.<ref name=challenge>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/79317f20-67f5-11e8-8cf3-0c230fa67aec|title=Inflation rise poses challenge to Erdogan as election looms|date=5 June 2018|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref> The economic policy underlying these trends had increasingly been micro-managed by Erdoğan since the election of his AK Party in 2002, and strongly so since 2008, with a focus on the [[construction|construction industry]], state-awarded contracts and stimulus measures. Although, [[research and development]] expenditure of the country (% of GDP) and the government expenditure on [[education]](% of GDP) are nearly doubled during AK Party governments, the desired outcomes could not been achieved<ref>{{cite web |title=Research and development expenditure (% of GDP) |url=https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/GB.XPD.RSDV.GD.ZS |website=The World Bank Data |publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics |accessdate=31 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Government expenditure on education, total (% of GDP) |url=https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.XPD.TOTL.GD.ZS?end=2014&locations=TR&start=1999&view=chart&year=2014 |publisher=United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization ( UNESCO ) Institute for Statistics. |accessdate=31 October 2018}}</ref><ref name=bet>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/amp/news/articles/2018-06-22/a-crazy-200-billion-says-erdogan-wins-his-election-bet|title=A Crazy $200 Billion Says Erdogan Wins His Election Bet|date=22 June 2018|publisher=Bloomberg|author1=Marc Champion|author2=Cagan Koc}}</ref> The motive for these policies have been described as Erdoğan losing faith in Western-style capitalism since the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|2008 financial crisis]] by the secretary general of the main Turkish business association, [[Turkish Industry and Business Association|TUSIAD]].<ref name=bet />
Investment inflows had already been declining in the period leading up to the crisis, owing to Erdoğan instigating political disagreements with countries that were major sources of such inflows (such as Germany, France, and the Netherlands).<ref name=e101 /> Following the [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt|2016 coup attempt]], the government [[2016–present purges in Turkey|seized the assets]] of those it considered involved, even if their ties to the coup were attenuated. Erdoğan has not taken seriously concerns that foreign companies investing in Turkey might be deterred by the country's political instability.<ref name=e101 /> Other factors include worries about the decreasing value of lira (TRY) which threatens to eat into investors' profit margins.<ref name=e101>{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2018/05/25/erdogan-is-a-mad-economist-and-turkey-is-his-laboratory/|title=Erdogan Is Failing Economics 101|date=25 May 2018|publisher=Foreign Policy|author=Borzou Daragahi}}</ref> Investment inflows have also declined because Erdoğan's [[Erdoğanism|increasing authoritarianism]] has quelled free and factual reporting by [[financial analyst]]s in Turkey.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-24/a-big-chill-silences-turkey-s-market-analysts-amid-lira-s-plunge|title=A Big Chill Has Silenced Turkey’s Market Analysts|date=24 May 2018|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref> Between January and May 2017, foreign portfolio investors funded $13.2 billion of Turkey's $17.5 billion current account deficit, according to the latest available data. During the same period this year they plugged just $763 million of a swollen $27.3 billion deficit.<ref name=pariah />
By the end of 2017, the corporate foreign-currency debt in Turkey had more than doubled since 2009, up to $214 billion after netting against their foreign-exchange assets.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-29/turkey-s-bill-for-debt-fueled-economic-growth-starts-to-fall-due|title=Turkey's Bill for Debt-Fueled Economic Growth Starts to Fall Due|date=29 March 2018|agency=Bloomberg}}</ref> Turkey's gross external debt, both public and private, stood at $453.2 billion at the end of 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/turkeys-external-debt-stock-reaches-4532b-/1103634|title=Turkey's external debt stock reaches $453.2B|date=30 March 2018|agency=Anadolu}}</ref> As of March 2018, $181.8 billion of external debt, public and private, was due to mature within a year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcmb.gov.tr/wps/wcm/connect/b19b5048-dd64-4075-ae01-47b2fd3ede50/st.pdf?MOD=AJPERES&CACHEID=ROOTWORKSPACE-b19b5048-dd64-4075-ae01-47b2fd3ede50-mdO36yX|title=Short Term External Debt Statistics|date=March 2018|work=Türkiye Cumhuriyet Merkez Bankası (Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey)}}</ref> Non-resident holdings of domestic shares stood at $53.3 billion in early March and at $39.6 billion in mid-May, and non-resident holdings of domestic government bonds stood at $32.0 billion in early March and at $24.7 billion in mid-May.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcmb.gov.tr/wps/wcm/connect/7b1a6b8b-cd10-43ae-90b4-b3d702fae602/hmkexcelEn.pdf?MOD=AJPERES&CACHEID=ROOTWORKSPACE-7b1a6b8b-cd10-43ae-90b4-b3d702fae602-mehWrra/|title=Securities Statistics|date=18 May 2018|work=Türkiye Cumhuriyet Merkez Bankası (Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey)}}</ref> Overall non-residents’ ownership of Turkish equities, government bonds and corporate debt has plummeted from a high of $92 billion in August 2017 to just $53 billion as of July 13, 2018.<ref name=pariah>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/115e91ac-8f51-11e8-bb8f-a6a2f7bca546|title=Turkey nears ‘pariah’ status over defiance on rates|date=31 July 2018|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref>
== Government's ‘action plans’ to tackle the crisis ==
The finance minister of the Turkish government, Albayrak unveiled a new economic program to stave off the recent financial crisis. The three-year plan aims to "reign in inflation, spur growth and cut the current account deficit".<ref>{{cite web |title=Turkey unveils 2019-2021 economic programme |url=https://www.trtworld.com/turkey/turkey-unveils-2019-2021-economic-programme-20330 |publisher=TRT World |accessdate=20 September 2018}}</ref> The plan includes reduction on the government expenditures by $10 billion and suspension of the projects whose tender have not been carried yet. The transformational phase of the plan will be focusing on value-added areas to increase the country's export volume and long-term production capacity with the goal of creating two million new jobs by 2021. <ref>{{cite web |title=New economic program: Turkey lays out a broad guideline to rebalance economic growth |url=https://www.dailysabah.com/economy/2018/09/21/new-economic-program-turkey-lays-out-a-broad-guideline-to-rebalance-economic-growth-1537477046 |publisher=Daily Sabah |accessdate=20 September 2018}}</ref> The program is expected to lower economic growth substantially in the short term (from a previous forecast of 5.5% to 3.8% in 2018 and 2.3% in 2019) but with a gradual growth increase by 2021 towards 5%.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Turkish government presents plan to balance the economy |url=https://www.bbva.com/en/the-turkish-government-presents-plan-to-balance-the-economy/ |publisher=BBVA |accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Turkey unveils plan to stave off economic crisis |url=https://www.dw.com/en/turkey-unveils-plan-to-stave-off-economic-crisis/a-45581306 |publisher=Deutsche Welle |accessdate=31 October 2018}}</ref>
== Presidential interference with the central bank == {{Bar graph | title = Average [[Turkish lira]] equivalent of 1 US Dollar (2005{{en dash}}2017)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://data.oecd.org/conversion/exchange-rates.htm|title=Exchange rates|publisher=[[OECD]]}}</ref> | float = right | data_max = 8 | bar_width = 20 | width_units = em | label_type = Year | data_type = Exchange rate | label1 = 2005 | data1 = 1.344 | label2 = 2006 | data2 = 1.428 | label3 = 2007 | data3 = 1.303 | label4 = 2008 | data4 = 1.302 | label5 = 2009 | data5 = 1.550 | label6 = 2010 | data6 = 1.503 | label7 = 2011 | data7 = 1.675 | label8 = 2012 | data8 = 1.796 | label9 = 2013 | data9 = 1.904 | label10 = 2014 | data10 = 2.189 | label11 = 2015 | data11 = 2.720 | label12 = 2016 | data12 = 3.020 | label13 = 2017 | data13 = 3.648 }}
Turkey has experienced substantially higher [[inflation]] than other [[emerging markets]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-turkey-emerging-yield/with-high-inflation-turkish-lira-lacks-yield-buffer-idUKKBN1CG1RX|title=With high inflation, Turkish lira lacks yield buffer|date=11 October 2017|agency=Reuters}}</ref> In October 2017, inflation was at 11.9%, the highest rate since July 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.handelsblatt.com/finanzen/maerkte/devisen-rohstoffe/tuerkische-lira-lira-faellt-richtung-rekordtief/20538184.html?ticket=ST-7210-45hD6rWiFYdVLkBpNMdq-ap1|title=Lira fällt Richtung Rekordtief|publisher=[[Handelsblatt]]|date=3 November 2017|accessdate=3 August 2018}}</ref> In 2018, the lira's exchange rate accelerated deterioration, reaching a level of 4.0 USD/TRY by late March, 4.5 USD/TRY by mid-May, 5.0 USD/TRY by early August and 6.0 as well as 7.0 USD/TRY by mid-August. Among economists, the accelerating loss of value was generally attributed to [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] preventing the [[Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey]] from making the necessary interest rate adjustments.<ref name=wapo>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2018/05/16/turkeys-leader-is-helping-to-crash-its-currency/|title=Turkey’s leader is helping to crash its currency|date=16 May 2018|publisher=Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/e41a56d6-5855-11e8-bdb7-f6677d2e1ce8|title=Investors lose their appetite for Turkey|date=16 May 2018|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref>
Erdoğan, who claimed interest rates beyond his control to be "the mother and father of all evil",<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-currency/turkeys-erdogan-calls-interest-rates-mother-of-all-evil-lira-slides-idUSKBN1IC1NV|title=Turkey's Erdogan calls interest rates "mother of all evil"; lira slides|last=Küçükgöçmen|first=Ali|date=2018-05-11|work=Reuters|access-date=2018-06-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180519111546/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-currency/turkeys-erdogan-calls-interest-rates-mother-of-all-evil-lira-slides-idUSKBN1IC1NV|archive-date=2018-05-19|last2=Taner|first2=Behiye Selin|language=en-US}}</ref> shared unorthodox interest rate theories in a 14 May interview with ''[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]]'' and said that "the central bank can't take this independence and set aside the signals given by the president."<ref name=wapo /><ref name=unorthodox>{{cite web|url=https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2018/05/turkey-erdogans-controversial-economic-theory.html|title=The unorthodox theory behind Erdogan's monetary policy|date=25 May 2018|publisher=Al-Monitor|author=Marc Edward Hoffman}}</ref> Presidential interference with central bank policy comes with a general perception in international investment circles of a "textbook institutional decline" in Turkey, with Erdoğan seen increasingly reliant on politicians whose main qualifications for their jobs is loyalty, at the expense of more qualified and experienced options.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-18/why-investors-have-become-skittish-about-turkey|title=Why Investors Have Become Skittish About Turkey|date=18 May 2018|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref> Erdoğan also has a long history of voicing [[Islamism|Islamist]] discourse of interest-based banking as "[[Haram|prohibited by Islam]]" and "a serious dead-end".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/9ef872ff-bfce-3db5-bc22-67c649327c2f|title=Turkish lira falls further as Erdogan calls for interest rate cuts|date=24 November 2016|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/turkey-banks/rise-of-turkish-islamic-banks-chimes-with-erdogans-ideals-idUSL5N0WB3RW20150315|title=Rise of Turkish Islamic banks chimes with Erdogan's ideals|date=15 March 2015|agency=Reuters}}</ref> He is also on record referring to interest rate increases as "[[treason]]".<ref name=crash>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2018/07/13/turkeys-economy-looks-like-its-headed-big-crash/|title=Turkey’s economy looks like it’s headed for a big crash|date=13 July 2018|publisher=Washington Post|author=Matt O'Brien}}</ref> Despite Erdogan's apparent opposition, Turkey's Central Bank made sharp interest rates increases<ref>{{cite web |title=Defying Erdogan, Turkey's Central Bank Raises Interest Rates |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/13/business/turkey-central-bank-interest-rates-erdogan.html |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=13 September 2018}}</ref>.
The ''[[Financial Times]]'' quoted leading emerging markets financial analyst Timothy Ash analyzing that "Turkey has strong banks, healthy public finances, good demographics, pro-business culture but [has been] spoiled over past four to five years by unorthodox and loose macroeconomic management."<ref name=strong /> By mid-June, analysts in London suggested that with its current government, Turkey would be well advised to seek an [[International Monetary Fund]] loan even before the dwindling central bank foreign exchange reserves run out, because it would strengthen the central bank's hand against Erdoğan and help gain back investor confidence in the soundness of Turkey's economic policies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/turkey-needs-imf-loans-after-investor-confidence-undercut|title=Turkey needs IMF loans after investor confidence undercut|date=16 June 2018|publisher=Ahval|author=Mark Bentley}}</ref>
Economist [[Paul Krugman]] described the unfolding crisis as "a classic currency-and-debt crisis, of a kind we’ve seen many times", adding: "At such a time, the quality of leadership suddenly matters a great deal. You need officials who understand what’s happening, can devise a response and have enough credibility that markets give them the benefit of the doubt. Some emerging markets have those things, and they are riding out the turmoil fairly well. The Erdoğan regime has none of that."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/24/opinion/turkey-trump-erdogan.html?action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=opinion-c-col-left-region&region=opinion-c-col-left-region&WT.nav=opinion-c-col-left-region|title=Turmoil for Turkey’s Trump|date=24 May 2018|author=Paul Krugman|publisher=New York Times}}</ref>
== Consequences in Turkey == During the emergence of the crisis, lenders in Turkey were hit by restructuring demands of corporations unable to serve their [[United States dollar|USD]] or [[Euro|EUR]] denominated debt, due to the loss of value of their earnings in [[Turkish lira]]. While financial institutions had been the driver of the [[Istanbul stock exchange]] for many years, accounting for almost half it's value, by mid-April they accounted for less than one-third.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-10/investors-bet-against-turkey-banks-as-debt-wave-gathers-force|title=Investors Bet Against Turkey Banks as Debt Wave Gains Force|date=10 April 2018|agency=Bloomberg}}</ref> By late-May, lenders were facing a surge in demand from companies seeking to reorganise debt repayments.<ref name=pile>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-31/turkish-banks-face-increasing-pile-of-debt-restructuring-demands|title=Turkish Banks Face Rising Pile of Debt-Restructuring Demands|date=31 May 2018|agency=Bloomberg}}</ref> By early-July, public restructuring requests by some of the country's biggest businesses alone already totalled $20,000,000,000 with other debtors not publicly listed or large enough to require disclosures.<ref name=bereket>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-05/turkey-s-bereket-is-said-to-begin-sales-to-pay-4-billion-debt|title=Turkey's Bereket Is Said to Begin Sales to Pay $4 Billion Debt|date=5 July 2018|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref> The [[asset quality]] of Turkish banks, as well as their [[capital adequacy ratio]], kept deteriorating throughout the crisis.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/unethical-moodys-forewarns-second-wave-turkish-crisis|title=‘Unethical’ Moody’s forewarns second wave of Turkish crisis|date=9 June 2018|author=Mark Bentley|publisher=Ahval}}</ref> By June [[Halk Bankası]], the most vulnerable of the large lenders, had lost 63% of its US dollar value since last summer and traded at 40% of book value.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atimes.com/article/turkeys-economic-crisis-has-just-begun/|title=Turkey’s economic crisis has just begun|date=12 June 2018|author=David P.
