Goldman|publisher=Asia Times}}</ref> However, it is hard to say that this is mainly due to the economic developments in Turkey since the valuation of Halkbank was largely affected by the rumors over the possible outcomes of the US investigation about the bank's alleged help Iran for evading US sanctions.<ref name="ING-Halkbank">{{cite web |last1=Smallwood |first1=Nicholas |title=Halkbank: What happens next? |url=https://think.ing.com/articles/turkish-bank-halkbank-posts-1q18-results/ |website=THINK - Economic and Financial Analysis |publisher=ING Bank |accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref>
Banks continuously raised interest rates for business and consumer loans and [[Mortgage loan|mortgage loan]] rates, towards 20% annually, thus curbing demand from businesses and consumers. With a corresponding growth in deposits, the gap between total deposits and total loans, which had been one of the highest in emerging markets, began to narrow.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-banking/cash-hungry-turkish-banks-raise-rates-highest-crisis|title=Cash-hungry Turkish banks raise rates to highest since crisis|date=9 April 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref><ref name=estate>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkey-limits-real-estate-commissions-house-prices-slashed|title=Turkey limits real estate commissions, house prices slashed|date=14 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref> However, this development has also led to unfinished or unoccupied housing and commercial real estate littering the outskirts of Turkey's major cities, as Erdoğan's policies had fuelled the construction sector, where many of his business allies are very active, to lead past economic growth.<ref name=bentley>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-elections/turkish-real-estate-ills-reflect-erdogans-snap-poll-decision|title=Turkish real estate ills reflect Erdoğan’s snap poll decision|date=19 April 2018|publisher=Ahval|author=Mark Bentley}}</ref><ref name=estate /> In March 2018, home sales fell 14% and mortgage sales declined 35% compared to a year earlier. As of May, Turkey had around 2,000,000 unsold houses, a backlog three times the size of the average annual number of new housing sales.<ref name=houses>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/turkey-economy-realestate/turkish-property-firms-to-slash-prices-in-one-month-drive-to-revive-market-idUSL5N1SM2LT|title=Turkish property firms to slash prices in one-month drive to revive market|date=15 May 2018|agency=Reuters}}</ref> In the first half of 2018, unsold stock of new housing kept increasing, while increases in new home prices in Turkey were lagging consumer price inflation by more than 10 percentage points.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-property/turkish-house-prices-lag-inflation-10-percentage-points|title=Turkish house prices lag inflation by 10 percentage points|date=17 July 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
While heavy portfolio capital outflows persisted, $883,000,000 in June, with official foreign exchange reserves declining by a $6,990,000,000 during June, the current account deficit started narrowing in June, due to the weakened exchange rate for the lira. This was perceived as a sign of getting balanced economy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkey-current-account-gap-narrows-sign-rebalancing|title=Turkey current account gap narrows in sign of rebalancing|date=10 August 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref> Turkish Lira started recover its losses as of September 2018 and the current account deficit continued to shrink.<ref name="Ahval-LiraGains">{{cite web |title=Turkish current account deficit narrows; lira gains |url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/turkish-current-account-deficit-narrows-lira-gains |publisher=Ahval News |accessdate=September 14, 2018}}</ref>
As a consequence of the earlier monetary policy of easy money, any newfound fragile short-term macroeconomic stability is based on higher interest rates, thus creating a recessionary effect for the Turkish economy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-contraction-looms-rates-fallout-becomes-evident|title=Turkish contraction looms as rates fallout becomes evident|date=8 June 2018|publisher=Ahval|author=Güldem Atabay Şanlı}}</ref> In mid-June, the ''[[Washington Post]]'' carried the quote from a senior financial figure in Istanbul that "years of irresponsible policies have overheated the Turkish economy. High inflation rates and current account deficits are going to prove sticky. I think we are at the end of our rope."<ref name=housing>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/06/19/the-quest-to-defeat-erdogan/|title=The quest to defeat Erdogan|date=19 June 2018|publisher=Washington Post|author=Ishaan Tharoor}}</ref>
[[File:Recep Tayyip Erdogan WEF Turkey 2008 edited.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]]'s unorthodox views on interest rates are considered one of the most important causes of the crisis.<ref name=wapo /><ref name=e101 />]]
=== Timeline of events (2018) === * 12 February – [[Yıldız Holding]] unexpectedly requested to restructure as much as $7,000,000,000 in loans.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-12/yildiz-7-billion-request-adds-to-asset-woes-for-turkish-banks|title=Yildiz $7 Billion Restructuring Bid Adds to Turkish Bank Woes|date=12 February 2018|agency=Bloomberg}}</ref>
* 21 February – Cemil Ertem, senior economic adviser to president [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]], published an opinion piece in the ''[[Daily Sabah]]'' suggesting that the [[International Monetary Fund]]'s policy advice for Turkey's central bank to raise short term interest rates should be ignored and that "not only Turkey, but all developing countries, should do the opposite of what the IMF preaches."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/imf-turkey/imf-backed-terrorists-has-failed-turkey-adviser|title=IMF backed by terrorists has failed in Turkey – adviser|date=21 February 2018|work=Ahval}}</ref>
* 5 April – [[Mehmet Şimşek]], the deputy prime minister in charge of the economy, sought to resign due to disagreement with president Erdoğan about the latter's interference with central bank policy, but was later convinced to withdraw his resignation.<ref name=monitor>{{cite web|url=https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2018/04/rumors-mehmet-simsek-resigns.html|title=Rumors of Turkish deputy PM's departure spook markets|date=5 April 2018|publisher=Al-Monitor}}</ref>
* 7 April – [[Doğuş Group|Doğuş Holding]] applied to their banks for debt restructuring. Doğuş’ outstanding loans stood at the equivalent of 23,500,000,000 Turkish lira (£2,765,597,500) at the end of 2017; up 11% from the year before.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-dogus-gyo-debt/turkeys-dogus-in-talks-with-banks-on-debt-restructuring-sources-idUSKBN1HE06U|title=Turkey's Dogus in talks with banks on debt restructuring|date=7 April 2018|agency=Reuters}}</ref>
* 18 April – President Erdoğan announced that the upcoming [[Turkish general election, 2018|general election]] would be held on 24 June, eighteen months earlier than scheduled.
* 14 and 15 May – In a televised interview with ''Bloomberg'' and in a meeting with global money managers in [[London]], Erdoğan said that after the elections, he intended to take greater control of the economy, including ''de facto'' control over monetary policy, and to implement lower interest rates; this caused "shock and disbelief" among investors about the central bank's ability to fight inflation and stabilise the lira.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-markets-investors/disbelief-investors-in-turkey-stunned-by-erdogans-fight-with-markets-idUSKCN1IG2Y1|title='Disbelief': Investors in Turkey stunned by Erdogan's fight with markets|date=15 May 2018|agency=Reuters}}</ref><ref name=unorthodox />
* 23 May – Foreign exchange bureaus in Istanbul temporarily stopped trading amidst an extreme dive in the price of the lira.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/istanbul-foreign-exchange-bureaus-close-survive-turbulence|title=Istanbul foreign exchange bureaus close to survive turbulence|date=23 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref> On the same day, the [[Turkish Statistical Institute]] reported another slip in consumer confidence over the month of May, with all sub-indices decreasing. On 25 May, it reported a sharp drop in confidence in Turkey's services, retail trade, and construction sectors over the month of May.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkeys-sectoral-confidence-goes-down-in-may-132348|title=Turkey’s sectoral confidence goes down in May|date=25 May 2018|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> Also on the same day, the [[Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey|Central Bank of Turkey]] raised interest rates at an emergency meeting of its Monetary Policy Committee, bowing to pressure from financial markets. The central bank raised it's late liquidity window rate by 300 basis points to 16.5%.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-23/turkey-central-bank-has-held-extraordinary-rate-meeting|title=Turkey Raises Interest Rates to Halt Slide Into Currency Crisis|date=23 May 2018|agency=Bloomberg}}</ref> Taken against the vociferous objections of Erdoğan, this step brought temporary relief for the lira exchange rate.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2018/05/25/turkey-tried-to-save-its-currency-it-worked-for-a-day/|title=Turkey tried to save its currency. It worked — for a day.|date=25 May 2018|publisher=Washington Post|author=Matt O'Brien}}</ref>
* 28 May – Turkey's central bank announced an operational simplification of its monetary policy, effective 1 June, coming with the announcement of another interest rate hike. The one-week repo rate, at 8 percent—currently not used—is to be raised to 16.5 percent and become the future benchmark of monetary policy. The current benchmark late liquidity window rate, now at 16.5 percent, will be fixed at 150 basis points above the one-week repo rate, which would now be 18 percent. The lira somewhat firmed in response.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-central-bank/turkish-central-bank-simplifies-policy-lira-gains|title=Turkish central bank simplifies policy; lira gains|date=28 May 2018|work=Ahval}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkish-central-bank-says-it-will-complete-policy-simplification-132463|title=Turkish Central Bank says it will complete ‘policy simplification’|date=28 May 2018|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref>
* 30 May – The Turkish Statistical Institute reported economic confidence sliding steeply in May to a value of 93.5, the lowest level in 15 months, since the aftermath of the [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt|2016 coup attempt]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-economic-confidence-slumps-lowest-15-months|title=Turkish economic confidence slumps to lowest in 15 months|date=30 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 30 May – GAMA Holding sought to ease repayment terms for $1.5 billion of loans with creditors.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-banking/gama-refinancing-15-billion-latest-turkish-debt-applicant|title=Gama refinancing $1.5 billion latest Turkish debt applicant|date=30 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 30 May – Turkey's central bank released minutes of the crucial 23 May Monetary Policy Committee meeting, saying that “the tight stance in monetary policy will be maintained decisively until the inflation outlook displays a significant improvement and becomes consistent with the targets”, the latter being 5 percent by law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkish-central-bank-vows-tight-policy-warns-about-risks-132659|title=Turkish Central Bank vows tight policy, warns about risks|date=31 May 2018|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref>
[[File:Euro exchange rate to TRY.svg|thumb|right|The [[Turkish lira]] has a history of accelerating loss of value relative to the [[euro]], breaching the mark of five lira per euro in early 2018]]
[[File:DollarTRYCurrency.jpg|thumb|The Turkish Lira regains a significant proportion of its losses within the three months after July 2018. According to the models by IMF and International Institute of Finance, the lira is getting closer to the fair value but it is still slightly undervalued.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bentley |first1=Mark |title=What next for Turkey after currency crisis? |url=https://www.spreaker.com/user/ahvalpod/what-next-for-turkey-after-currency-cris?utm_medium=widget&utm_source=user%3A10753342&utm_term=episode_title |publisher=Speaker |accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref>]]
* 1 June – The Istanbul Chamber of Industry published its index of manufacturing in Turkey for the month of May, revealing that with a sharp drop for the second consecutive month, manufacturing conditions deteriorated to the worst since 2009, elaborating that "inflationary pressures remained marked in May, cost burdens continued to rise in the manufacturing sector."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.markiteconomics.com/Survey/PressRelease.mvc/eca3dc09ed4a4ff592ec19620a507f1b|title=PMI posts 46.4 during May|date=1 June 2018|work=Istanbul Chamber of Industry}}</ref>
* 4 June – Turkey's statistics institute reported the annual inflation rate for May as risen to 12.2 percent from 10.9 percent the previous month, just below a 14-year high of last November, while monthly inflation was 1.6 percent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-06-04/turkish-inflation-accelerates-more-than-expected-on-weak-lira|title=Turkey Inflation Accelerates in May on Weak Currency|date=4 June 2018|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloombergquint.com/onweb/2018/06/05/enthusiastic-lira-bulls-may-preclude-a-central-bank-rate-hike|title=Lira's Rebound From a Record May Preclude Central Bank Rate Hike|date=5 June 2018|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref>
* 6 June – At the [[Borsa Istanbul]], Turkey's main stock index BIST-100 dropped 1.5 percent to the lowest level in dollar terms since the global financial crisis in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-stocks/turkish-stock-market-hits-lowest-2008-crisis|title=Turkish stock market hits lowest since 2008 crisis|date=6 June 2018|work=Ahval}}</ref>
* 7 June – Turkey's central bank at its regular Monetary Policy Committee meeting raised its benchmark repo rate by 125 basis points to 17.75 percent. The move beat market expectations, resulting in immediate gains for the lira, and the yield on the benchmark 10-year lira bond eased, after touching a record-high 15.41 percent on 6 June.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-06-07/turkish-central-bank-unexpectedly-raises-rate-to-17-75-percent|title=Turkey Central Bank Is Latest to Surprise With Big Rate Move|date=7 June 2018|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref>
* 10 June – Turkey's Automotive Manufacturers Association published data for the month of May, showing car sales sliding to the lowest level since 2014. Passenger car sales slumped by 13 percent when compared to May 2017, while sales of commercial vehicles dropped 19 percent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-car-sales-lowest-4-years-show-economic-woes|title=Turkish car sales at lowest in 4 years show economic woes|date=11 June 2018|work=Ahval}}</ref>
* 11 June – Turkey's central bank released financial data for April, with the account deficit widening by $1.7 billion to $5.4 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-current-account-gap-widens-portfolio-inflows-slump|title=Turkish current account gap widens; portfolio inflows slump|date=11 June 2018|work=Ahval}}</ref>
* 13 June – Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan's senior economic adviser Cemil Ertem in an opinion piece in the ''Daily Sabah'' argued the unorthodox idea that it would be wrong to see inflation as a monetary phenomenon,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/erdogan-adviser-says-high-growth-doesnt-cause-inflation|title=Erdoğan adviser says high growth doesn't cause inflation|date=13 June 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref> leading to a sharp slide in the value of the lira and of Turkey's benchmark 10-year lira bonds, with yields on the latter reaching a record-high of 16.25 percent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/turkish-lira-slumps-renewed-concern-over-economic-policy|title=Turkish lira slumps on renewed concern over economic policy|date=13 June 2018|work=Ahval}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-06-13/turkey-s-bonds-lira-slide-a-third-day-before-central-banks-meet|title=Turkish Yields Head for Record While Lira Loses Rate-Hike Boost|date=13 June 2018|agency=Bloomberg}}</ref>
* 14 June – Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan in a televised interview said that his government would "conduct an operation against" international credit ratings agency [[Moody's Investors Service]] following elections on June 24.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/erdogan-says-will-sanction-moodys-after-it-defamed-turkey|title=Erdoğan says will sanction Moody’s after it defamed Turkey|date=14 June 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/turkey-currency/turkish-lira-weakens-market-seems-to-shrug-off-erdogans-comments-on-moodys-idUKL8N1TG2RB|title=Turkish lira weakens, market seems to shrug off Erdogan's comments on Moody's|date=14 June 2018|agency=Reuters}}</ref> The next day, the lira finished its worst week since 2008, tumbling 5.7 per cent relative to the dollar, while also hitting its worst weekend close ever at 4.73 USD/TRY.<ref name=strong>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/1e5f9fc6-7076-11e8-92d3-6c13e5c92914|title=Turkish lira slides almost 6% in worst week in a decade|date=15 June 2018|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref>
* 24 June – In the [[Turkish general election, 2018|Turkish general election]], Erdoğan retained the office of president while his [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party]] (AKP) narrowly lost its majority in parliament but achieved such majority together with its alliance partner the [[Nationalist Movement Party]] (MHP). The day after, the Turkish Industry and Business Association (TÜSİAD) urgently called for economic reforms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkeys-top-business-group-calls-for-urgent-reforms-after-election-133769|title=Turkey’s top business group calls for ‘urgent’ reforms after election|date=25 June 2018|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref>
* 28 June – The Turkish Statistical Institute reported its economic confidence index dropping in June for the fifth straight month, with construction sector confidence leading the declines.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-economic-confidence-lowest-18-months|title=Turkish economic confidence lowest in 18 months|date=28 June 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
[[File:Türk Telekom logo.svg|thumb|right|The debt default of [[Türk Telekom]] was Turkey's biggest ever.<ref name=Telekom />]]
* 3 July – The Turkish Statistical Institute reported that Turkey's annual inflation rate surged to 15.4 percent in June, the highest level since 2003. Consumer price inflation climbed 2.6 percent month-on-month in June, exceeding annual price increases in many developed economies. Turkey's annual inflation rate now was about four times the average in emerging markets. Producer price increases accelerated to 23.7 percent from 20.2 percent the previous month.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-inflation-surges-highest-2003|title=Turkish inflation surges to highest since 2003|date=3 July 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref> On the same day, the Automotive Distributors Association said that sales of the commercial vehicles sank 44 percent in June from June 2017, while car sales fell 38 percent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-car-sales-slump-underscoring-economic-slowdown|title=Turkish car sales slump, underscoring economic slowdown|date=3 July 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 5 July – ''Bloomberg'' reported that Turkish and international banks were taking control of [[Türk Telekom]], Turkey's biggest telephone company, due to billions of dollars in unpaid debt. Creditors set up a special purpose vehicle to acquire the company as they try to resolve Turkey's biggest-ever debt default.<ref name=Telekom>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-04/banks-said-poised-to-take-over-majority-stake-in-turk-telekom|title=Banks Are Poised to Take a Majority Stake in Turk Telekom|date=5 July 2018|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref> The same day, Bereket Enerji group was reported seeking buyers for two power plants as it negotiates with banks to refinance $4 billion in debt.<ref name=bereket />
* 9 July – Erdoğan appointed his son-in-law [[Berat Albayrak]] as economic chief of his new administration, in charge of a new ministry of treasury and finance. Erdoğan also appointed Mustafa Varank, a close adviser who had overseen a pro-government social media team on Twitter and elsewhere, to industry minister, the other key economy portfolio.<ref name=Varank /> These announcement fueled investor unease about competence and orthodoxy of economic policymaking, with the [[Turkish lira]] losing 3,8 percent of its value within one hour after Albayrak's appointment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-09/turkish-lira-slumps-after-names-son-in-law-as-economy-dzar|title=Turkish Lira Slumps as Erdogan Names Son-in-Law as Economy Chief|publisher=Bloomberg|date=9 July 2018}}</ref> Same day, Erdoğan by presidential decree appropriated to himself the authority to appoint the central bank governor, his deputies and the monetary policy committee members.<ref name=Fadi>{{cite web|url=http://time.com/5343999/turkey-erdogan-economic-crisis/|title=Turkey Is Heading for Economic Meltdown|date=20 July 2018|publisher=TIME|author1=Fadi Hakura}}</ref>
* 11 July – The lira dropped 2.5 percent to 4.82 per dollar, its weakest level since falling to an all-time low of 4.92 against the U.S. currency in May. The stock market in Istanbul dropped 5.2 percent to 91.290 points. Yields on government debt surged.<ref name=Varank>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/turkish-lira-slides-towards-record-erdogan-tightens-grip|title=Turkish lira slides towards record as Erdoğan tightens grip|publisher=Ahval|date=11 July 2018}}</ref> The next day, the lira touched an all-time low of 4.98 lira for a US dollar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/lira/istanbul-exchange-offices-stop-selling-dollars|title=Istanbul exchange offices stop selling dollars|publisher=Bloomberg|date=15 July 2018}}</ref> Two days later, the lira recorded its biggest weekly slump in almost a decade. The benchmark Borsa Istanbul 100 Index fell the most since the foiled coup in 2016, with the selloff dragging price-to-estimated earnings valuations to the lowest in more than nine years. The 10-year government bond yield surged almost 100 basis points this week.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-13/lira-heads-for-steepest-drop-in-almost-10-years-in-week-of-drama|title=Lira Heads for Steepest Drop in Almost 10 Years in Week of Drama|publisher=Ahval|date=12 July 2018}}</ref>
* 19 July – ÇEL-MER Çelik Endüstrisi, a leading Turkish steel producer also operating in the automobile sector, agriculture, white goods, machinery production and the defence industry, sought bankruptcy protection from the courts after it failed to repay its debts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/top-turkish-steel-company-seeks-bankruptcy-protection|title=Top Turkish steel company seeks bankruptcy protection|publisher=Ahval|date=19 July 2018}}</ref>
* 20 July – Ozensan Taahhut, a large Turkish construction company which has carried out construction contracts for state housing authority TOKI, the Justice Ministry, the Health Ministry and various municipalities, filed for bankruptcy protection.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-construction-firm-applies-bankruptcy-protection|title=Turkish construction firm applies for bankruptcy protection|publisher=Ahval|date=20 July 2018}}</ref>
* 24 July – The Central Bank of Turkey at a meeting of its Monetary Policy Committee unexpectedly left the benchmark interest rate for its lending unchanged at 17.75 percent despite the latest hike in inflation, leading to a selloff in the lira currency as well as in Turkey's dollar-denominated government bonds and in Turkey's stock market.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkeys-central-bank-leaves-policy-rate-unchanged-134939|title=Turkey’s Central Bank leaves policy rate unchanged, lira falls|date=24 July 2018|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloombergquint.com/global-economics/2018/07/24/turkey-defies-market-expectations-for-rate-rise-under-albayrak|title=Turkey Defies Market Expectations for Rate Rise Under Albayrak|date=24 July 2018|agency=Bloomberg}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/turkey-bonds/turkey-dollar-bonds-hit-as-central-bank-shies-away-from-rate-hike-idUKL5N1UK3NR|title=Turkey dollar bonds hit as central bank shies away from rate hike|date=24 July 2018|agency=Reuters}}</ref> In the words of Brad Bechtel, global head of foreign exchange at US investment bank ''Jefferies'', the central bank's decision to hold rates left Turkey as "the pariah of emerging markets".<ref name=pariah />
* 31 July – Turkey's central bank acknowledged it won’t meet its 5 percent inflation target for three more years, disappointing investors seeking signs that monetary policy would tighten. Although Governor Murat Cetinkaya pledged to raise borrowing costs when needed, he predicted 13.4 percent inflation through this year, 9.3 percent through 2019 and 6.7 percent by the end of 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-31/turkey-admits-to-three-more-years-of-missing-inflation-target|title=Turkey Admits to 3 More Years of Missing Inflation Target|date=31 July 2018|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref> The same day, the Turkish lira heading for its longest streak of monthly losses since an International Monetary Fund bailout in 2001, the Banks Association of Turkey (TBB) drew up a framework of principles for restructuring loans that exceed 50 million lira: If lenders with exposure to at least 75 percent of the total owed agree, a committee of lenders should order measures such as changes to shareholder structure and management, asset sales, spinoffs and capital injections, resolving restructurings within 150 days.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-31/turkey-banks-want-faster-loan-restructuring-as-lira-plunge-bites|title=Turkey Banks Want Faster Loan Restructuring as Lira Plunge Bites|date=31 July 2018|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref>
* 1 August – Due to the weakening lira, Turkey's state pipeline operator [[BOTAŞ]] raised the price of natural gas used by electric power plants by 50 percent. BOTAŞ also raised natural gas prices for residential use. The same day, the energy regulation authority raised electricity prices for industrial and residential use.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasdaq.com/article/turkeys-botas-hikes-natural-gas-price-for-power-generation-by-50-pct-20180731-01501|title=Turkey's Botas hikes natural gas price for power generation by 50 pct|date=31 July 2018|work=Nasdaq}}</ref> Also the same day, the Istanbul Chamber of Industry said in a monthly survey of manufacturers that producer price inflation in July accelerated to the highest pace in more than a decade, after already having accelerated to 23.7 percent in June due to the Erdoğan government stimulating economic growth with a series of measures ahead of elections on June 24.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-inflation/turkish-manufacturers-signal-more-bad-news-inflation|title=Turkish manufacturers signal more bad news for inflation|date=1 August 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 3 August – The Turkish Statistical Institute reported that Turkey's annual inflation rate increased to 15.9 percent, from 15.4 percent in June, extending the highest level since 2003. Producer price inflation climbed to 25 percent from 23.7 percent in June.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-inflation-accelerates-159-percent|title=Turkish inflation accelerates to 15.9 percent|date=3 August 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 9 August – Late in the day, Erdoğan in a speech called upon supporters not to pay heed to "various campaigns under way against Turkey", adding: "If they have dollars, we have our people, our righteousness and our God."<ref name=Allah /> As these remarks reduced markets’ hope that the Turkish government were willing to tighten monetary policy or begin economic reform, throughout the night and into the next morning, the lira in a dramatic fall lost almost 10 percent of its value, touching the mark of 6 lira for a US dollar.<ref name=Allah />
* 14 August – Erdoğan announced a policy of boycott of US electronic products.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/aug/14/erdogan-turkey-boycott-us-lira-trump-pastor-brunson|title=Erdoğan says Turkey will boycott US electronic products|date=14 August 2018|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> On the same day, Turkey's banking regulator placed comprehensive limits on use of credit card instalments.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/credit-cards/turkish-banking-regulator-limits-credit-card-spending|title=Turkish banking regulator limits credit card spending|date=14 August 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 16 August – The Turkish Statistical Institute reported that Turkey's industrial production declined by 2 percent in June from May, contracting for a second-straight month.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-manufacturing-growth-halves-lira-slump|title=Turkish manufacturing growth halves in lira slump|date=16 August 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 27 August – The Turkish Statistical Institute reported its economic confidence index dropping in August from 91.9 to 88.0, with another sharp drop in construction sector confidence leading the declines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.turkstat.gov.tr/PreHaberBultenleri.do?id=27879|title=Sectoral Confidence Indices, August 2018|date=27 August 2018|work=Turkish Statistical Institute}}</ref> *28 August - [[Moody's Investors Service|Moody's]] downgraded another 20 Turkish financial institutions. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-currency-banks/moodys-sounds-more-alarm-over-turkeys-banks-downgrades-20-firms-idUSKCN1LD1Z3|title=Moody's sounds more alarm over Turkey's banks, downgrades 20 firms|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en-US}}</ref> The ratings agency estimated that Turkey's [[operating environment]] had "deteriorated beyond its previous expectations", and predicted that this deterioration would continue.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-downgrades-20-financial-institutions-in-Turkey--PR_388052|title=Moody's downgrades 20 financial institutions in Turkey|date=2018-08-28|work=Moodys.com|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref>
* 29 August - Ownership of insolvent Turk Telekom transferred to "a joint venture of creditor banks."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/transfer-of-turk-telekoms-majority-stake-to-banks-approved-by-turkish-govt-136250|title=Transfer of Türk Telekom’s majority stake to banks approved by Turkish gov’t|date=29 August 2018|work=Hurriyet Daily News.}}</ref> Another measure of Turkish economic confidence slid from 92.2 in July to 83.9 in August, its lowest level since March 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/08/29/traders-sell-lira-after-turkeys-economic-confidence-hits-9-year-low.html|title=Traders dump lira after Turkey's economic confidence hits a nine-year low|last=Reid|first=David|date=2018-08-29|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref> Research from consultancy [[Capital Economics]] indicated that Turkey has entered a 'steep' recession and predicted that the Turkish economy would contract by as much as 4% in the fourth quarter of 2018, before stagnating in 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.fr/us/turkey-recession-capital-economics-2018-8|title=Turkey has dived headfirst into a 'steep' and 'deep' recession|website=Business Insider France|language=fr-FR|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref> *30 August - Erkan Kilimci, the deputy governor of the Turkish central bank, resigned, putting further pressure on the lira, which fell almost 5% against the dollar throughout the day.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/turkey-cenbank-board/turkish-cenbanks-deputy-governor-kilimci-to-resign-sources-idUSL8N1VL3TI|title=Turkish cenbank's deputy governor Kilimci to resign - sources|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gulf-times.com/story/604349/Turkish-lira-tumbles-another-5-as-deputy-bank-chie|title=Turkish lira tumbles another 5% as deputy bank chief quits|date=2018-08-30|work=Gulf-Times|access-date=2018-09-13|language=ar}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://businessweekme.com/turkey-central-bank-deputy-governor-quits/|title=Turkey Central Bank Deputy Governor Quits - Bloomberg Businessweek Middle East|website=businessweekme.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref> *3 September - Turkey's central bank announced that inflation in August had risen to nearly 18 percent, a 15-year high.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/turkish-inflation-soars-fueling-fears-of-an-economic-crisis/4556659.html|title=Turkish Inflation Soars, Fueling Fears of Economic Crisis|last=Jones|first=Dorian|work=VOA|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en}}</ref> *10 September - Data released by the Turkish Statistical Institute showed a slowdown in Turkey's economic growth in the second quarter of 2018. The country saw a 5.2 percent increase in GDP in the June quarter, compared to 7.3 percent in the first quarter of the year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/interestrates/turkey-gdp-growth-slows-in-q2-1027520250|title=Turkey GDP Growth Slows In Q2 {{!}} Markets Insider|last=GmbH|first=finanzen.net|work=markets.businessinsider.com|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref>Finance minister Berat Albayrak predicted that the economic slowdown would become more visible in the third quarter of 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-economy-gdp/turkish-economic-growth-dips-lira-crisis-darkens-outlook-idUSKCN1LQ0RD|title=Turkish economic growth dips, lira crisis darkens outlook|last=Kucukgocmen|first=Ali|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en-US}}</ref> *12 September - Erdoğan sacked the entire management staff of Turkey's [[sovereign wealth fund]] and named himself chairman of the fund.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.atimes.com/article/erdogan-takes-wheel-of-turkish-wealth-fund/|title=Erdogan takes wheel of Turkish wealth fund|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-12/erdogan-names-himself-chairman-of-turkey-wealth-fund-in-overhaul?srnd=premium-europe|title=Erdogan Names Himself Turkey Wealth Fund Chairman in Shakeup|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref> He also appointed Zafer Sonmez, formerly of Malaysia's government investment vehicle, as general manager.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-12/erdogan-names-himself-chairman-of-turkey-wealth-fund-in-overhaul?srnd=premium-europe|title=Erdogan Names Himself Turkey Wealth Fund Chairman in Shakeup|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref> Erdoğan's son-in-law [[Berat Albayrak]] was named as his deputy on the board of the sovereign wealth fund.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/8fe07c16-b693-11e8-bbc3-ccd7de085ffe|title=Erdogan takes control of Turkey’s sovereign wealth fund|last=|first=|date=|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref> *13 September - Erdoğan published an executive decree requiring all contracts between two Turkish entities to be made in lira. The measure took effect immediately and requires existing contracts to be reindexed to the lira within 30 days. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-13/turkey-bans-fx-based-contracts-for-some-sales-leasing-rentals?srnd=premium-europe|title=Erdogan Publishes Decree Forcing Contracts in Turkey to Be Made in Liras|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref> During a speech in Ankara, Erdoğan sharply criticized the Turkish central bank and urged the bank to cut interest rates.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-13/turkey-bans-fx-based-contracts-for-some-sales-leasing-rentals?srnd=premium-europe|title=Erdogan Dollar Ban Sows Confusion Ahead of Key Rate Decision|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-13/turkey-s-erdogan-bashes-central-bank-hours-before-rates-decision?srnd=premium-europe|title=Turkey's Erdogan Bashes Central Bank Hours Before Rates Decision|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref> Instead, the central bank sharply increased its benchmark lending rate, from 17.75 percent to 24 percent, beating Reuters' predictions of a hike to 22 percent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ea3f778e-b742-11e8-bbc3-ccd7de085ffe|title=Turkish central bank hikes rates to 24% in bid to stem currency crisis|last=|first=|date=|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref>
== International consequences == {{See also|European Union–Turkey relations|Turkey–United States relations}}
The crisis has brought considerable risks of [[financial contagion]]. One aspect concerns risk to foreign lenders, where according to the [[Bank for International Settlements]], international banks had outstanding loans of $224 billion to Turkish borrowers, including $83 billion from banks in Spain, $35 billion from banks in France, $18 billion from banks in Italy, $17 billion each from banks in the United States and in the United Kingdom, and $13 billion from banks in Germany.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://turkey.theglobepost.com/turkey-economy-bonds-erdogan/|title=Turkey’s Economy Under Great Stress After Erdogan’s Monetary Remarks|date=22 May 2018|publisher=The Globe Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/wirtschaft/article176765162/Drohende-Kreditausfaelle-Europas-Banken-fuerchten-tuerkischen-Kollaps.html|title=Europas Banken fürchten den türkischen Kollaps|date=29 May 2018|publisher=Die Welt|language=German}}</ref> Another aspect concerns the situation of other [[emerging economies]] with high levels of debt denominated in USD or EUR, with respect to which Turkey may either be considered "a canary in the coalmine" or even by its crisis and the bad handling thereof increase international investors' retreat for increased perception of risk in such countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/turkey-lira-turmoil-herald-global-financial-crisis-180825165156035.html|title=Turkey's lira turmoil could herald a global financial crisis|date=26 August 2018|publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref> On 31 May 2018, the Institute of Financial Research (IIF) reported that the Turkish crisis has already spread to [[Lebanon]], [[Colombia]] and [[South Africa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.nl/debt-contagion-in-argentina-and-turkey-is-spreading-to-other-countries-2018-6/?international=true&r=UK|title=Debt ‘contagion’ in Argentina and Turkey is spreading to other countries|date=6 June 2018|publisher=Businessinsider|language=English}}</ref>
[[File:Mehmet Simsek - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting 2011.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Mehmet Şimşek]] is credited with having tried but failed to bring back orthodoxy to Turkish interest rate policy.<ref name=monitor />]]
=== Timeline of events (2018) ===
* 19 January – [[Fitch Ratings]] closed its [[Istanbul]] office after Erdoğan made numerous negative comments about [[credit rating agencies]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Why has rating agency Fitch left Turkey?|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/opinion/ugur-gurses/why-has-rating-agency-fitch-left-turkey-126075|publisher=Hurriyet Daily News|date=22 January 2018}}</ref><ref name=e101 />
* 7 March – Credit ratings agency [[Moody's Investors Service]] downgraded Turkey's [[sovereign debt]], warning of an erosion of checks and balances under Erdoğan, and saying that the [[Turkish military operation in Afrin]], having strained [[Turkey–United States relations|ties with Washington]] and drawn the country deeper into the Syrian civil war, had added an extra layer of geopolitical risk.<ref>{{cite web|title=Moody’s downgrades Turkish debt|url=https://www.ft.com/content/18004182-2263-11e8-9a70-08f715791301|publisher=Financial Times|date=8 March 2018}}</ref>
* 1 May – Credit ratings agency [[Standard & Poor's]] cut Turkey's debt rating further into junk territory, citing widening concern about the outlook for inflation amid a sell-off in the Turkish lira currency.<ref>{{cite web|title=S&P cuts Turkey's rating deeper into 'junk'|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/turkey-ratings/update-1-sp-cuts-turkeys-rating-deeper-into-junk-idUSL8N1S85JM|agency=Reuters|date=1 May 2018}}</ref>
* 22 May – Turkish government dollar bonds traded at prices lower than those of [[Senegal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/storm-turkeys-economy-bonds-trade-below-senegals|title=Storm in Turkey’s economy as bonds trade below Senegal’s|date=22 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref> On the same day, the [[Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus]] (TRNC) government started discussing abandonment of the Turkish lira for another currency.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/turkish-cypriots-consider-abandoning-sinking-lira|title=Turkish Cypriots consider abandoning sinking lira|date=22 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 23 May - the [[Central Bank of the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus]] discontinues offering loans to their citizens unless their salary is paid in a foreign currency.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews2.com/trnc/turkish-cyprus-bans-foreign-currency-personal-loans|title=Turkish Cyprus bans foreign currency personal loans|date=23 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 28 May – [[Jordan]] terminated its free-trade agreement with Turkey, which had lately seen Turkish exports to Jordan increase fivefold.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-jordan/jordan-end-turkish-free-trade-agreement|title=Jordan to end Turkish free trade agreement|date=28 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 30 May – Credit ratings agency [[Moody's Investors Service]] lowered its estimate for growth of the Turkish economy in 2018 from 4 percent to 2.5 percent and in 2019 from 3.5 percent to 2 percent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-growth-forecast-almost-halved-moodys|title=Turkish growth forecast almost halved at Moody's|date=30 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 6 June – Bloomberg reported that [[Astaldi]], an Italian multinational construction company, was poised to sell its stake in the flagship [[Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge]] project for $467 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-06-06/astaldi-bridge-stake-is-said-valued-up-to-467-million-by-bidder|title=Astaldi May Fetch More Than What It Needs in Istanbul Bridge Sale|date=6 June 2018|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref> The project had failed to meet projections, requiring Ankara to boost operators' revenue from treasury coffers,<ref name=selim>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/ekonomi/iste-kopru-gercekleri-40507240|title=İşte köprü gerçekleri|date=2 July 2017|work=Hurriyet|language=Turkish}}</ref> and since early 2018, the partners in the joint venture had sought restructuring of $2.3 billion of debt from creditors.<ref name=pile />
* 7 June – Credit ratings agency Moody's Investors Service downgraded the ratings of 17 Turkish banks, reasoning "that the operating environment in Turkey has deteriorated, with negative implications for the institutions’ funding profile."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/moodys-takes-rating-actions-on-19-turkish-financial-institutions-132988|title=Moody’s takes rating actions on 19 Turkish financial institutions|date=8 June 2018|publisher=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> Also on 7 June, Moody's put eleven of Turkey’s top companies under review, because their credit quality was correlated in varying degrees to the government in [[Ankara]]. The firms included [[Koç Holding]], Turkey’s biggest industrial conglomerate, [[Doğuş Holding]], which has applied to banks to restructure some of its debt, and [[Turkish Airlines]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-business/top-turkish-firms-put-under-review-moodys|title=Top Turkish firms put under review by Moody's|date=7 June 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 18 June – Credit ratings agency [[Fitch Ratings]] lowered its estimate for growth of the Turkish economy in 2018 from 4.7 percent to 3.6 percent, citing reasons including an anticipated reduction in government stimulus.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/fitch-cuts-turkeys-growth-outlook|title=Fitch cuts Turkey’s growth outlook|date=18 June 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 26 June – The [[European Union]]'s [[General Affairs Council]] stated that "the Council notes that Turkey has been moving further away from the European Union. Turkey’s [[Accession of Turkey to the European Union|accession negotiations]] have therefore effectively come to a standstill and no further chapters can be considered for opening or closing and no further work towards the modernisation of the [[European Union–Turkey Customs Union|EU-Turkey Customs Union]] is foreseen."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cyprus-mail.com/2018/06/26/eu-council-issues-strong-message-about-turkeys-obligations/|title=EU Council issues strong message about Turkey’s obligations|date=26 June 2018|publisher=Cyprus Mail}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.zeit.de/politik/ausland/2018-06/recep-tayyip-erdogan-wahl-eu-zollunion-erklaerung|title=EU will Zollunion mit der Türkei nicht ausbauen|date=27 June 2018|publisher=Die Zeit|language=german}}</ref>
* 13 July – Credit ratings agency Fitch Ratings downgraded Turkey's debt rating further into junk with negative outlook, reasoning that "economic policy credibility has deteriorated in recent months and initial policy actions following elections in June have heightened uncertainty (...) Monetary policy credibility has been damaged by comments by President Erdoğan suggesting a greater role of the presidency in setting monetary policy after the elections (...) Monetary policy has persistently been unable to bring inflation near its 5% target and inflation expectations have become unanchored. Key figures from the previous administration with reformist credentials were excluded from a new cabinet, appointed on 9 July, while the son-in-law of the president was appointed as Minister of Treasury and Finance."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/fitch-downgrades-turkey-bb-outlook-negative|title=Fitch Downgrades Turkey to 'BB'; Outlook Negative|date=13 July 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
* 20 July – The government of Germany lifted export credit guarantee sanctions against Turkey, which it had implemented a year earlier in order to protest the ongoing state of emergency (OHAL) in Turkey and to effect the release of German citizen [[Deniz Yücel]] and others held under arrest by the Turkish government, after the German citizens concerned were freed and the state of emergency was lifted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.handelsblatt.com/politik/international/export-absicherung-bundesregierung-hebt-obergrenzen-fuer-tuerkei-buergschaften-auf/22829208.html|title=Bundesregierung hebt Obergrenzen für Türkei-Bürgschaften auf|date=21 July 2018|publisher=Handelsblatt|language=german}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/europe/2018-07-30/how-save-us-turkey-relationship|title=How to Save the U.S.-Turkey Relationship|date=30 July 2018|publisher=Foreign Affairs|author=Amanda Sloat}}</ref>
* 26 July – European rating agency Scope Ratings placed Turkey's BB+ sovereign ratings on review for downgrade, citing i) "Deterioration in Turkey’s economic policy and governance framework both before and in following the June election, which weigh on the effectiveness and credibility of fiscal, monetary and structural economic policy management" alongside ii) "Increasing downside risks to Turkey’s macroeconomic stability stemming from external vulnerabilities."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scoperatings.com/#search/research/detail/157333EN|title=Scope places Turkey’s BB+ ratings under review for downgrade|date=26 July 2018|publisher=Scope Ratings}}</ref>
* 27 July – At their summit in Johannesburg between July 25 and July 27, [[BRICS]] countries rejected Erdoğan's desire for Turkey to join the bloc.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://eurasiantimes.com/brics-turkey/|title=BRICS Rejects Full-Time Membership to Turkey; Ankara Dejected|date=30 July 2018|publisher=The EurAsian Times}}</ref>
* 10 August – The [[European Central Bank]] voiced increased concerns about the exposure of some of the [[Euro]] currency area's biggest lenders to Turkey – chiefly [[BBVA]], [[UniCredit]] and [[BNP Paribas]] – in light of the lira's dramatic fall.<ref name=Allah>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/51311230-9be7-11e8-9702-5946bae86e6d|title=Turkish lira plunges as crisis mounts|date=10 August 2018|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref> On the same day, the US government started "a bullet a day" economic sanctions against Turkey, designed to effect the release of US citizen [[Andrew Brunson]] and 15 others, held under arrest (on charges described as a sham by U.S. officials) by the Turkish government; in a first step, US President Donald Trump announced a doubling of tariffs on Turkish steel and aluminum.<ref>https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1027899286586109955</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/turkish-turmoil-is-tied-to-pastors-fate-1533942854|title=Turkish Turmoil Is Tied to Pastor’s Fate|date=10 August 2018|publisher=Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
* 16 August – European rating agency Scope Ratings downgraded Turkey's sovereign ratings to BB- from BB+ and revised the Outlook to Negative, citing in the downgrade: i) "Deterioration in Turkey’s economic policy predictability and credibility, in view of monetary, fiscal and structural economic policies inconsistent with the rebalancing of the economy onto a more sustainable path"; ii) "Accentuated macroeconomic imbalances"; and iii) "The impact of balance of payment weaknesses on modest levels of international reserves."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scoperatings.com/#search/research/detail/157475EN|title=Scope downgrades Turkey’s credit rating to BB- from BB+ and changes Outlook to Negative|date=16 August 2018|publisher=Scope Ratings}}</ref>
* 17 August – Credit ratings agencies Standard & Poor's and Moody's downgraded Turkey's debt rating further into junk, down to B+ (S&P) and Ba3 (Moody's).<ref name=ft1>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/9ed3b3e2-a25b-11e8-85da-eeb7a9ce36e4|title=S&P, Moody’s send Turkey deeper into junk territory|publisher=[[Financial Times]]|date=17 August 2018|accessdate=19 August 2018}}</ref> S&P predicted a recession for 2019 and inflation to peak at 22% in 2018, before subsiding to below 20% by mid-2019.<ref name=ft1 /> Moody's said that the chances of a swift and positive resolution to Turkey's turmoil was becoming less likely thanks to the "further weakening of Turkey’s public institutions and the related reduction in the predictability of Turkish policy making."<ref name=ft1 />
== Improvements == On 29th November the Turkish lira hit an 4 month high in value against the [[US Dollar]]. It recovered from 7.0738 against the dollar to 5.17 on 29 November, an increase of 36.8%. Reuters also reported in a response to a poll that it expects the inflation to decrease for the November month. The reasons that were given are the positive exchanges, discounts on products and taxt cuts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasdaq.com/article/turkish-cpi-expected-to-fall-from-15year-peak-in-november-poll-shows-20181129-00458|title=Turkish CPI expected to fall from 15-year peak in November, poll shows|date=29 November 2018|publisher=Nasdaq|language=English}}</ref>
== Politics and corruption ==
=== Turkish government claims of a foreign plot === {{See also|Conspiracy theories in Turkey}}
From a background of a long history of promoting conspiracy theories by the Turkish government of Erdoğan and the [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party]] (AKP),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/09/12/the-tin-foil-hats-are-out-in-turkey/|title=The Tin-Foil Hats Are Out in Turkey|date=12 September 2016|publisher=[[Foreign Policy]]|author=Mustafa Akyol|accessdate=10 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2018/06/turkey-erdogan-election-kurds/563240/|title=How Nietzsche Explains Turkey|date=21 June 2018|publisher=[[The Atlantic]]|author=Selim Koru}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2017/01/turkey-believes-all-terrorists-are-united-against-it.html|title=Why Turkish government pushes 'global conspiracy' narrative|date=9 January 2017|publisher=[[Al-Monitor]]|author=Mustafa Akyol|accessdate=10 January 2017}}</ref> with the emergence of the financial crisis, members of the government have claimed that the crisis were not attributable to the government's policies, but rather were the conspiratorial work of shadowy foreign actors, seeking to harm Turkey and deprive President Erdoğan of support.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/a9b3dc8a-5a6a-11e8-bdb7-f6677d2e1ce8|title=Tumbling Turkish lira tests voters’ support for Erdogan|date=18 May 2018|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref><ref name=e101 /> During the major lira sell-off on 23 May, Turkey's energy minister, Erdoğan's son-in-law [[Berat Albayrak]], told the media that the recent sharp drop in the value of the lira was the result of the machinations of Turkey's enemies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/berat-albayrak/currency-crisis-clear-operation-against-turkey-energy-minister|title=Currency crisis “clear operation” against Turkey - Energy minister|date=23 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref> On 30 May, foreign minister [[Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu]] claimed that the plunge of the lira would have been caused by an organized campaign masterminded abroad, adding that the conspiracy would include both "the interest rate lobby" and "some Muslim countries", which he however refused to name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkish-fm-accuses-some-muslim-countries-for-trying-to-demolish-economy-132594|title=Turkish FM accuses ‘some Muslim countries’ for trying ‘to demolish economy’|date=30 May 2018|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> At an election campaign rally in Istanbul on 11 June, Erdoğan claimed that the recently published 7.4 percent GDP growth figure for the January to March period would demonstrate victory against what he called "conspirators" whom he blamed for May's heavy falls of the Turkish lira.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/erdogan-seizes-on-growth-figures-to-persuade-skeptical-public-/4434745.html|title=Erdogan Seizes on Growth Figures to Persuade Skeptical Public|date=11 June 2018|work=VOA News}}</ref> In August, Erdoğan started using the formula of "the world fighting an economic war against Turkey".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2018/08/08/turkeys-erdogan-says-hes-fighting-an-economic-war-hes-right-its-war-against-reality/|title=Turkey is fighting an ‘economic war’—against reality|date=8 August 2018|work=Washington Post}}</ref> Part of this idea likely had to do with a row with America regarding the case of U.S. citizen [[Andrew Brunson]], which had a deletorious effect on Turkey-U.S. relations. Alongside sanctions on specific government figures, [[tariffs]] were also used by both countries to create economic pressure. Vox describes it as a "[[trade war|trade spat]]".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kirby |first1=Jen |title=The US-Turkey trade spat, explained |url=https://www.vox.com/world/2018/8/15/17687928/turkey-united-states-tariffs-lira-andrew-brunson |accessdate=August 15, 2018 |work=Vox |publisher=Vox Media |date=August 15, 2018}}</ref> Commentators such as Vox's Jen Kirby have pointed to the pivotal role Brunson's case plays in it.
A tariff on steel and other products was placed on Turkey by the United States. However, Sarah Sanders has described the American tariffs as related to "national defense"<ref>https://www.business-standard.com/article/international/us-tariffs-on-turkey-for-national-security-will-not-be-lifted-white-house-118081600095_1.html</ref>, and thus not changeable by circumstances, noting that only the sanctions would be lifted upon the release of Brunson.
Erdogan describes these tariffs as an "economic war" against Turkey. <ref>https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-currency-erdogan/turkey-is-a-target-of-economic-war-erdogan-says-idUSKBN1KW08U</ref>
In retaliation, Turkey announced tariffs on US products, most notably the iPhone. <ref>https://www.voanews.com/a/erdogan-wants-boycott-of-us-electronics/4527699.html</ref> The tariffs by Turkey cover products such as American cars, and coal. At a White House Press conference, Sanders described these as "regrettable". <ref>https://www.voanews.com/a/white-house-condemns-turkey-s-tariffs-on-us-products/4530059.html</ref> Sanders claimed that the Turkish economic trouble was part of a long-term trend that wasn't related to any actions America did.
On August 22, 2018, [[John R. Bolton]], speaking to Reuters, said "the Turkish government made a big mistake in not releasing Pastor Brunson... [e]very day that goes by that mistake continues, this crisis could be over instantly if they did the right thing as a NATO ally, part of the West, and release pastor Brunson without condition." <ref name="Reuters Bolton economy">{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Dan |title=U.S.-Turkey crisis could end 'instantly' if pastor freed: Bolton |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-turkey-bolton-interview/us-turkey-crisis-could-end-instantly-if-pastor-freed-bolton-idUSKCN1L70A5 |accessdate=28 August 2018 |agency=Reuters |date=22 August 2018}}</ref> He went on to state that Turkey's membership in NATO was not as much of a major foreign policy issue for the US, but instead the American focus was on individuals that the United States believes Turkey is holding for non-legitimate reasons. Bolton also expressed skepticism in regard to Qatar's attempts to infuse money in the Turkish economy.<ref name="Reuters Bolton economy" /> Erdogan spokesman Ibrahim Kalin, in a written statement, described these remarks as an admission that, contra Sanders, the American tariffs were, in fact, in relation to the Brunson case and proof that the US intended them to economically war against Turkey. <ref>https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-currency-erdogan-nato-exclusiv/exclusive-bolton-remarks-proof-us-targeting-turkey-in-economic-war-erdogan-spokesman-idUSKCN1L729I</ref>
According to a poll from April 2018, 42 percent of Turks, and 59 percent of Erdoğan's governing AKP voters, saw the decline in the lira as a plot by foreign powers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/forty-two-percent-turks-say-liras-drop-foreign-plot|title=Forty-two percent of Turks say lira's drop is foreign plot|date=18 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref> In another poll from July, 36 percent of survey respondents said it the AKP government was most responsible for the depreciation of the Turkish lira, while 42 percent said it was foreign governments.<ref name=poll>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2018/08/22/turkeys-currency-is-plummeting-heres-what-it-might-mean-for-president-erdogan/?noredirect=on|title=Will Turkey’s currency crisis hurt Erdogan? Here’s what a new poll shows.|date=23 August 2018|publisher=Washington Post}}</ref> This was explained by [[Censorship in Turkey|the government's far-reaching control]] over [[Media of Turkey|the media]] via the fact that those respondents mostly reading alternative views in the Internet were more likely to see their own government responsible, at 47 percent, than foreign governments, at 34 percent.<ref name=poll />
[[File:Muharrem İnce cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Muharrem İnce]] (pictured) and [[Meral Akşener]] vowed to restore integrity to economic institutions in Turkey.]] [[File:Meral Akşener İYİ Party.jpg|thumb|right|[[Meral Akşener]], İYİ Party leader and presidential candidate, announcing her economic policies on 7 May.]]
=== Crisis as a topic in the June 2018 elections === {{Further|Turkish general election, 2018}}
On 16 May, a day after [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party]] (AKP) president [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] had unsettled markets during his visit to London by suggesting he would curb the independence of the [[Central Bank of Turkey]] after the election, [[Republican People's Party (Turkey)|Republican People's Party]] (CHP) presidential candidate [[Muharrem İnce]] and [[İyi Party|İYİ Party]] presidential candidate [[Meral Akşener]] both vowed to ensure the independence of the central bank if elected.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-election-chp/erdogans-policies-driving-turkey-to-the-edge-challenger-says-idUSKCN1IH2BO|title=Erdogan's policies driving Turkey to the edge, challenger says|date=16 May 2018|agency=Reuters}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/tired-driver-is-sending-turkeys-economy-over-cliff-edge-iyi-party-head-aksener-131932|title=‘Tired driver’ is sending Turkey’s economy over cliff edge: İYİ Party head Akşener|date=16 May 2018|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/chp-presidential-candidate-muharrem-ince-vows-to-ensure-central-bank-independence-if-elected-131953|title=CHP presidential candidate Muharrem İnce vows to ensure Central Bank independence if elected|date=17 May 2018|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref>
In a 26 May interview [[Muharrem İnce presidential campaign, 2018|on his campaign trail]], CHP presidential candidate Muharrem İnce said on economic policy that "the central bank can only halt the lira’s slide temporarily by raising interest rates, because it’s not the case that depreciation fundamentally stems from interest rates being too high or too low. So, the central bank will intervene, but the things that really need to be done are in the political and legal areas. Turkey needs to immediately be extricated from a political situation that breeds economic uncertainty, and its economy must be handled by independent and autonomous institutions. My economic team is ready, and we have been working together for a long time."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/muharrem-ince/muharrem-ince-turkish-economy-needs-political-reform-exclusive|title=Muharrem İnce: Turkish economy needs political reform|date=26 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
In a nationwide survey conducted between 13 and 20 May, 45 percent saw the economy (including the steadily-dropping lira and unemployment) as the greatest challenge facing Turkey, with foreign policy at 18 percent, the justice system at 7 percent and terror and security at 5 percent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/economy/turkeys-biggest-problems-economy-unemployment-survey|title=Turkey’s biggest problems economy, unemployment - survey|date=23 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
İYİ Party presidential candidate Meral Akşener, supported by a strong economic team led by former Central Bank Governor Durmuş Yılmaz,<ref name=bentley /> had on 7 May presented her party's economic program, saying that "we will purchase the debts from consumer loans, credit card and overdraft accounts of 4.5 million citizens whose debts are under legal supervision of banks or consumer financing companies and whose debts have been sold to collection companies as of April 30, 2018. It is our duty to help our citizens with this condition, as the state has helped big companies in difficult situations."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/iyi-party-chair-aksener-vows-to-restructure-8-billion-lira-debts-of-4-5-million-citizens-131472|title=İYİ Party chair Akşener vows to restructure 8 billion-lira debts of 4.5 million citizens|date=7 May 2018|publisher=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref>
On 13 June, CHP leader [[Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu]] reiterated the opposition's view that the [[state of emergency]] in place since July 2016 were an impediment to Turkey's currency, investment and economy, vowing that it be lifted within 48 hours in case of an opposition victory in the elections.<ref name=kemal>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/chp-vows-to-lift-emergency-rule-48-hours-after-ince-takes-office-as-president-133206|title=CHP vows to lift emergency rule 48 hours after İnce takes office as president|date=13 June 2018|publisher=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> İYİ Party leader and presidential candidate Akşener had made the same vow on 18 May,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/i-will-lift-state-of-emergency-day-after-elections-if-elected-meral-aksener-132071|title=I will lift state of emergency day after elections if elected: Meral Akşener|date=20 May 2018|publisher=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> while CHP presidential candidate İnce had said on 30 May: "Foreign countries do not trust Turkey, thus they do not invest in our country. When Turkey becomes a country of the rule law, foreign investors will invest thus the lira will gain value."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/emergency-rule-must-be-lifted-to-lure-foreign-investments-chp-candidate-ince-132605|title=Emergency rule must be lifted to lure foreign investments: CHP candidate İnce|date=30 May 2018|publisher=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> Early June, President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan had suggested in an interview that the issue of lifting the emergency rule would be discussed the elections, however asked back: "What's wrong with the state of emergency?"<ref name=kemal />
=== Allegations of corruption and insider trading === {{see also|Corruption in Turkey|2013 corruption scandal in Turkey}}
In early April, [[Peoples' Democratic Party (Turkey)|Peoples' Democratic Party]] (HDP) presidential candidate [[Selahattin Demirtaş]], writing in a letter from prison—where he has been held without conviction since 2016, accused of inciting violence with words—<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/13/magazine/inside-turkeys-purge.html|title=Inside Turkey’s Purge|date=13 April 2017|publisher=The New York Times Magazine|author=Suzy Hansen}}</ref> [[Selahattin Demirtaş presidential campaign, 2018|saying]] that "the biggest problem for the youth in Turkey is corruption which has accompanied with AKP governance."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/09052018|title=Presidential candidate Demirtas promises youth, women, pension reforms|date=9 May 2018|publisher=Rudaw}}</ref>
In late May, [[Republican People's Party (Turkey)|Republican People's Party]] (CHP) deputy chair Aykut Erdoğdu called the Financial Crimes Investigation Board of Turkey (MASAK) to investigate exchange rate transactions made amid rapid decline and partial recovery in the value of the lira on 23 May, alleging [[insider trading]] by market participants who knew of the 300 basis points interest rate hike by the Turkish central bank in advance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-economy/opposition-demands-investigation-transactions-during-lira-slide|title=Opposition demands investigation of transactions during lira slide|date=25 May 2018|publisher=Ahval}}</ref>
In early July, Turkey's Capital Markets Board (SPK) said that until the end of August share purchases on the [[Borsa Istanbul]] by people party to the relevant company's internal information, or by those close to them (insider trading), would not be subject to a stock market abuse directive. Amid a public outcry, it suspended the directive some days later, without giving a reason for the move.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-bourse-directive/turkish-financial-watchdog-suspends-stock-market-abuse-article-idUSKBN1K40EQ|title=Turkish financial watchdog suspends stock market abuse article|date=14 July 2018|agency=Reuters}}</ref><ref name=erosion>{{cite web|url=https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/political-control-oversight-bodies-erodes-trust-turkeys-economy|title=Political control of oversight bodies erodes trust in Turkey’s economy|date=22 August 2018|publisher=Ahval|author=Zülfikar Doğan}}</ref>
